         <tei:p>Labena malecasta sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 16)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female. Large species, fore wing length 13-15 mm. Malar space 0-8 times as long as basal mandibular<tei:lb/>width. Occipital carina mediodorsally complete, ventrally joining hypostomal carina and continuing to<tei:lb/>mandibular base as a distinct carina, not developed into a flange. Pronotum laterally with a median<tei:lb/>swelling; mesothorax laterally and ventrally bearing sparse, long, white pubescence; mesoscutum finely<tei:lb/>punctate with indications of weak transverse striae; horizontal mesopleural furrow indistinct; metapleuron<tei:lb/>indistinctly puncto-striate; submetapleural carina anteriorly abruptly expanded into an almost quadrate<tei:lb/>lobe. Propodeum with anterior transverse carina present centrally, separating area superomedia from area<tei:lb/>basalis, latter with transverse striae. Fore wing with 3r-m converging towards 2r-m, almost joining at<tei:lb/>junction with Rs. Hind wing with distal abscissa of Ci present in membrane, not confluent with Cu\ and<tei:lb/>cu-a. Mid tibia with a longitudinal row of spine-like bristles on outer surface, proximally slender, distally<tei:lb/>swollen, with an oblique furrow on inner surface. Gaster with sternite 1 0-7 times as long as hind coxa,<tei:lb/>reaching to well behind level of spiracle; tergites 2-4 smooth and polished with sparse, fine punctures; apex<tei:lb/>of terminal plate of tergite 8 simple . Ovipositor pro j ecting beyond apex of gaster by at least 3 5 times length<tei:lb/>of hind tibia, the apex bearing distinct teeth.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coloration. Black to red. Palps, clypeus, inner orbit of face, emargination of orbit opposite antennal<tei:lb/>socket, thin line on outer orbit, antero-lateral corner of mesoscutum, tegula, subalar process, posterior 0-3<tei:lb/>of scutellum, postscutellum, posterior 0-3 of propodeum, posterior margin of tergites 1-7, fore leg (except<tei:lb/>coxa and distal part of femur), mid leg with distal end of femur, tibia and tarsal segments 1-4, hind leg with<tei:lb/>distal end of tibia and basal tarsal segment yellow. Antennal disruptive mark at distal end except for last<tei:lb/>1-2 segments which are blackish.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male. Similar to female but with fore wing length 12 mm; malar space 0-5 times basal mandibular width;<tei:lb/>gaster with sternite 10-9 times as long as hind coxa. Gonosquama with an apical tuft of long hairs.<tei:lb/>Coloration similar to female.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This large species is structurally rather similar to L. chadwickii. The female has a subtly different<tei:lb/>colour pattern and a longer ovipositor whilst the male is distinct in bearing a tuft of long hair on the<tei:lb/>gonosquama. L. malecasta is only known from Tasmania, Victoria and the southern alps of New South<tei:lb/>Wales.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>AUSTRALIAN LABENINI &amp; POECILOCRYPTINI 117</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype $, Tasmania (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. New South Wales: 1 cf, Mt Kosciusko, Dainer's Gap, x.1929 (Musgrave) (AM). Victoria:<tei:lb/>1 9, Warburton, ii-iii (TC). Tasmania: 1 $ (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Labena pudenda sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 10, 20, 21)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female. Large to very large species, fore wing length 13-20 mm. Malar space 0-7 times as long as basal<tei:lb/>mandibular width. Occipital carina mediodorsally complete, ventrally joining hypostomal carina and<tei:lb/>forming flange. Pronotum laterally with a median convex swelling; mesothorax laterally and ventrally<tei:lb/>bearing sparse, short white pubescence; mesoscutum smooth with sparse fine punctures; horizontal<tei:lb/>mesopleural furrow distinct; mesopleuron smooth and polished; metapleuron smooth and polished;<tei:lb/>submetapleural carina anteriorly expanded with a large rounded striate lobe. Propodeum with anterior<tei:lb/>transverse carina absent centrally so areae superomedia and basalis are confluent. Fore wing with 3r-m<tei:lb/>slightly inclined, 2r-m strongly converging towards 3r-m, both widely separated at junction with Rs. Hind<tei:lb/>wing with distal abscissa of Ci complete. Mid tibia without obvious spine-like bristles on outer surface,<tei:lb/>proximally slender and slightly flattened, distally swollen. Gaster with sternite 1 0-7-1-0 times as long as<tei:lb/>hind coxa, reaching behind level of spiracle; tergites 2-4 smooth and polished; apex of terminal plate of<tei:lb/>tergite 8 simple. Ovipositor projecting beyond apex of gaster by 4-0-4-4 times length of hind tibia, the apex<tei:lb/>bearing strong teeth.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coloration. Black to deep red. Palps, labrum, clypeus, inner and outer orbits, ventral corner of<tei:lb/>propleuron, tegula, subalar process, scutellum, postscutellum, posterolateral corner of propodeum,<tei:lb/>posterior margin of tergites 1-7 (may be divided medially), fore and mid leg with distal part of coxa,<tei:lb/>trochanter, femur, distal and proximal ends of tibia and tarsal segments 1-4, hind leg with distal end of each<tei:lb/>segment including tarsal segment 1 and entire tarsal segments 2-4 yellow.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male. Similar to female but with fore wing length 10-11 mm; malar space 0-9 times basal mandibular<tei:lb/>width; gaster with sternite 1 0-9 times as long as hind coxa. Gonosquama distally flattened and fringed<tei:lb/>almost entirely by very fine hairs. Coloration similar to female.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This large, rather slender species is easily recognized by the very long ovipositor of the female.<tei:lb/>The tip of this organ is distinctive in having much coarser teeth than are usually found in species of Labena.<tei:lb/>Males have the most specialized gonosquamae of any Australian Labena species. L. pudenda seems to be a<tei:lb/>southern temperate forest species and has been recorded from New South Wales, Victoria and the<tei:lb/>Australian Capital Territory.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype $, Victoria: BogongHigh Plains, xii.1931 (Kubala) (NMV).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. New South Wales: 1 cf, Dainer's Gap (36-12S 148-43E), xi.1973 (Morrow) (ANIC); 1 $,<tei:lb/>Kosciusko, xii.1922 (Goldfinch) (AM); 1 $, Mt York, x.1930 (NMV). Australian Capital Territory: 1 $,<tei:lb/>Lees Springs, xi.1953 (Riek) (ANIC). Victoria: 1 ? , 1 cf , 'Alps', xii. 1910 (NMV); 1 $ , Mt Buffalo, 1600 m,<tei:lb/>ii (TC); 1 ? , 2 cf , 'Victoria', ii.1901 (French) (BMNH); 1 $ , Yarra Falls, S. Warburton, i.1907 (Barnard)<tei:lb/>(NMV).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CERTONOTUS Kriechbaumer</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Certonotus Kriechbaumer, 1889: 308. Type-species: Certonotus varius Kriechbaumer, by monotypy.<tei:lb/>Asperellus Townes in Townes et al., 1961: 471. Type-species: Certonotus hinnuleus Krieger, by original<tei:lb/>designation. Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Small to very large insects, fore wing length 4-17 mm; clypeus flat, transverse, margin thin, evenly arcuate;<tei:lb/>labrum barely projecting; mandible short, stout but tapered, twisted 25-30, with upper tooth the longer;<tei:lb/>outer mandibular surface with a groove bearing hairs; malar space trans-striate, usually a little longer than<tei:lb/>basal mandibular width. Occipital carina dorsally absent; eye not indented next to antennal socket.<tei:lb/>Antenna slightly clavate, apically pointed, without a flat sensillum. Mesoscutum with transverse rugae,<tei:lb/>notauli weak, notaular crests very weak. Propodeum usually quite short, convexly rounded with spiracle<tei:lb/>elliptical; anterior transverse carina usually complete except centrally, other carinae often reduced, area<tei:lb/>superomedia usually not delineated; gaster inserted high up on propodeum, above level of hind coxae.<tei:lb/>Fore tibia with a short tooth on outer distal margin; fore tarsus unspecialized; hind coxa of female with an<tei:lb/>anterior carina continued ventrally as a process, the area behind this carina concave and closely punctate;</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>118 I. D. GAULD &amp; G. A. HOLLOW AY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>tarsal claws simple. Fore wing with cu-a opposite or proximal to base of Rs&amp;M; 3r-m usually present,<tei:lb/>areolet almost triangular, often petiolate above; 2m-cu sinuous, with two close bullae. Hind wing with<tei:lb/>distal abscissa of Cu\ present or incomplete or absent; first abscissa of Cu\ shorter than cu-a; basal cell<tei:lb/>slender; Sc with one or two hamuli. Gaster quite long, tergite 1 from stout to quite slender, with spiracles<tei:lb/>before centre; sternite 1 usually reaching nearly to level of spiracles; laterotergites 2-4 membranous,<tei:lb/>folded under; tergite 8 highly modified, projecting laterally as a pair of prominences at either side of<tei:lb/>ovipositor base, dorsally with a detached plate projecting through concave orifice in hind margin, tergite 7<tei:lb/>often mediodorsally incised. Ovipositor projecting beyond apex of gaster by 3-0-8-0 times length of hind<tei:lb/>tibia, its apex compressed, the upper valve with weak blunt serrations, the lower valve enclosing the upper<tei:lb/>and bearing fine file-like teeth.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Certonotus is a large genus centred in Australia with a few species present in New Guinea, New<tei:lb/>Zealand and South America. Previously, the species now included in this taxon were divided between<tei:lb/>Certonotus and Asperellus (Townes, 1969; Gauld, 1984) but more detailed study has revealed that the<tei:lb/>latter genus is almost certainly polyphyletic. In the present work 23 species are recognized as occurring in<tei:lb/>Australia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Certotonus species are easily recognized by the possession of transverse rugae on the mesoscutum, a<tei:lb/>feature immediately distinguishing the genus from all other Australian labenines. Certonotus species may<tei:lb/>inadvertently be confused with Rhyssini, especially Epirhyssa species. Unlike rhyssines, which have an<tei:lb/>undeveloped submetapleural carina, Certonotus has a broad expanded lobe present anteriorly. Further-<tei:lb/>more, Certonotus has fine file-like teeth on the ovipositor apex, not the coarse teeth found in Epirhyssa<tei:lb/>(Gauld, 1984).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The relationships of the Australian species. Gauld (1984) suggested that Asperellus, as defined by Townes<tei:lb/>(1969), was merely a specialized species-group of Certonotus. Further study suggests that Asperellus is not<tei:lb/>even a monophyletic group, but rather an assemblage of species of Certonotus that lack the distal abscissa<tei:lb/>of Cu\. The majority of species (farrugiai, pineus, mogimbensis, zebrus, toolangi, hinnuleus and<tei:lb/>leeuwinensis) do comprise a natural group, the leeuwinensis-group. All have rather similar propodeal<tei:lb/>carination, in that the posterior transverse carina is absent but a large smooth area is enclosed by the<tei:lb/>anterior carina and the lateral carinae; they possess a very small areolet, have one or more spine-like<tei:lb/>bristles present on the hind tibia and have a slightly convex face. Most have a rather short first sternite, a<tei:lb/>quite deeply divided tergite 7 and a pronounced lobe on tergite 8. Only in farrugiai is tergite 7 barely<tei:lb/>indented posteriorly. The species ixion, paluma, celeus and Certonotus species A would all run to<tei:lb/>Asperellus in Townes' (1969) key but these do not appear to be closely related to the others (i.e. the<tei:lb/>leeuwinensis-group). The first three are closely related to Certonotus talus and belong to the humeralifer-<tei:lb/>group, which is defined by having a very deeply divided tergite 7 and possessing rather long narrow<tei:lb/>processes on tergite 8. The group includes seven Australian species - humeralifer, apicalis, talus, cestus,<tei:lb/>ixion, paluma and Certonotus species A. The New Zealand species C. fractinervis apparently also belongs<tei:lb/>to this group.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The majority of other Australian species (annulatus, nitidulus, geniculatus, rufescens, andrewi, avitus,<tei:lb/>sisyphus and celeus) constitute a third group, having a weakly to moderately deeply divided tergite 7,<tei:lb/>rounded lobes on tergite 8 and a relatively long first sternite. Within the nitidulus-group one rather<tei:lb/>distinctive lineage can be recognized comprising rufescens, geniculatus, sisyphus and celeus. These species<tei:lb/>all have flat lower faces, and most have the posterior end of the lateral propodeal carina broadened to form<tei:lb/>a raised keel.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The remaining Australian species, C. monticola, belongs to the/Zav/ce/w-group which is characterized by<tei:lb/>possession of elongate glossae and a very short occipital carinal stub. Males of species in this group are<tei:lb/>specialized in having a very elongate gaster (with tergite 7 about 1-5 times as long as broad or longer).<tei:lb/>Frequently the hind margins of the tergites are concave. This elongate form of the gaster is characteristic of<tei:lb/>wood-boring species in which the male copulates with the female prior to her emergence from the burrow<tei:lb/>(see Nuttall, 1973) . The male of C. fractinervis resembles males of theflaviceps-group though the structure<tei:lb/>of the female suggests the species is best placed in the humeralifer-group.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The relationships of the species-groups are difficult to determine as there is considerable conflict in the<tei:lb/>characters. The leeuwinensis-group, a holophyletic clade, may well be the sister-lineage of the humeralifer-<tei:lb/>group. Both have a similarly deeply divided tergite 7 and many often possess spine-like bristles on the hind<tei:lb/>tibia and show reduction in the distal abcissa of Cu\. This arrangement leads to difficulty in placing C.<tei:lb/>farrugiai which has tergite 7 barely divided. The humeralifer-group could be paraphyletic with respect to<tei:lb/>the leeuwinensis-group. The nitidulus-group could well be a paraphyletic assemblage, the stem group from<tei:lb/>which all others have arisen, although the rufescens-subgroup is clearly a holophyletic clade. The<tei:lb/>flaviceps-group is also undoubtedly a holophyletic clade.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The geographical distribution of the species- groups is as follows:</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>AUSTRALIAN LABENINI &amp; POECILOCRYPTINI 119</tei:p>
         <tei:p>nitidulus-group: New Guinea, Australia;<tei:lb/>rufescens-subgroup: Australia;<tei:lb/>humeralifer-group: Australia, New Zealand;<tei:lb/>flaviceps-group: Moluccas, New Guinea, tropical Australia;<tei:lb/>leeuwinensis-group: New Guinea, Australia, New Hebrides, New Caldeonia.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Certonotus andrewisp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 29)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female. Medium to large-sized species, fore wing length 7-14 mm. Labium with glossae unspecialized.<tei:lb/>Lower face at narrowest point 1-0-1-1 times as broad as high; malar space 0-7-0-8 times as long as basal<tei:lb/>mandibular width. Occipital carina ventrally more than twice as long as abscissa of hypostomal carina<tei:lb/>between it and base of mandible. Upper part of pronotum, slightly before posterior corner, almost flat, in<tei:lb/>dorsal view barely projecting beyond scutal margin; subalar prominence moderately convex. Scutellum<tei:lb/>transversely striate, crest strong; metapleuron smooth and polished; submetapleural carina anteriorly<tei:lb/>expanded into a moderately broad, rather long lobe; metanotum with very strong tooth opposite anterior<tei:lb/>end of lateral carina. Propodeum moderately short with anterior transverse carina incomplete centrally;<tei:lb/>posterior transverse carina absent centrally; lateromedian longitudinal carina present only before anterior<tei:lb/>carina; pleural carina complete, but weak posteriorly; area superomedia undefined; area spiracularis<tei:lb/>confluent with first lateral area; first and second lateral area separated by a carina. Fore wing with 3r-m<tei:lb/>converging towards 2r-m, joining Rs separately; 2m-cu joining M 0-25 to 0-50 from 3r-m towards 2r-m.<tei:lb/>Hind wing with distal abscissa of Cu^ distinct to wing margin. Hind tibia with posterior margin without<tei:lb/>spine-like bristles. Gaster with segment 1 short, the sternite 0-5-0-6 times as long as hind coxa, reaching to<tei:lb/>level of spiracle. Tergite 7 mediodorsally without any indentation; tergite 8 posteriorly with process short<tei:lb/>and rounded; tergite 9 in dorsal view transverse. Ovipositor projecting beyond apex of gaster by 3-5 to 4-0<tei:lb/>times length of hind tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coloration. Orange-yellow species with frons centrally, vertex, mesoscutal stripes, most of gaster and<tei:lb/>hind legs more brownish or orange; flagellum black with subapical white band. Pterostigma brown, wings<tei:lb/>hyaline.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male. Similar to female.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>i</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Very like C. annulatus which it resembles in colour, venation, possession of short malar space<tei:lb/>and an almost flat pronotum. C. andrewi appears to be a more southern species than annulatus as it has<tei:lb/>been collected in southern Queensland, New South Wales and Victoria.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype $, New South Wales: Heathcote, near Sydney, x.1979 (Holloway) (AM).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. Queensland: 1 &lt;j&gt;, Brisbane, xii.1972 (SedlaceK) (TC); 4 &lt;j&gt;, Mt Glorious, near Brisbane,<tei:lb/>xii.1976 (Boucek) (BMNH); 1 $, 6 cf , Mt Glorious, xi (TC). New South Wales: 1 $, Cabbage Tree Ck,<tei:lb/>Clyde Mtn, ix.1979 (Naumann &amp; Cardale) (ANIC); 1 $, Iluka, Clarence R., rain forest, xi.1970<tei:lb/>(McAlpine) (AM); 1 $, Warren, ix.1982 (Holloway) (AM). Victoria: 1 $, 'Victoria' (NMV).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Certonotus annulatus Morley<tei:lb/>(Figs 28, 31)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Certonotus annulatus Morley, 1913: 31; Turner, 1919: 551. LECTOTYPE $ , QUEENSLAND (BMNH), here<tei:lb/>designated [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female. Moderately large species, fore wing length 9-13 mm. Labium with glossae very slightly leng-<tei:lb/>thened. Lower face at narrowest point 0-9 times as broad as high; malar space 0-7-0-8 times as long as basal<tei:lb/>mandibular width. Occipital carina ventrally about as long as abscissa of hypostomal carina between it and</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>122 I. D. GAULD &amp; G. A. HOLLOWAY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>mandibular base. Upper part of pronotum, slightly before posterior corner, very weakly convex, in dorsal<tei:lb/>view projecting only slightly beyond scutal margin; subalar prominence weakly convex. Scutellum<tei:lb/>punctate, transverse crest distinct; metapleuron virtually smooth except for a few striae ventrally and<tei:lb/>posteriorly; submetapleural carina anteriorly expanded into a broad rounded lobe that usually bears<tei:lb/>concentric striae; metanotum with a blunt tooth opposite anterior end of lateral carina. Propodeum<tei:lb/>moderately long with anterior transverse carina centrally absent; posterior transverse carina centrally<tei:lb/>present; lateromedian longitudinal carina complete only anteriorly and with stub behind anterior trans-<tei:lb/>verse carina; pleural carina complete; area superomedia indicated, but incomplete anteriorly and laterally;<tei:lb/>area spiracularis complete; first and second lateral areae separated, distinctly delineated. Fore wing with<tei:lb/>3r-m converging towards 2r-m, joining Rs separately; 2m-cu joining M 0-2-0-3 from 3r-m towards 2r-m.<tei:lb/>Hind wing with distal abscissa of Cu\ distinct to wing margin. Hind tibia with posterior margin without<tei:lb/>spine-like bristles. Gaster with segment 1 short, the sternite 0-5-0-6 times as long as hind coxa, reaching<tei:lb/>behind level of spiracle. Ovipositor projecting beyond apex of gaster by 4-5 times length of hind tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coloration. Orange species with face and orbits, notauli, subalar prominences, scutellar margins and<tei:lb/>hind margins of gastral tergites more yellowish; flagellum black with distal 10 or so segments white.<tei:lb/>Pterostigma blackish, wings very weakly infumate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male. Similar to female but with fore wing length 8 mm; malar space 0-4 times basal mandibular width;<tei:lb/>3r-m present; gaster with segment 1 moderately slender, the sternite 0-5 times as long as hind coxa. Apex of<tei:lb/>gonosquama flattened, bearing a tuft of long hairs. Coloration as for female.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. C. annulatus is rather similar to and probably the sister species of C. andrewi. The two species<tei:lb/>are fairly easily separated by the characters given in the key.<tei:lb/>C. annulatus seems to be a north Queensland species.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Certonotus apicalis Morley<tei:lb/>(Fig. 23)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Certonotus apicalis Morley, 1913: 31; Turner, 1919: 551. LECTOTYPE $, QUEENSLAND (BMNH), here<tei:lb/>designated [examined]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female. Large species, fore wing length 12-15 mm. Labium with glossae slightly lengthened. Lower face at<tei:lb/>narrowest point 1-0-1-1 times as broad as high; malar space 0-7-0-8 times as long as basal mandibular<tei:lb/>width. Occipital carina ventrally sinuous, more than twice as long as abscissa of hypostomal carina between<tei:lb/>it and base of mandibles. Upper part of pronotum, slightly before posterior corner, convex, in dorsal view<tei:lb/>projecting as a rounded protuberance; subalar prominence quite strongly convex. Scutellum punctate,<tei:lb/>transverse crest weak; metapleuron with fine sparse punctures; submetapleural carina anteriorly expanded<tei:lb/>into a broad rounded lobe; metanotum with a weak swelling in front of lateral carina. Propodeum<tei:lb/>moderately short with anterior transverse carina complete; posterior transverse carina present centrally;<tei:lb/>lateromedian longitudinal carina present before anterior carina only; pleural carina strong anteriorly,<tei:lb/>weak posteriorly; area superomedia not defined laterally; area spiracularis complete; first and second<tei:lb/>lateral areae more or less completely separated, the latter usually undefined externally. Fore wing with<tei:lb/>3r-m fused anteriorly with 2r-ra, so areolet is petiolate; 2m-cu joining M 0-20-0-25 basad of 3r-m. Hind<tei:lb/>wing with distal abscissa of Cu\ distinct to wing margin. Hind tibia with posterior margin without spine-like<tei:lb/>bristles. Gaster with segment 1 short, the sternite 0-5 times as long as hind coxa, not reaching level of<tei:lb/>spiracle. Tergite 7 mediodorsally divided about 0-5 times its length; tergite 8 posteriorly with long narrow<tei:lb/>process; tergite 9 in dorsal view transverse, rounded apically. Ovipositor projecting beyond apex of gaster<tei:lb/>by 7-5 or more times length of hind tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coloration. Yellowish brown species, antenna black with distal segments white, the apical one or two<tei:lb/>segments slightly infuscate. Pterostigma black, wings weakly infumate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male. Similar to female but with fore wing length 9 mm; malar space 0-5 times basal mandibular width;</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>AUSTRALIAN LABENINI &amp; POECILOCRYPTINI 123</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3r-m fused anteriorly with 2r-m; gaster with segment 1 short, the sternite 0-7 times as long as hind coxa,<tei:lb/>apex of gonosquama flattened, with a tuft of long close hairs. Colour similar to female but pterostigma dark<tei:lb/>brown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The females of this species are easily distinguished by their very long ovipositors, the apices of<tei:lb/>which are fairly bluntly pointed. The fore femur is also rather distinctive, being slender proximally, then<tei:lb/>abruptly inflated proximocentrally. This is most similar to C. humeralifer and the two are probably<tei:lb/>sister-taxa.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>C. apicalis is a tropical species, only recorded from Queensland.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Certonotus avitus sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 41, 42)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female. Medium-sized species, fore wing length 8-10 mm. Labium with glossae unspecialized. Lower face<tei:lb/>at narrowest point 1-0 times as broad as high; malar space 0-4-0-6 times as long as basal mandibular width.<tei:lb/>Occipital carina ventrally sinuous, more than 3 times as long as abscissa of hypostomal carina between it<tei:lb/>and base of mandible. Upper part of pronotum, slightly before posterior corner, almost flat, in dorsal view<tei:lb/>barely projecting beyond scutal margin; subalar prominence weakly convex. Scutellum finely punctate,<tei:lb/>crest strong; metapleuron finely punctate, obsolescent striae posteriorly; submetapleural carina anteriorly<tei:lb/>expanded into a rectangular elongate flange; metanotum laterally produced into a stout tooth in front of<tei:lb/>lateral carina. Propodeum moderately long with anterior transverse carina incomplete centrally; posterior<tei:lb/>transverse carina absent except laterally; lateromedian longitudinal carina present only before anterior<tei:lb/>carina; pleural carina incomplete posteriorly; area superomedia indistinct; area spiracularis complete; first<tei:lb/>and second lateral areae separated, the second not defined laterally. Fore wing with 3r-m converging<tei:lb/>towards 2r-m, widely separated on Rs; 2m-cu joining M 0-3 from 3r-m towards 2r-m. Hind wing with distal<tei:lb/>abscissa of Cui distinct to wing margin. Hind tibia with posterior margin without spine-like bristles. Gaster<tei:lb/>with segment 1 long, the sternite 1-2 times as long as hind coxa, reaching well behind level of spiracle.<tei:lb/>Tergite 7 mediodorsally with indentation to 0-25 of tergite length; tergite 8 posteriorly with short, rounded<tei:lb/>process; tergite 9 in dorsal view transverse. Ovipositor projecting beyond apex of gaster by 5 times length<tei:lb/>of hind tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coloration. Flagellum black, distal apex white; head brown, orbits entirely and all of lower face whitish;<tei:lb/>alitrunk dark brown, notaular stripes, subalar prominence, tegula, scutellum, postscutellum, mesopleural<tei:lb/>stripe and posterior part of propodeum/metapleuron yellow. Gaster reddish brown, tergites laterally<tei:lb/>yellow and with posterolateral yellow spots. Tergite 1 anteriorly yellowish. Anterior two pairs of coxae<tei:lb/>whitish, hind ones brown with white apices; all tibiae and tarsi infuscate; femora brown, distally pale.<tei:lb/>Pterostigma dark brown; wings hyaline.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male. Similar to female but with fore wing length 8 mm; malar space 0-3-0-4 basal mandibular width;<tei:lb/>3r-m present; gaster with segment 1 slender, the sternite 1-0 times as long as hind coxa. Gonosquama with<tei:lb/>apex slightly flattened, with a tuft of close moderately long hairs. Similar in colour to female.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. C. avitus is a distinctive species with a very characteristic submetapleural carina. For its size this<tei:lb/>species has a rather large areolet and a fairly long first sternite.<tei:lb/>It is known from eastern Australia, from southern Queensland to Victoria.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype $ , New South Wales: Mt Tomah, Blue Mtns, viii.1979 (Rodd) (AM).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. Queensland: 1 $ , Eungella, xi (TC); 1 $ , Mt Glorious, i (TC); 1 cf , Mt Nebo, viii (TC); 1 $ ,<tei:lb/>Mt Tamborine, ix-x.1978 (Galloway) (BMNH).          <tei:p>124 I. D. GAULD &amp; G. A. HOLLO WAY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Occipital carina ventrally longer than abscissa of hypostomal carina between it and lobe of mandible.<tei:lb/>Upper part of pronotum, slightly before posterior cornet, weakly convex, in dorsal view barely protruding<tei:lb/>beyond scutal margin; subalar prominence quite strongly convex. Scutellum coarsely punctate, crest<tei:lb/>strong; metapleuron small and polished; submetapleural carina anteriorly expanded into a rounded lobe,<tei:lb/>metanotum barely produced before lateral carina. Propodeum moderately long with anterior transverse<tei:lb/>carina obsolescent centrally; posterior transverse carina weak but more or less complete; lateromedian<tei:lb/>longitudinal carina present anteriorly and weakly between transverse carina; pleural carina anteriorly<tei:lb/>strong, posteriorly weaker or absent; area superomedia more or less distinct, not defined anteriorly; area<tei:lb/>spiracularis complete; first and second lateral areae separated, the first very short, the second ill-defined<tei:lb/>externally. Fore wing with 3r-m converging towards 2r-ra, joining Rs separately; 2m-cu joining M opposite<tei:lb/>3r-m. Hind wing with distal abscissa of Cu\ distinct to wing margin. Hind tibia with posterior margin with<tei:lb/>two spine-like bristles. Gaster with segment 1 short and broad posteriorly, the sternite 0-5 times as long as<tei:lb/>hind coxa, reaching almost to level of spiracle. Tergite 7 mediodorsally with broad indentation; tergite 8<tei:lb/>posteriorly short and rounded; tergite 9 in dorsal view very broad. Ovipositor projecting beyond apex of<tei:lb/>gaster by 6 times length of hind tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coloration. Very dark brown species, flagellum with a white subapical band; facial, frontal and genal<tei:lb/>orbits, upper and lower margin of pronotum, mesoscutum in a central quadrate spot and indistinctly<tei:lb/>laterally, scutellum, postscutellum, subalar prominence, anterior and posterior mesopleural spots, most of<tei:lb/>hind part of propodeum and metapleuron whitish. Gaster dark brown with large anterolateral spots.<tei:lb/>Anterior coxa whitish, hind coxa brown with whitish mark. Pterostigma blackish, wings hyaline.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male. Similar to female but with fore wing length 9 mm; malar space 0-7 times basal mandibular width;<tei:lb/>3r-m present; gaster with segment 1 quite stout, the sternite 0-5 times as long as hind coxa. Apex of<tei:lb/>gonosquama with a small lobe that bears scattered long hairs. Colour similar to female but face entirely<tei:lb/>pale.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species is readily recognizable by its colour pattern. Structurally it seems to be related to the<tei:lb/>C. humeralifer-group as it has tergite 7 very deeply divided. Tergite 8 is less pronounced apically in this<tei:lb/>species than others in the humeralifer-group.<tei:lb/>It is known from Queensland and New South Wales.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST RECORD. Buprestidae: Diadoxussp. (ANIC).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Certonotus geniculatus Morley<tei:lb/>(Fig. 32)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Certonotus geniculatus Morley, 1913: 28. LECTOTYPE $, VICTORIA (BMNH), here designated [ex-<tei:lb/>amined] .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female. Large species, fore wing length 12-17 mm. Labium with glossae slightly lengthened. Lower face at<tei:lb/>narrowest point 1-1-1-2 times as broad as high; malar space 0-9-1-0 times as long as basal mandibular<tei:lb/>width. Occipital carina ventrally about as long as abscissa of hypostomal carina between it and base of<tei:lb/>mandible. Upper part of pronotum, slightly before posterior corner, very weakly convex, in dorsal view<tei:lb/>barely projecting beyond scutal margin; subalar prominence weakly convex. Scutellum punctate with<tei:lb/>strong transverse crest; metapleuron longitudinally striate; submetapleural carina anteriorly expanded<tei:lb/>into a moderately broad lobe; metanotum produced into a tooth opposite anterior end of lateral carina.<tei:lb/>Propodeum quite short with anterior transverse carina incomplete centrally; posterior transverse carina<tei:lb/>vestigial; lateromedian longitudinal carina present only as vestige anteriorly; pleural carina strongly raised<tei:lb/>into tubercle below spiracle, posteriorly obsolescent; area superomedia undefined; area spiracularis not<tei:lb/>completely delineated posteriorly; first and second lateral areae separated, but not clearly delineated<tei:lb/>internally or laterally. Fore wing with 3r-m and 2r-m converging but not joining anteriorly. Hind wing with<tei:lb/>distal abscissa of Cu\ distinct to hind margin. Hind tibia with posterior margin without spine-like bristles.<tei:lb/>Gaster with segment 1 long and narrow, the sternite 1-0-1-3 times as long as hind coxa, reaching behind<tei:lb/>level of spiracle. Tergite 7 mediodorsally with very small indentation on posterior margin; tergite 8<tei:lb/>posteriorly short and rounded. Tergite 9 in dorsal view broad. Ovipositor projecting beyond apex of gaster<tei:lb/>by 5-5 to 7-0 times length of hind tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coloration. Antenna black; head black, lower face, frontal and genal orbits yellow. Alitrunk red-brown<tei:lb/>with periphery of sclerites infuscate, only tegula, scutellum posteriorly, postscutellum and hind end of</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>AUSTRALIAN LABENINI &amp; POECILOCRYPTINI 125</tei:p>
         <tei:p>propodeum yellow. Gaster reddish brown, tergite 1 anteriorly, laterally and posteriorly yellow, other<tei:lb/>tergites with lateral and posterior margins yellow. Fore leg yellow, proximal part of femur black; mid leg<tei:lb/>yellow, coxa basally, femur proximally and tarsus black. Hind leg black, coxa distally, trochanter<tei:lb/>segments, distal apex of femur, base and apex of tibia yellow. Pterostigma dark brown, wings virtually<tei:lb/>hyaline.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male. Similar to female but with fore wing length 11 mm; malar space 0-7-0-9 times basal mandibular<tei:lb/>width; 3r-m present; gaster with segment 1 very slender, the sternite 1-3 times as long as hind coxa. Apex of<tei:lb/>gonosquama flattened with a dense tuft of long hairs. Colour similar to female.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. C. geniculatus belongs to the rufescens-subgroup of the tasmaniensis-group. It is probably the<tei:lb/>sister-species of C. rufescens. Both have the prementum and glossae somewhat lengthened, have a very flat<tei:lb/>face, the anterior portion of the lateral carina strongly raised and the pleural carina raised into a tubercle<tei:lb/>below the propodeal spiracle. C. geniculatus is most easily distinguished by the possession of a longitudin-<tei:lb/>ally striate metapleuron.<tei:lb/>This is a southern species, only recorded from Victoria.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Certonotus celeussp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 44)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female. Medium-sized species, fore wing length 8-9 mm. Labium with glossae slightly lengthened. Lower<tei:lb/>face at narrowest point 0-9 times as broad as high; malar space 1-3-1-4 times as long as basal mandibular<tei:lb/>width. Occipital carina ventrally slightly longer than abscissa of hypostomal carina between it and base of<tei:lb/>mandible. Upper part of pronotum, slightly before posterior corner, very weakly convex, in dorsal view<tei:lb/>projecting slightly beyond mesoscutal margin; subalar prominence moderately convex. Scutellum sparsely<tei:lb/>punctate with strong crest posteriorly; metapleuron smooth, very sparsely punctate; submetapleural carina<tei:lb/>anteriorly strongly expanded into a quadrate lobe that is abruptly narrowed posteriorly; metanotum with a<tei:lb/>weak lateral tooth. Propodeum quite long with anterior transverse carina complete; posterior transverse<tei:lb/>carina complete; lateromedian longitudinal carina present only anterior to anterior carina; pleural carina<tei:lb/>complete; area superomedia not defined; area spiracularis clearly delineated; first and second lateral areae<tei:lb/>distinct, separated. Fore wing with 3r-m converging towards 2r-m, joining Rs separately; 2m-cu joining M<tei:lb/>0-3 from 3r-m towards 2r-m. Hind wing with distal abscissa of Cu\ absent. Hind tibia with posterior margin<tei:lb/>with one spine-like bristle. Gaster with segment 1 very long and narrow, the sternite 1-2-1-6 times as long<tei:lb/>as hind coxa, reaching well behind level of spiracle. Tergite 7 mediodorsally with shallow indentation;<tei:lb/>tergite 8 posteriorly short and rounded; tergite 9 in dorsal view short and pointed. Ovipositor projecting<tei:lb/>beyond apex of gaster by 4-5 times length of hind tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coloration. Red-brown species, flagellum black with subapical white band, lower face yellowish,<tei:lb/>anterior leg orange. Pterostigma dark brown; wings hyaline, apex of fore wing strongly infumate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Putative male. Similar to female but with fore wing length 8 mm; malar space 0-6 times basal mandibular<tei:lb/>width; 3r-m present; propodeal carinae weaker; gaster with segment 1 slender, the sternite 0-9 times as<tei:lb/>long as hind coxa. Apex of gonosquama rounded, with scattered fine hairs. Pale orange, antenna black,<tei:lb/>head yellowish and wings uniformly hyaline.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. A distinctive species on account of the infumate tip to the fore wing of the female, the very long<tei:lb/>petiole, long hind coxa and rather flat face. It is probably related to C. rufescens though it is the only species<tei:lb/>in this subgroup without the distal abscissa of Cu\. The male, here tentatively associated, has similarly long<tei:lb/>coxae and a rather flat face but has no clear posterior transverse propodeal carina nor has the wing apices<tei:lb/>infumate.<tei:lb/>It is only known from Queensland.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype $, Queensland: Baldy Mtn Rd, via Atherton, Malaise trap, vi.1981 (Brown) (QM).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. Queensland: 1 $, same data as holotype (BMNH); 1 cf, Eungella Nat. Park, xi.1976<tei:lb/>(Boucek) (BMNH); 1 $, Windsor Tableland, iii.1981 (Storey) (BMNH).</tei:p>

      </tei:div>

         <tei:p>126 I. D. GAULD &amp; G. A. HOLLO WAY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Certonotusfarrugiaisp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 58)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female. Medium-sized species, fore wing length 6-10 mm. Labium with glossae unspecialized. Lower face<tei:lb/>at narrowest point 1-1-1-2 times as broad as high; malar space 1-2-1-3 times as long as basal mandibular<tei:lb/>width. Occipital carina ventrally as long as abscissa of hypostomal carina between it and base of mandible.<tei:lb/>Upper part of pronotum, slightly before posterior corner, almost flat, in dorsal view barely projecting<tei:lb/>beyond mesoscutal margin; subalar prominence quite strongly convex and medially raised in dorsal aspect.<tei:lb/>Scutellum smooth, virtually impunctate with weak transverse carina apically; metapleuron anteriorly<tei:lb/>smooth, posteriorly with few coarse punctures; submetapleural carina anteriorly expanded into a broad<tei:lb/>rounded lobe; metanotum with a small lateral tooth before vestige of lateral carina. Propodeum<tei:lb/>moderately short with anterior transverse carina complete; posterior transverse carina absent; laterome-<tei:lb/>dian longitudinal carina absent; pleural carina present, posteriorly obsolescent; area superomedia<tei:lb/>undefined; area spiracularis defined except medially; first and second lateral areae confluent. Fore wing<tei:lb/>with 3r-m converging towards 2r-m, joining latter at Rs or sometimes slightly separated; 2m-cu joining M<tei:lb/>slightly basad of 3r-m. Hind wing with distal abscissa of Cu\ absent. Hind tibia with posterior margin with<tei:lb/>one spine-like bristle. Caster with segment 1 short and broad, the sternite 0-4-0-6 times as long as hind<tei:lb/>coxa, reaching to level of spiracle. Tergite 7 mediodorsally with wide indentation; tergite 8 posteriorly<tei:lb/>short and broadly rounded; tergite 9 in dorsal view short and broad. Ovipositor projecting beyond apex of<tei:lb/>gaster by 3-0-3-5 times length of hind tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coloration. Head and anterior part of alitrunk reddish brown; antenna, much of metapleuron and<tei:lb/>propodeum black; gaster black, tergite 2 entirely and posterior margins of tergites 3+ white; anteriorly<tei:lb/>red-brown, partially infuscate; hind leg mainly black. Pterostigma black, wings strongly infumate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male. Similar to female but with fore wing length 6 mm; malar space 0-8 times basal mandibular width;<tei:lb/>3r-m present; gaster with segment 1 stout, the sternite 0-6 times as long as hind coxa. Apex of gaster<tei:lb/>rounded, bearing long scattered hairs. Similar in colour to female but with gaster entirely red; mid leg<tei:lb/>brownish.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. C. farrugiai is probably the most distinct species in the genus on account of its striking colour<tei:lb/>pattern which resembles that of a number of other unrelated species of Hymenoptera occurring in<tei:lb/>south-eastern Australia. Structurally it is also distinctive in having the posterior margin of tergite 7 only<tei:lb/>weakly indented.<tei:lb/>This species occurs from south-eastern Queensland to Victoria.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype $, Victoria: Toolangi, xii.1982 (Farrugia) (AM).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. Queensland: 4 $ , Mt Glorious, xi-iii (TC); 1 $ , Mt Nebo, 500 m, iii (TC); 1 $ , Tambourine,<tei:lb/>x.1977 (Galloway) (BMNH); 1 tf , Mt Tambourine, iv. 1935 (Turner) (BMNH); 1 $ , 2 cT, Mt Tambourine,<tei:lb/>x-xii (TC). Victoria: 2 $, same data as holotype (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Certonotus hinnuleus Krieger comb. rev.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Certonotus hinnuleus Krieger, 1901: 123; Turner, 1919: 551. Holotype $, NEW SOUTH WALES (MNHU)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>[not examined] .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Certonotus n. sp.; Fullaway, 1942: 244.<tei:lb/>Asperellus hinnuleus (Krieger) Townes et al. , 1961: 114.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female. Fairly small species, fore wing length 4-7 mm. Labium with glossae unspecialized. Lower face at<tei:lb/>narrowest point 1-2 times as broad as high; malar space 1-2-1-4 times as long as basal mandibular width.<tei:lb/>Occipital carina ventrally almost twice as long as abscissa of hypostomal carina between it and mandible<tei:lb/>base. Upper part of pronotum, slightly before posterior corner, very convex, in dorsal view appearing as a<tei:lb/>conical projection; subalar prominence moderately convex. Scutellum sparsely punctate with strong<tei:lb/>transverse keel; metapleuron smooth and polished; submetapleural carina anteriorly expanded into a<tei:lb/>broad triangular lobe; metanotum without a tooth. Propodeum short with anterior transverse carina<tei:lb/>complete, close to anterior margin; posterior transverse carina absent; lateromedian longitudinal carina<tei:lb/>present before anterior transverse carina; pleural carina present anteriorly, posteriorly absent; area<tei:lb/>superomedia not delineated; area spiracularis not delineated internally; first and second lateral areae<tei:lb/>indistinctly delineated, confluent. Fore wing with 3r-m converging towards 2r-m, sometimes forming a<tei:lb/>petiolate areolet or joining at one point on Rs; 2m-cu joining M at 3r-m or slightly basad. Hind wing with<tei:lb/>distal abscissa of Cui absent. Hind tibia with posterior margin with one spine-like bristle. Gaster with<tei:lb/>segment 1 short and broad, the sternite 0-6 times as long as hind coxa, reaching to level of spiracle. Tergite 7</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>AUSTRALIAN LABENINI &amp; POECILOCRYPTINI 127</tei:p>
         <tei:p>mediodorsally with large indentation; tergite 8 posteriorly short, broad, truncate; tergite 9 in dorsal view<tei:lb/>short, rounded posteriorly. Ovipositor projecting beyond apex of gaster by 5-0-5-5 times length of hind<tei:lb/>tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coloration. Antenna black, distal flagellar segments white; head white, vertex, interocellar area and<tei:lb/>frons centrally whitish; mesoscutum brownish or blackish with a yellow central quadrate mark; most of<tei:lb/>pronotum, tegula, subalar prominence, metapleuron and propodeum almost entirely yellowish; meta-<tei:lb/>pleuron brownish. Gaster dark brown with lateral margins and spots near posterolateral corners yellow;<tei:lb/>legs brownish; tibia proximally and femur distally somewhat paler; fore coxa whitish. Pterostigma<tei:lb/>blackish, wings very weakly infumate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male. Similar to female but with fore wing length 3-6 mm; malar space 0-9-1-0 times basal mandibular<tei:lb/>width; 3r-m present; gaster with segment 1 quite stout, the sternite 0-5 times as long as hind coxa; apex of<tei:lb/>gonosquama quite weakly sclerotized, slightly flattened, bearing long fine hairs. Colour similar to female<tei:lb/>but mid coxa yellow.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Certonotus hinnuleus belongs to the leeuwinensis-group. It is the most distinctive taxon in the<tei:lb/>group on account of the swollen pronotal corner. Structurally it is most closely related to C. zebrus from<tei:lb/>which it differs in having a longer ovipositor and shorter stouter petiole. In Australia it has only been<tei:lb/>recorded from New South Wales and Victoria. The female from Western Australia referred to by Morley<tei:lb/>(1913) is a distinct species, C. ixion. Townes et al. (1961) note that this species occurs in New Caledonia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>New Caledonia: 2 $ , 7 km SE. La Foa, i. 1945 (Remington) (TC) (compared with type); 1 d", hills behind<tei:lb/>Noumea, x.1940 (Williams) (TC). Queensland: 1 C?, N. slope, Bluff Range, Biggenden, viii.1976 (Frauca)<tei:lb/>(ANIC); 1 C?, Broken R., near Eungella, xii.1961 (McAlpine &amp; Lossiri) (AM); 1 $, 1 cf, Kuranda,<tei:lb/>v-vi.1913 (Turner) (BMNH); 1 C?, Mackay, 1909 (Turner) (BMNH); 3 C?, Mt Cootha, iv-v (TC); 1 C?, Mt<tei:lb/>Glorious, i (TC); 2 d" , Mt Tambourine, xi.1977 (Galloway) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Certonotus humeralifer Krieger<tei:lb/>(Figs 24, 26, 27, 30)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Certonotus humeralifer Krieger, 1901: 121. Lectotype $, NEW SOUTH WALES (MNHU), designated by<tei:lb/>Townes et al., 1961: 113 [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female. Medium to large species, fore wing length 7-14 mm. Labium with glossae unspecialized. Lower<tei:lb/>face at narrowest point 1-2-1-3 times as broad as high; malar space 0-7-0-8 times as long as basal<tei:lb/>mandibular width. Occipital carina ventrally sinuous, at least twice as long as abscissa of hypostomal carina<tei:lb/>between it and base of mandible. Upper part of pronotum, slightly before posterior corner, very strongly<tei:lb/>swollen, in dorsal view pyramidal, projecting; subalar prominence strongly convex. Scutellum punctate,<tei:lb/>crest distinct, metapleuron smooth and polished; submetapleural carina anteriorly expanded into a tooth<tei:lb/>before lateral carina. Propodeum moderately short with anterior transverse carina weak centrally but<tei:lb/>usually complete; posterior transverse carina absent; lateromedian longitudinal carina present anteriorly;<tei:lb/>pleural carina strong anteriorly, posteriorly vestigial; area superomedia not delineated; area spiracularis<tei:lb/>not clearly delineated posteriorly; first and second lateral area confluent, weakly defined laterally. Fore<tei:lb/>wing with 3r-m fused anteriorly with 2r-m, so areolet petiolate; 2m-cu joining M-basad by 0-2 from 3r-m.<tei:lb/>Hind wing with distal abscissa of Cui distinct to wing margin. Hind tibia with posterior margin with one<tei:lb/>spine-like bristle. Gaster with segment 1 short, the sternite 0-5 times as long as hind coxa, reaching to level<tei:lb/>of spiracle. Tergite 7 mediodorsally with wide indentation narrowing to slit to 0-5 of tergite length; tergite 9<tei:lb/>in dorsal view short, rectangular. Ovipositor projecting beyond apex of gaster by 5 times length of hind<tei:lb/>tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coloration. Bright yellow species; flagellum, interocellar area, mesoscutum in central spot and<tei:lb/>scutoscutellar groove black; hind tarsus infuscate. Pterostigma black, wings hyaline.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male. Similar to female but with fore wing length 7-8 mm; malar space 0-6 times basal mandibular width;<tei:lb/>3r-m present; gaster with segment 1 quite stout, the sternite 0-5 times as long as hind coxa; apex of<tei:lb/>gonosquama strongly flattened, with periphery bearing only fine sparse hairs. Similar in colour to female.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The bright yellow ground colour of this species and the conical pronotal process distinguish C.<tei:lb/>humeralifer from other Australian Certonotus species. C. humeralifer belongs to the humeralifer-group; it<tei:lb/>appears to be most closely related to C. apicalis. Both have a characteristically specialized fore femur.<tei:lb/>C. humeralifer has been collected in Queensland and New South Wales.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>128 I. D. GAULD &amp; G. A. HOLLO WAY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Certonotus ixion sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 55, 61)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female. Medium-sized species, fore wing length 8 mm. Labium with glossae unspecialized. Lower face at<tei:lb/>narrowest point 1-2 times as broad as high; malar space 0-9 times as long as basal mandibular width.<tei:lb/>Occipital carina ventrally slightly longer than abscissa of hypostomal carina between it and base of<tei:lb/>mandible. Upper part of pronotum, slightly before posterior corner, weakly convex, in dorsal view parallel<tei:lb/>with mesoscutal margin; subalar prominence moderately convex. Scutellum closely, finely punctate with<tei:lb/>strong transverse crest; metapleuron with close shallow punctures; submetapleural carina anteriorly<tei:lb/>abruptly expanded into a broad lobe. Propodeum moderately short with anterior transverse carina<tei:lb/>complete; posterior transverse carina almost complete; lateromedian longitudinal carina absent except for<tei:lb/>vestiges before anterior carina; pleural carina obsolescent posteriorly; area superomedia not delimited<tei:lb/>laterally; area spiracularis almost complete; first and second lateral areae barely delineated laterally,<tei:lb/>confluent. Fore wing with 3r-m strongly converging towards 2r-m, joining Rs separately; 2m-cu joining M<tei:lb/>at 3r-m. Hind wing with distal abscissa of Cu\ present over distal 0-5 to wing margin, not joined to first<tei:lb/>abscissa of Cu\. Hind tibia with posterior margin with a small spine-like bristle. Gaster with segment 1 long<tei:lb/>and narrow, the sternite 0-8 times as long as hind coxa, reaching behind level of spiracle. Tergite 7<tei:lb/>mediodorsally with narrow indentation to 0-5 of length; tergite 8 posteriorly short and truncate; tergite 9 in<tei:lb/>dorsal view broad. Ovipositor projecting beyond apex of gaster by 5-5 times length of hind tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coloration. Antenna blackish, apex (except extreme distal part of last segment) whitish; head reddish<tei:lb/>brown, lower face, frontal orbits and most of genae whitish; alitrunk reddish, peripherally darker;<tei:lb/>scutellum posteriorly, postscutellum, tegula, subalar prominence and upper margin of pronotum yellow-<tei:lb/>ish. Gaster dark red-brown; tergites 1-6 with posterolateral triangular yellow marks, tergites 2-3 with<tei:lb/>anterolateral pale spots. Legs predominantly reddish brown, anterior two pairs of coxae and distal apices<tei:lb/>of fore and mid femora whitish. Pterostigma red-brown, wings hyaline.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male. Quite similar to female but with fore wing length 5-7 mm; malar space 0-6 times basal mandibular<tei:lb/>width; 3r-m present; gaster with segment 1 slender, the sternite 1-0 times as long as hind coxa; apex of<tei:lb/>gaster with a small lobe bearing long scattered hairs. Colour similar to female but with mesopleuron<tei:lb/>white-marked and pale maculae on gaster smaller, rather inconspicuous, flagellum entirely black.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The species is one of the three Certonotus that have incomplete distal abscissa of Cu\, It is most<tei:lb/>similar to C. paluma from which it differs strikingly in colour pattern, length of ovipositor and shape of<tei:lb/>tergite 8. The coxae are more elongate than in many other species and the sculpture of the alitrunk is<tei:lb/>coarser than that of C. paluma.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>C. ixion has been collected in Queensland and Victoria.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype , Victoria: Ferntree Gully, x.1921 (Burns) (NMV).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. Queensland: 1 cf , Lamington N.P. , xi.1961 (Common &amp; Upton) (ANIC); 1 cf , Mt Glorious,<tei:lb/>xii (TC); 2 cf , Mt Nebo, 500 m, iii (TC).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Certonotus leeuwinensis Turner comb. rev.<tei:lb/>(Figs 49, 52)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Certonotus leeuwinensis Turner, 1919: 551. Holotype cf , WESTERN AUSTRALIA (BMNH) [examined].<tei:lb/>Asperellus leeuwinensis (Turner) Townes et al. , 1961: 115.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female. Medium-sized species, fore wing length 6-7 mm. Labium with glossae unspecialized. Lower face<tei:lb/>at narrowest point 1-2-1-3 times as broad as high; malar space 1-1-1-2 times as long as basal mandibular<tei:lb/>width. Occipital carina ventrally weak, only slightly longer than abscissa of hypostomal carina between it<tei:lb/>and mandibular base. Upper part of pronotum, slightly before posterior corner, weakly convex, in dorsal<tei:lb/>view slightly protruding from mesoscutal margin; subalar prominence weakly convex. Scutellum sparsely</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>AUSTRALIAN LABENINI &amp; POECILOCRYPTINI 129</tei:p>
         <tei:p>punctate, with strong transverse keel; metapleuron closely, quite finely punctate; submetapleural carina<tei:lb/>anteriorly expanded into a moderately broad, triangular lobe; metanotum with weak lateral tooth.<tei:lb/>Propodeum quite short with anterior transverse carina complete; posterior transverse carina absent;<tei:lb/>lateromedian longitudinal carina present before anterior transverse carina; pleural carina more or less<tei:lb/>complete; area superomedia undefined; area spiracularis incomplete internally; first and second lateral<tei:lb/>areae confluent. Fore wing with 3r-m convergent towards 2r-m in some specimens; 2m-cu joining M just<tei:lb/>basad of 2r-m. Hind wing with distal abscissa of Cui absent. Hind tibia with posterior margin with one<tei:lb/>spine-like bristle. Caster with segment 1 short, the sternite 0-5 times as long as hind coxa, reaching nearly<tei:lb/>to level of spiracle. Tergite 7 mediodorsally with indentation to 0-5 its length; tergite 8 posteriorly short and<tei:lb/>rounded; tergite 9 in dorsal view short and broad. Ovipositor projecting beyond apex of gaster by 5-5 times<tei:lb/>length of hind tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coloration. Antenna black with apical segments white (except for distal apex of last segment which is<tei:lb/>black); head black, orbits entirely whitish, lower face centrally brownish; alitrunk reddish brown, the<tei:lb/>sclerites often margined with black irregularly; pronotum dorsally as a stripe, ventrally, tegula, subalar<tei:lb/>prominence, scutellum and postscutellum pale whitish yellow; gaster brownish or even blackish, tergites<tei:lb/>1-7 laterally and posteriorly margined with yellow. Legs with fore and mid coxae yellow above, black<tei:lb/>below; hind coxa brown above, blackish below; anterior two pairs of legs otherwise brownish except for<tei:lb/>distal apices of femora which are yellow; hind femur brownish; hind tibia darker brown, proximally<tei:lb/>indistinctly paler, tarsus infuscate. Pterostigma dark brown, wings hyaline.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male. Similar to female but with fore wing length 3-6 mm; malar space 0-9 times basal mandibular width;<tei:lb/>3r-m present; gaster with segment 1 moderately stout, the sternite 0-6 times as long as hind coxa; apex of<tei:lb/>gonosquama flattened slightly and bearing long scattered hairs. Colour similar to female but lower face and<tei:lb/>anterior two pairs of coxae almost entirely yellow.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Certonotus leeuwinensis belongs to the leeuwinensis-group. It is structurally most similar to C.<tei:lb/>toolangi in having a noticeably punctate metapleuron. The most obvious difference between the two<tei:lb/>species is in coloration. The gaster of leeuwinensis has the hind margins of tergites 2-5 banded with yellow<tei:lb/>whereas those of toolangi are spotted with yellow. The hind tibia of toolangi is bicoloured, that of<tei:lb/>leeuwinensis is almost unicolorous. C. leeuwinensis has a slightly longer ovipositor and malar space than<tei:lb/>toolangi.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , Western Australia: Yallingup near Cape Naturaliste ix-x.1913 (Turner) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>New South Wales: 1 $, Killara, xii.1935 (Day) (ANIC). Tasmania: 1 $, Coles Bay, ii-iii (TC); 1 cf,<tei:lb/>Georgetown, xi.1917 (Cole) (NMV); 1 $, Mt Barrow, 1200 m, xiii-i (TC). Western Australia: 1 $<tei:lb/>(paratype), same data as holotype (BMNH); 1 cf , 21 km SW. by S. Donnybrook (23-44S 115-41E), x.1981<tei:lb/>(Naumann &amp; Cardale) (ANIC); 1 cf , Mt Chudalup, S. of Northcliffe, x.1970 (Colless) (ANIC); 1 cf ,<tei:lb/>Yallingup, near Cape Naturaliste, ix-x.1913 (Turner) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Certonotus mogimbensis Cheesman comb. rev.<tei:lb/>(Fig. 47)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Certonotus mogimbensis Cheesman, 1936: 180. Holotype $, NEW HEBRIDES (BMNH) [examined].<tei:lb/>Asperellus mogimbensis (Cheesman) Townesefa/., 1961: 115.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female. Small species, fore wing length 5 mm. Labium with glossae slightly elongate. Lower face at<tei:lb/>narrowest point 1-0 times as broad as high; malar space 0-8-1-0 times as long as basal mandibular width.<tei:lb/>Occipital carina ventrally from slightly shorter to slightly longer than abscissa of hypostomal carina<tei:lb/>between it and base of mandible. Upper part of pronotum, slightly before posterior corner, weakly convex,<tei:lb/>in dorsal view parallel to mesoscutal margin; subalar prominence very weakly convex. Scutellum punctate<tei:lb/>with strong transverse keel; metapleuron smooth with some fine punctures posteriorly; submetapleural<tei:lb/>carina anteriorly expanded into a rounded lobe; metanotum without a lateral tooth. Propodeum short with<tei:lb/>anterior transverse carina complete; posterior transverse carina absent; lateromedian longitudinal carina<tei:lb/>vestigial; pleural carina complete; area superomedia undefined; area spiracularis not defined internally;<tei:lb/>first and second lateral areae confluent. Fore wing with 3r-m present for half the distance or less from Rs<tei:lb/>towards M; 2m-cu joining M well distad of 2r-m. Hind wing with distal abscissa of Cui absent. Hind tibia<tei:lb/>with posterior margin with one or two spine-like bristles. Gaster with segment 1 short and broad, the<tei:lb/>sternite 0-5 times as long as hind coxa, reaching to level of spiracle. Tergite 7 mediodorsally with<tei:lb/>indentation to 0-5 of length; tergite 8 posteriorly long and rounded; tergite 9 in dorsal view elongate.<tei:lb/>Ovipositor projecting beyond apex of gaster by 4-0-4-5 times length of hind tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>130 I. D. GAULD &amp; G. A. HOLLOWAY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coloration. Antenna black with a subapical broad white band; head whitish; clypeus and mouth parts<tei:lb/>brownish, frons centrally and interocellar area dark brown. Alitrunk, legs and gaster uniformly orange.<tei:lb/>Pterostigma dark brown, wings hyaline.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male. Similar to female but with fore wing length 3-4 mm; malar space 0-9-1-1 times basal mandibular<tei:lb/>width; 3r-m absent; gaster with segment 1 moderately slender; the sternite 0-6 times as long as hind coxa;<tei:lb/>apex of gonosquama with small lobe bearing fine scattered hairs. Similarly coloured to female but with<tei:lb/>head uniformly orange, flagellum entirely black, hind tibia and tarsus weakly to strongly infuscate, some<tei:lb/>tergites of gaster infuscate and wings slightly infumate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. C. mogimbensis most closely resembles C. pineus in colour and structure and the two may be<tei:lb/>closely related. However, mogimbensis is distinctive, not only in having a flatter pronotum but in having<tei:lb/>3r-m incomplete in the male and lacking dark maculae on the mesoscutum. This species is known to occur<tei:lb/>in tropical Queensland and on Vanuatu (New Hebrides).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype $, New Hebrides: Malekula, Ounua, ii.1929 (Cheesman) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Queensland: 1 $, 1 cf, Claudie R, near Mt Lamond, xii.1971 (McAlpine &amp; Holloway) (AM); 1 cf,<tei:lb/>Shipton's Flat (15-47S 124-14E), x.1980 (Cardale) (ANIC).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Certonotus monticola Morley</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 38)<tei:lb/>Certonotus monticola Morley, 1913: 29. Holotype $, QUEENSLAND (BMNH) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female. Medium-sized species, fore wing length 9-12 mm. Labium with glossae elongate, projecting<tei:lb/>beyond clypeus by a distance equal to or greater than facial height. Lower face at narrowest point 0-9-1-0<tei:lb/>times as broad as high; malar space 0-5-0-6 times as long as basal mandibular width. Occipital carina<tei:lb/>ventrally obsolescent, represented by a stub that is shorter than abscissa of hypostomal carina between it<tei:lb/>and base of mandible. Upper part of pronotum, slightly before posterior corner, weakly convex, in dorsal<tei:lb/>view barely projecting beyond scutal margin; subalar prominence very weakly convex. Scutellum closely<tei:lb/>and coarsely punctate, with transverse crest; metapleuron anteriorly punctate, posteriorly and dorsally;<tei:lb/>submetapleural carina anteriorly abruptly expanded into a broad rounded lobe; metanotum without a<tei:lb/>tooth before lateral carina. Propodeum quite short with anterior transverse carina centrally incomplete;<tei:lb/>posterior transverse carina absent; lateromedian longitudinal carina present only before anterior carina;<tei:lb/>pleural carina complete; area superomedia not delineated; area spiracularis complete, short; first and<tei:lb/>second lateral areae confluent. Fore wing with 3r-m converging on 2r-m but joining Rs separately; 2m-cu<tei:lb/>joining M midway between 3r-m and 2r-m. Hind wing with distal abscissa of Cu^ distinct to wing margin.<tei:lb/>Hind tibia with posterior margin without spine-like bristles. Gaster with segment 1 short and broad, the<tei:lb/>sternite 0-7 times as long as hind coxa, reaching just beyond level of spiracle. Tergite 7 mediodorsally with<tei:lb/>small indentation; tergite 8 posteriorly elongate and narrow; tergite 9 in dorsal view long and truncate.<tei:lb/>Ovipositor projecting beyond apex of gaster by 4-5 times length of hind tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coloration. A reddish brown species with lower face, frontal and genal orbits, central mesoscutal spot,<tei:lb/>scutellum, most of pronotum, much of mesopleuron and virtually all of metapleuron/propodeum behind<tei:lb/>spiracle, yellow. Gaster dark brown, tergites 2+ with anterolateral triangular marks. Fore leg brownish<tei:lb/>yellow, coxa infuscate; mid leg blackish brown, femur distally yellow marked, coxa darker; hind leg with<tei:lb/>coxa black with dorsal yellow marks, femur and tarsus strongly infuscate, tibia less strongly infuscate.<tei:lb/>Pterostigma black, wings weakly infumate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male. Slender gaster, otherwise similar to female but with fore wing length 7-11 mm; malar space<tei:lb/>0-5-0-6 times basal mandibular width; 3r-m present; gaster exceptionally elongate with segment 1 quite<tei:lb/>stout, the sternite 0-6 times as long as hind coxa; gonosquama long, apex a little flattened, with scattered<tei:lb/>hairs of various length. Male similar in general colour pattern to female, although with fewer yellow<tei:lb/>maculae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. C. monticola belongs to the /7av/ce/w-group. It is the only taxon in this complex to occur in<tei:lb/>Australia where it is easily recognizable by the elongate glossae and short occipital carina. C. monticola is<tei:lb/>known to occur in both north Queensland and Papua New Guinea.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype 9&gt; Queensland: Tambourine Mt (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Queensland: 1 $, Middle Claudie R., Iron Range, x.1974 (Daniels) (AM). Papua New Guinea: 1 $,<tei:lb/>Amuk, 165 m, i.1960 (Mao) (BPBM); 1 $, 2 cf , Bulolo, ix.1981, exMyristica sp. (Roberts) (BMNH); 7 $,</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>AUSTRALIAN LABENINI &amp; POECILOCRYPTINI 131</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 Cf , Kiunga, Fly River, viii-x. 1957 (Brandt) (BPBM) ; 2 , Normanby Is. , Wakaiuma, Sewa Bay, xii. 1956<tei:lb/>(Brandt) (BPBM); 1 $, 10 mi. W. Vudal, xi.1970 (TC); 1 $, Waris, S. of Hollandia, 450-500 m, viii.1959<tei:lb/>(Maa) (BPBM).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Certonotus nitidulus Morley<tei:lb/>(Fig. 33)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Certonotus nitidulus Morley, 1913: 29. Holotype cf , VICTORIA (BMNH) [examined].<tei:lb/>Certonotus tasmaniensis Turner, 1919: 550; Hocking, 1967: 57; Short, 1978: 41. Holotype cf , TASMANIA<tei:lb/>(BMNH) [examined]. Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female. Medium to large species, fore wing length 7-14 mm. Labium with glossae unspecialized. Lower<tei:lb/>face at narrowest point 1-0-1-1 times as broad as high; malar space 0-6-0-7 times as long as basal<tei:lb/>mandibular width. Occipital carina ventrally strong, slightly longer than abscissa of hypostomal carina<tei:lb/>between it and base of mandible . Upper part of pronotum , slightly before posterior corner , weakly convex ,<tei:lb/>in dorsal view barely projecting beyond scutal margin; subalar prominence weakly convex. Scutellum<tei:lb/>punctate, transverse keel strong; metapleuron smooth with isolated punctures; submetapleural carina<tei:lb/>anteriorly expanded into a broad rounded lobe; metanotum with a weak tooth opposite anterior end of<tei:lb/>lateral carina. Propodeum quite short with anterior transverse carina centrally incomplete; posterior<tei:lb/>transverse carina absent; lateromedian longitudinal carina present only before anterior carina; pleural<tei:lb/>carina present, complete but rather weak; area superomedia undefined; area spiracularis complete,<tei:lb/>defined posteriorly by an arched carina that is very close to spiracle; first and second lateral areae<tei:lb/>separated, distally delineated. Fore wing with 3r-m converging towards 2r-m, joining Rs separately; 2m-cu<tei:lb/>joining M to 0-3 basad of 3r-m. Hind wing with distal abscissa of Cu\ distinct to wing margin. Hind tibia with<tei:lb/>posterior margin without spine-like bristles. Gaster with segment 1 short, the sternite 0-6 times as long as<tei:lb/>hind coxa, reaching behind level of spiracle. Tergite 7 mediodorsally with indentation almost to 0-5 length<tei:lb/>of tergite; tergite 8 posteriorly short and rounded; tergite 9 in dorsal view transverse. Ovipositor projecting<tei:lb/>beyond apex of gaster by 5-0 times length of hind tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coloration. Colour somewhat variable but generally with antenna black, distally, except for apex of last<tei:lb/>segment, white. Head red-brown, lower face laterally to entirely, genal and frontal orbits pale yellow.<tei:lb/>Alitrunk reddish brown, yellow marks on pronotum medially, anterior 'corners' and central spot on<tei:lb/>mesoscutum, scutellum laterally, tegula, subalar prominence, anterior and posterior mesopleural spots,<tei:lb/>postscutellum and hind part of propodeum. Gaster reddish with tergites posteriorly and laterally yellowish<tei:lb/>margined, and also with spots in anterolateral corners. Fore leg yellow, femur red centrally, peripherally<tei:lb/>black with distal apex yellow. Mid leg similar with coxa black-marked and tibia and tarsus infuscate. Hind<tei:lb/>leg as mid leg but with coxa reddish brown, ventrally black. Pterostigma black, wings hyaline.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male. Similar to female but with fore wing length 7-10 mm; malar space 0-4-0-6 times basal mandibular<tei:lb/>width; 3r-m present; gaster with segment 1 moderately slender, 0-6 times as long as hind coxa; apex of<tei:lb/>gonosquama flattened, bearing two widely separated dense tufts of long hairs. Similarly coloured to<tei:lb/>female.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. C. nitidulus is apparently one of the commonest species in the genus as it has adapted to<tei:lb/>parasitizing an introduced siricid in Pinus radiata plantations in Victoria and Tasmania (Hocking, 1967). In<tei:lb/>coloration C. nitidulus most strongly resembles C. geniculatus (from which it can be separated by reference<tei:lb/>to couplet 8 in the key) but structurally it is most similar to C. annulatus and C. andrewi. C. nitidulus differs<tei:lb/>from both in colour pattern and in the form of the propodeal carinae. This is a quite widespread species in<tei:lb/>the south-east, extending from southern Queensland to Tasmania.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST RECORDS. Siricidae: SirexnoctilioF. (Hocking, 1967).</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Certonotus paluma sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 54, 62)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female. Medium-sized species, fore wing length 8-10 mm. Labium with glossae unspecialized. Lower face<tei:lb/>at narrowest point 1-1-1-2 times as broad as high; malar space 0-8 times as long as basal mandibular width.<tei:lb/>Occipital carina ventrally as long as abscissa of hypostomal carina between it and base of mandible. Upper<tei:lb/>part of pronotum, slightly before posterior corner, very weakly convex, in dorsal view almost parallel with<tei:lb/>mesoscutal margin; subalar prominence weakly convex. Scutellum sparsely punctate, with a posterior<tei:lb/>transverse crest; metapleuron polished, smooth, virtually impunctate; submetapleural carina anteriorly<tei:lb/>expanded into a broad rounded lobe; metanotum barely produced opposite anterior margin of lateral<tei:lb/>carina. Propodeum quite short with anterior transverse carina complete; posterior transverse carina<tei:lb/>present at least centrally; lateromedian longitudinal carina present only anterior to anterior transverse<tei:lb/>carina; pleural carina complete anteriorly, posteriorly obsolescent; area superomedia not bounded<tei:lb/>laterally; area spiracularis completely delineated; first and second lateral areae separated by carina. Fore<tei:lb/>wing with 3r-m converging towards 2r-ra, joining the latter at Rs; 2m-cu joining M at 3&gt;r-m. Hind wing with<tei:lb/>distal abscissa of Cu\ present over distal 0-5 to wing margin, not joined to first abscissa of Cu\. Hind tibia<tei:lb/>with posterior margin without spine-like bristles. Gaster with segment 1 long and narrow, the sternite 0-7<tei:lb/>times as long as hind coxa, reaching to level of spiracle. Tergite 7 mediodorsally with narrow indentation,<tei:lb/>over 0-5 of its length; tergite 8 posteriorly long and narrow; tergite 9 in dorsal view short and pointed.<tei:lb/>Ovipositor projecting beyond apex of gaster by 4 times length of hind tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coloration. Antenna black, distally white with extreme apex of last segment black; head black with face<tei:lb/>and orbits white; ali trunk black or reddish black, with central mesoscutal stripe, scutellum, pronotum,<tei:lb/>tegula, subalar prominence, mesopleuron centrally, metapleuron and propodeum laterally white; gaster<tei:lb/>black with very large lateral triangular areas white. Anterior two pairs of legs white with femora, tibiae and<tei:lb/>tarsi variously infuscate ; hind leg black , coxa dorsally with white spot . Pterostigma blackish , wings hyaline .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. C. paluma is one of the three quite closely related Certonotus species that have an incomplete<tei:lb/>distal abscissa of Cu\ in the hind wing. It is distinguishable from Certonotus sp. A by its unspecialized<tei:lb/>subalar prominence. It is structurally similar to C. ixion, from which it may be separated by reference to the<tei:lb/>key.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Certonotus pineussp. n.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Female. Medium-sized species, fore wing length 7-9 mm. Labium with glossae unspecialized. Upper part of pronotum, slightly before posterior corner, very convex, in dorsal view<tei:lb/>subpyramidal; subalar prominence moderately convex. Scutellum moderately, closely punctate, trans-</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>AUSTRALIAN LABENINI &amp; POECILOCRYPTINI 133</tei:p>
         <tei:p>verse keel weak; metapleuron anteriorly smooth, posteriorly punctate; submetapleural carina anteriorly<tei:lb/>expanded into a broad almost quadrate lobe; metanotum with a very weak tooth before vestige of lateral<tei:lb/>carina. Propodeum quite short with anterior transverse carina present, very close to anterior part of<tei:lb/>propodeum; posterior transverse carina absent; lateromedian longitudinal carina vestigial before anterior<tei:lb/>carina, otherwise absent; pleural carina more or less complete; area superomedia undefined; area<tei:lb/>spiracularis more or less complete except internally; first and second lateral areae not separated. Fore wing<tei:lb/>with 3r-m only slightly convergent towards 2r-m, joining Rs away from 2r-m, making areolet quadrate;<tei:lb/>2m-cu joining M at 3r-m. Hind wing with distal abscissa of Cu\ absent.
