Legs yellow, hind tarsus and sometimes distal apex of tibia blackish.<tei:lb/>Pterostigma black, wings hyaline.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male. Similar to female but with fore wing length 4 mm; malar space 0-7 times basal mandibular width;<tei:lb/>3r-m present; gaster with segment 1 quite stout, the sternite 0-3 times as long as hind coxa; apex of<tei:lb/>gonosquama rounded, bearing scattered hairs. Similar in colour to female but with yellowish areas a little<tei:lb/>paler, more strongly contrasted with infuscate areas; flagellar white mark very indistinct.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. A stocky species easily recognized by the almost pyramidal pronotal convexity. The virtually<tei:lb/>quadrate areolet and very short first sternite are also quite characteristic of this species. C. pineus is only<tei:lb/>known to occur in Queensland.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype $, Queensland: Moses Ck, 45 km N. by E. Mt Finnigan (15-47S 145-17E), x.1980 (Cardale)<tei:lb/>(ANIC).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. Queensland: 1 $, Lake Barrine, ii.1935 (Burns) (NMV); 1 cf , Mt Webb Nat. Park (15-04S<tei:lb/>145-07E), iv.1981 (Naumann) (ANIC); 1 cf , Palm Is. nearTownsville, x (TC).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Certonotus rufescens Morley<tei:lb/>(Figs 22, 25)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Certonotus rufescens Morley, 1913: 30. LECTOTYPE $, QUEENSLAND (BMNH), here designated<tei:lb/>[examined] .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female. Moderately large to large species, fore wing length 8-16 mm. Labium with glossae slightly<tei:lb/>lengthened. Lower face at narrowest point 0-9-1 -0 times as broad as high; malar space 0-9-1-0 times as long<tei:lb/>as basal mandibular width. Occipital carina ventrally rather straight, more than twice as long as abscissa of<tei:lb/>hypostomal carina between it and mandible base. Upper part of pronotum, slightly before posterior<tei:lb/>corner, weakly convex, in dorsal view rounded, just protruding beyond scutal margin; subalar prominence<tei:lb/>very strongly raised, in dorsal view with a blunt, back-curved, thorn-like protuberance. Scutellum<tei:lb/>punctate, with a moderately strong transverse crest; metapleuron smooth, virtually impunctate; submeta-<tei:lb/>pleural carina anteriorly expanded into a broad almost quadrate lobe which usually has ridge near anterior<tei:lb/>corner delimiting a narrow triangular area; metanotum with small tooth opposite anterior end of lateral<tei:lb/>carina. Propodeum moderately long with anterior transverse carina complete; posterior transverse carina<tei:lb/>present as lateral vestige; lateromedian longitudinal carina present before anterior carina; pleural carina<tei:lb/>very strong anteriorly, absent behind anterior carina; area superomedia not delineated laterally; area<tei:lb/>spiracularis complete; first and second lateral areae confluent, not delineated laterally. Fore wing with<tei:lb/>3r-m converging towards 2r-m and joining latter at Rs; 2m-cu joining M at 3r-m to 0-3 towards 2r-m. Hind<tei:lb/>wing with distal abscissa of Cui distinct to wing margin. Hind tibia with posterior margin with one to three<tei:lb/>spine-like bristles. Gaster with segment 1 long and narrow, the sternite 0-9-1-0 times as long as hind coxa,<tei:lb/>reaching behind level of spiracle. Tergite 7 mediodorsally at most only slightly indented on posterior<tei:lb/>margin; tergite 8 posteriorly with process short and rounded; tergite 9 in dorsal view elongated and bluntly<tei:lb/>pointed posteriorly. Ovipositor projecting beyond apex of gaster by 4-5 times length of hind tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coloration. Brownish orange; flagellum black with a white subapical band which is usually well<tei:lb/>developed but is entirely absent in specimens from the northern part of the range. Pterostigma dark brown,<tei:lb/>wings hyaline.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male. Similar to female but with fore wing length 5-7 mm; malar space 0-8-0-9 times basal mandibular</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>134 I. D. GAULD &amp; G. A. HOLLO WAY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>width; 3r-m present; gaster with segment 1 long, slender, the sternite 0-8-1-0 times as long as hind coxa;<tei:lb/>apex of gonosquama simply truncate, not broadened, but with long sparse hairs. Similarly coloured to<tei:lb/>female, flagellum without a white band.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. C. rufescens is easily distinguished from other Australian species by the thorn-like subalar<tei:lb/>prominence. The face of this species is flatter than most other Certonotus and laterally it is abruptly, almost<tei:lb/>angularly rounded before the malar space. The characteristic submetapleural carina and possession of a<tei:lb/>strong, usually Y-shaped vestigial carina above the insertion of the hind coxa are useful confirmatory<tei:lb/>characters. A widespread species extending from northern Queensland south to near Melbourne, Victoria.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lectotype 9, Queensland: Mackay, ix.1901 (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Queensland: 2 $ (paralectotypes), same data as lectotype (BMNH); 2 cf , Mackay, 1909 (BMNH); 1 $ ,<tei:lb/>Montville, ix.1935 (Burns) (NMV); 1 cf , Moses Ck, 4 km N. by E. Mt Finnigan (15-47S 145-17E), x.1980,<tei:lb/>at light (Cardale) (ANIC); 1 $, Mt Glorious, xii.1979 (Galloway} (BMNH); 1 $, Mt Glorious near<tei:lb/>Brisbane, xii.1976 (Boucek) (BMNH); 3 cf, Mt Glorious, i-iii (TC); 2 $, Mt Tambourine, ix-x.1978<tei:lb/>(Galloway) (BMNH); 2 $ , 4 cf , Mt Tambourine, x-xi. 1977 (Galloway) (BMNH). New South Wales: 1 $ ,<tei:lb/>19 km S. Coff s Harbour, i.1958 (Riek) (ANIC); 1 cf , Otford, xii.1962 (Colless) (BMNH); 1 $ , Sassafrass<tei:lb/>Gully, Springwood, ix.1972 (McAlpine) (AM). Victoria: 2 $, Toolangi, i-ii.1983 (Farrugia &amp; Gauld)<tei:lb/>(BMNH); 1 Cf , Yellingbo, xi.1976 (Neboiss) (NMV).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Certonotus sisyphussp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 36, 39, 40)<tei:lb/>[Certonotus hinnuleus Krieger; Morley 1913: 32. Misidentification.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female. Medium to large-sized species, fore wing length 8-18 mm. Labium with glossae slightly leng-<tei:lb/>thened. Lower face at narrowest point 1-1-1-3 times as broad as high; malar space 0-9-1-0 times as long as<tei:lb/>basal mandibular width. Occipital carina ventrally sinuous, much longer than abscissa of hypostomal<tei:lb/>carina between it and mandibular base. Upper part of pronotum, slightly before posterior corner, weakly<tei:lb/>convex, in dorsal view projecting slightly beyond scutal margin, subalar prominence very strongly convex,<tei:lb/>in dorsal view slightly pyramidal. Scutellum sparsely punctate, transverse crest distinct; metapleuron<tei:lb/>smooth with scattered punctures, on larger specimens with punctures closer; submetapleural carina<tei:lb/>anteriorly expanded into a rectangular flange; metanotum with strong tooth opposite end of lateral carina.<tei:lb/>Propodeum moderately long with anterior transverse carina complete; posterior transverse carina strong,<tei:lb/>complete, almost parallel to anterior carina; lateromedian longitudinal carina present only as vestiges<tei:lb/>before anterior carina; pleural carina weak, posteriorly evanescent; area superomedia not defined; area<tei:lb/>spiracularis complete; first and second lateral areae clearly separated though latter weakly defined<tei:lb/>externally. Fore wing with 3r-m strongly converging towards an almost vertical 2r-m, joining Rs separately;<tei:lb/>2m-cu joining M 0-2 from 3r-m towards 2r-m. Hind wing with distal abscissa of Cui distinct to wing margin.<tei:lb/>Hind tibia with posterior margin with one to three spine-like bristles. Gaster with segment 1 long and<tei:lb/>narrow, the sternite 1-0-1-2 times as long as hind coxa, reaching behind level of spiracle. Tergite 7<tei:lb/>mediodorsally with wide indentation to 0-5 length of tergite; tergite 8 posteriorly short and rounded; tergite<tei:lb/>9 in dorsal view as long as wide with blunt point posteriorly. Ovipositor projecting beyond apex of gaster by<tei:lb/>4-5 times length of hind tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coloration. Reddish brown, flagellum darker with subapical white band; clypeus, facial, frontal and<tei:lb/>genal orbits. Subalar prominence, pair of central stripes on mesoscutum, scutellum, mesopleural spot,<tei:lb/>spots in posterolateral corners of tergites 1+ and also on lateral margins of 3+ yellow. Legs yellowish<tei:lb/>brown, anterior two pairs of coxae and distal apex of mid femur yellow. Pterostigma dark brown, wings<tei:lb/>hyaline.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male. Similar to female but with fore wing length 8 mm; malar space 0-7 times basal mandibular width;<tei:lb/>3r-m present; gaster with segment 1 slender, the sternite 1-1 times as long as hind coxa; apex of<tei:lb/>gonosquama with a small angulate lobe that bears scattered long hairs. Similar in colour to female but with<tei:lb/>face entirely yellow, mid tibia yellow and yellow maculae on gaster virtually absent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The fairly elongate petiole, rather flat face and posteriorly flanged lateral propodeal carina<tei:lb/>suggest this species is related to C. rufescens though the pleural carina is not tuberculate as it is in rufescens<tei:lb/>and geniculatus . Superficially C. sisyphus is similar to C. avitus from which it can be distinguished, not only<tei:lb/>by the characters in the key, but also in having a distinctly longer prementum and having the hypostomal<tei:lb/>and occipital carinae meeting further from the base of the mandible than the basal mandibular width.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>AUSTRALIAN LABENINI &amp; POECILOCRYPTINI 135</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Widely distributed in the south-east of Australia; recorded from New South Wales, Victoria and<tei:lb/>Tasmania.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype $, Victoria: Toolangi, xi-xii.1982 (Farrugia &amp; Gauld) (AM).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. Victoria: 8 $ , 1 C?, same data as holotype (BMNH). New South Wales: 2 $ , Acacia Plateau,<tei:lb/>3000 ft, x.1961 (Common &amp; Upton) (ANIC). Tasmania: 1 $, Duck River, 6 km SE. Roger R., xii.1974<tei:lb/>(Neboiss) (NMV); 1 $, MeridithR., 20 km from Corinna, i. 1954 (Campbell) (ANIC); 1 $, Mt Field Nat.<tei:lb/>Park, 250 m, i-ii.1983 (Gauld) (BMNH); 1 $, Picton R. bridge, i.1983 (Gauld) (BMNH); 1 ?, no data<tei:lb/>(ANIC).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Certonotus talus sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 34, 35)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female. Medium-sized species, fore wing length 8-12 mm. Labium with glossae unspecialized. Lower face<tei:lb/>at narrowest point 1-1 times as broad as high; malar space 0-7-0-8 times as long as basal mandibular width.<tei:lb/>Occipital carina ventrally more than twice as long as abscissa of hypostomal carina between it and base of<tei:lb/>mandible. Upper part of pronotum, slightly before posterior corner, very weakly convex, in dorsal view<tei:lb/>barely projecting beyond scutal margin; subalar prominence convex, with a long sharp back-curved spine.<tei:lb/>Scutellum punctate with strong transverse keel; metapleuron very sparsely punctate; submetapleural<tei:lb/>carina anteriorly expanded into a broad triangular lobe; metanotum with a large tooth before anterior end<tei:lb/>of lateral carina. Propodeum moderately long with anterior transverse carina complete; posterior<tei:lb/>transverse carina almost complete; lateromedian longitudinal carina vestigial, discernible only before<tei:lb/>anterior carina; pleural carina strong anteriorly, posteriorly poorly developed or obsolescent; area<tei:lb/>superomedia not delineated; area spiracularis complete, posteriorly very weakly delineated; first and<tei:lb/>second lateral areae present, separated by strong carina. Fore wing with 3r-m converging towards 2r-m,<tei:lb/>joining latter at Rs; 2m-cu joining M at 3r-m. Hind wing with distal abscissa of Cu\ distinct to wing margin.<tei:lb/>Hind tibia with posterior margin with or without one spine-like bristle. Gaster with segment 1 short, the<tei:lb/>sternite 0-8-1-0 times as long as hind coxa, reaching behind level of spiracle. Tergite 7 mediodorsally with<tei:lb/>wide indentation almost to 0-7 length of tergite; tergite 8 posteriorly with long, narrow process; tergite 9 in<tei:lb/>dorsal view long and evenly rounded . Ovipositor projecting beyond apex of gaster by 5 times length of hind<tei:lb/>tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coloration. Antenna black with subapical white band; head reddish brown, orbits and clypeus entirely<tei:lb/>pale; alitrunk reddish, mesoscutum with longitudinal stripes, tegula, subalar prominence, scutellum<tei:lb/>partly, postscutellum, anterior mesopleural spot and paired spots on hind edge of propodeum yellow;<tei:lb/>gaster reddish, lateral margins of all tergites yellow and tergites also with paired large yellow spots in<tei:lb/>posterolateral corners. Fore and mid legs yellow, femur for proximal 0-7 and tibia externally reddish, distal<tei:lb/>tarsal segment blackish; hind leg virtually entirely reddish brown, tarsus infuscate. Pterostigma brown,<tei:lb/>wings hyaline.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The possession of a long, backwardly curved, slender spine arising from the subalar prominence<tei:lb/>immediately distinguishes talus from all other Australian Certonotus. It appears to belong to the<tei:lb/>humeralifer- group but differs in having a more slender petiole with a much longer sternite. One specimen<tei:lb/>has asymmetric hind wings; the left wing has the distal abscissa of Cu\ incomplete, not joining Cu and cu-a,<tei:lb/>whilst in the right wing the vein is complete. This incomplete condition is found in C. ixion andpaluma and<tei:lb/>we believe these are closely related species. All have similarly modified posterior gastral tergites, and<tei:lb/>rather small, oblique areolets. The petiole is more slender in these species than in other taxa in this group<tei:lb/>and the sternite is longer.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>C. talus occurs in New South Wales and Victoria and has been collected in subtropical and temperate wet<tei:lb/>forest.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype $, New South Wales: Dorrigo Nat. Park, E. end of Blackbutt Track, 710 m, ii-iii.1980, in<tei:lb/>subtropical rainforest (Newtown &amp; Thayer) (ANIC).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. Victoria: 2 &lt;J&gt;, Toolangi, xi.1982 (Farrugia) (BMNH). New South Wales: 1 &lt;j&gt;, Tubrabucca,<tei:lb/>i. 1948 (Bums) (NMV).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>136 I. D. GAULD &amp; G. A. HOLLOW AY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Certonotus toolangi sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 60)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female. Medium-sized species, fore wing length 6-7 mm. Labium with glossae unspecialized. Lower face<tei:lb/>at narrowest point 1-1 times as broad as high; malar space 0-9-1-1 times as long as basal mandibular width.<tei:lb/>Occipital carina ventrally as long as basal mandibular width. Occipital carina ventrally as long as or slightly<tei:lb/>longer than abscissa of hypostomal carina between it and base of mandible. Upper part of pronotum,<tei:lb/>slightly before posterior corner, almost flat, in dorsal view parallel to mesoscutal margin; subalar<tei:lb/>prominence moderately convex. Scutellum sparsely punctate, transverse keel weak; metapleuron with<tei:lb/>shallow coarse close punctures; submetapleural carina anteriorly expanded into a broad triangular lobe;<tei:lb/>metanotum with a weak tooth laterally. Propodeum quite short with anterior transverse carina complete;<tei:lb/>posterior transverse carina absent; lateromedian longitudinal carina vestigial, only present before anterior<tei:lb/>transverse carina; pleural carina present anteriorly; area superomedia undefined; area spiracularis<tei:lb/>incompletely defined internally; first and second lateral areae confluent, undefined laterally. Fore wing<tei:lb/>with 3r-m convergent towards 2r-m, joining Rs separately; 2m-cu joining M very near 3r-m. Hind wing with<tei:lb/>distal abscissa of Cui absent. Hind tibia with posterior margin with one spine-like bristle. Gaster with<tei:lb/>segment 1 short and broad, the sternite 0-6 times as long as hind coxa, just reaching level of spiracle.<tei:lb/>Tergite 7 mediodorsally with indentation to 0-5 of length; tergite 8 posteriorly short and rounded; tergite 9<tei:lb/>in dorsal view short and broad. Ovipositor projecting beyond apex of gaster by 4-0-4-5 times length of hind<tei:lb/>tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coloration. Very similarly coloured to leeuwinensis but differing in having the anterior two pairs of<tei:lb/>coxae entirely pale and the tibiae with at least proximal 0-5 whitish and mesoscutum centrally with a pair of<tei:lb/>short yellowish stripes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. C. toolangi belongs to the leeuwinensis-group. It is most readily distinguishable by its colour<tei:lb/>pattern. Structurally it is rather similar to C. leeuwinensis from which it may be distinguished by its shorter<tei:lb/>malar space and ovipositor. It is only known from the south-east of Australia, where it has been taken in<tei:lb/>wet sclerophyll forest.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype $ , New South Wales: New England Nat. Park, x.1962 (Colless) (ANIC).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. Victoria: 2 $, Toolangi, xi.1982 (Farrugia) (BMNH); 1 $, Toolangi, xii.1982 (Farmgia &amp;<tei:lb/>Gauld) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Certonotus zebrus sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 51, 53, 59)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female. Medium-sized species, fore wing length 7-8 mm. Labium with glossae unspecialized. Lower face<tei:lb/>at narrowest point 0-8-0-9 times as broad as high; malar space 0-8-0-9 times as long as basal mandibular<tei:lb/>width. Occipital carina ventrally weak, nearly twice as long as abscissa of hypostomal carina between it and<tei:lb/>mandibular base. Upper part of pronotum, slightly before posterior corner, very weakly convex, in dorsal<tei:lb/>view parallel with mesoscutal margin; subalar prominence strongly convex, centrally somewhat produced.<tei:lb/>Scutellum sparsely punctate, transverse crest quite weak; metapleuron anteriorly smooth, posteriorly with<tei:lb/>scattered punctures; submetapleural carina anteriorly expanded into a broad rounded lobe; metanotum<tei:lb/>with a weak tooth opposite anterior end of lateral carina. Propodeum short with anterior transverse carina<tei:lb/>complete; posterior transverse carina absent; lateromedian longitudinal carina discernible as traces before<tei:lb/>anterior transverse carina; pleural carina incomplete posteriorly; area superomedia not delineated; area<tei:lb/>spiracularis virtually complete; first and second lateral areae confluent, not defined laterally. Fore wing<tei:lb/>with 3r-/n converging towards 2r-ra, well separated at Rs; 2m-cu joining M 0-3 from 3r-m towards 2r-m.<tei:lb/>Hind wing with distal abscissa of Cui absent. Hind tibia with posterior margin with one spine-like bristle.<tei:lb/>Gaster with segment 1 long, the sternite 0-6 times as long as hind coxa, just reaching level of spiracle.<tei:lb/>Tergite 7 mediodorsally with indentation to 0-5 its length; tergite 8 posteriorly short and rounded<tei:lb/>posteriorly. Ovipositor projecting beyond apex of gaster by 4 times length of hind tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coloration. A black species that sometimes has pale yellow-white marks on distal flagellar segments<tei:lb/>(except extreme apex of distal one); lower face entirely, orbits, most of pronotum, tegula, scutellum,<tei:lb/>postscutellum, subalar prominence, mesopleural stripe, most of mesopleuron and propodeum laterally<tei:lb/>and posteriorly, base of petiole, posterior and lateral margins of gastral tergites whitish. Anterior two pairs<tei:lb/>of legs whitish, femora and tibiae centrally, tarsi partly brownish marked. Hind leg black. Pterostigma<tei:lb/>blackish, wings hyaline.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>AUSTRALIAN LABENINI &amp; POECILOCRYPTINI 137</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male. Similar to female but with fore wing length 3 mm; malar space 0-7 times basal mandibular width;<tei:lb/>3r-m present; gaster with segment 1 quite stout, the sternite 0-5 times as long as hind coxa; apex of<tei:lb/>gonosquama flattened slightly with scattered hairs. Similarly coloured to female but with flagellum entirely<tei:lb/>black as is most of mesopleuron and metapleuron.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The holotype differs from the female paratype in having entirely black antennae. C. zebrus<tei:lb/>belongs to the leeuwinensis-group. It is the only species in the complex which is virtually entirely black and<tei:lb/>white. Structurally it is rather unremarkable but it has a more strongly raised subalar prominence than any<tei:lb/>other species in this group.<tei:lb/>It is only known from tropical Queensland.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype $, Queensland: Baldy Mtn Road, via Atherton, vi.1981, ex Malaise trap (Brown) (QM).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. Queensland: 1 cT, 3 km N. by E. Mt Tip Tree (17-02S 145-37E), x.1980, at light (Cardale)<tei:lb/>(ANIC); 1 $, Windsor Tableland via Mt Carbine, xii.1980, ex Malaise trap (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Certonotussp. A<tei:lb/>(Figs 48, 50)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female. Medium-sized species, fore wing length 7 mm. Labium with glossae unspecialized. Lower face at<tei:lb/>narrowest point 1-3 times as broad as high; malar space 1-0 times as long as basal mandibular width.<tei:lb/>Occipital carina ventrally long, about 3 times length of abscissa of hypostomal carina between it and base of<tei:lb/>mandible. Upper part of pronotum, slightly before posterior corner, moderately convex, in dorsal view<tei:lb/>projecting beyond mesoscutal margin; subalar prominence weakly convex, rather sharp and ridge-like.<tei:lb/>Scutellum coarsely, closely punctate, transverse keel weak; metapleuron closely, coarsely punctate;<tei:lb/>submetapleural carina anteriorly expanded into a broad rounded flange, metanotum with a distinct tooth<tei:lb/>near anterior end of lateral carina. Propodeum moderately long with anterior transverse carina centrally<tei:lb/>strong; lateromedian longitudinal carina present anteriorly and weak between transverse carinae; pleural<tei:lb/>carina strong anteriorly, posteriorly obsolescent; area superomedia clearly discernible, hexagonal; area<tei:lb/>spiracularis complete; first and second lateral areae indistinctly delineated, confluent. Fore wing with 3r-m<tei:lb/>converging towards 2r-m, joining Rs separately; 2m-cu joining M opposite 3r-m. Hind wing with distal<tei:lb/>abscissa of Cu\ absent. Hind tibia with posterior margin without spine-like bristles. Gaster with segment 1<tei:lb/>short, the sternite 0-2 times as long as hind coxa, not reaching level of spiracle. Tergite 7 mediodorsally with<tei:lb/>indentation on posterior margin; tergite 8 posteriorly very elongate and narrow; tergite 9 in dorsal view<tei:lb/>quadrate, rounded posteriorly. Ovipositor projecting beyond apex of gaster by 4 times length of hind tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coloration. Head blackish with lower face, genal and frontal orbits yellow; alitrunk reddish brown, the<tei:lb/>tergites peripherally black and only tegula and subalar prominence yellow. Gaster with tergites 3+ with<tei:lb/>posterior and lateral margins very narrowly yellow. Legs reddish brown, anterior two pairs of coxae<tei:lb/>yellowish marked, hind coxa, trochanter, femur proximally and distally, and tarsus infuscate. Pterostigma<tei:lb/>blackish, wings hyaline.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Certonotus sp. A is easily recognized by its colour pattern and possession of very slender tergal<tei:lb/>processes. The area superomedia is almost regularly hexagonal and strongly delineated except for the weak<tei:lb/>posterolateral sides. Despite lacking any trace of a distal abscissa of Ci in the hind wing this species<tei:lb/>appears to be quite closely related to C. ixion, suggesting it belongs in the humeralifer-group rather than in<tei:lb/>the leeuwinensis-group.<tei:lb/>It is known only from Western Australia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED<tei:lb/>Western Australia: 1 $ , Swan River (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tribe POECILOCRYPTINI</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This relatively small tribe is characterized by the lack of an occipital carina dorsally and the<tei:lb/>presence of a single bulla in vein 2m-cu in the fore wing. It is restricted to Australia where it is<tei:lb/>represented by three genera, Alaothyris, Urancyla and Poecilocryptus .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Very little is known about the biology of poecilocryptines, but the available records suggest<tei:lb/>the species all oviposit into nutritious plant tissue. It is possible that the larva is partially<tei:lb/>phytophagous, as it has rather massive mandibles (Short, 1978).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>138 I. D. GAULD &amp; G. A. HOLLOWAY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to genera of Poecilocryptini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Fore wing with areolet and 2r-m obliterated by fusion of Rs and M (Fig. 63); gaster strongly</tei:p>
         <tei:p>laterally compressed; ovipositor very long, at least 6-0 times length of hind tibia</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ALAOTHYRIS Gauld(p. 138)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- Fore wing with areolet distinct, bounded internally by 2r-m (Fig. 5); gaster cylindrical or</tei:p>
         <tei:p>depressed ; ovipositor less than 5 -0 times length of hind tibia 2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Hind wing with distal abscissa of Cu\ present; propodeal carinae vestigial dorsally; ovipositor</tei:p>
         <tei:p>strongly decurved (Fig. 64) URANCYLA Gauld(p. 141)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- Hind wing with distal abscissa of Cu\ absent; propodeum with at least some carinae dorsally;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ovipositor more or less straight POECILOCRYPTUS Cameron (p. 139)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ALAOTHYRIS Gauld</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Genus A; Gauld, 1983: 169.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Alaothyris Gauld, 1984: 93. Type-species: Alaothyris elongissimus Gauld, by original designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Medium-sized species, fore wing length 6 mm; clypeus small, flat, truncate; labrum moderately large,<tei:lb/>exposed; mandible quite short, tapered, twisted about 20 times, almost evenly bidentate; malar space<tei:lb/>slightly less than basal mandibular width. Occipital carina absent on dorsal part of head, ventrally joining<tei:lb/>hypostomal carina above base of mandible. Antenna long, not tapered. Mesoscutum polished, almost<tei:lb/>smooth; notaulus deep on anterior 0-2 of scutum, notaular crest occluding extreme anterior end; scutellum<tei:lb/>weakly convex, not laterally carinate; propodeum long, evenly rounded without carinae dorsally;<tei:lb/>propodeal spiracles circular; gaster inserted at end of short propodeal neck, above and far behind coxal<tei:lb/>insertion. Fore tibia with a small tooth on outer side; mid and hind coxae very elongate; tarsal claws simple.<tei:lb/>Fore wing with cu-a proximal to base of Rs&amp;M ; 3r-m absent; Rs and M fused to obliterate areolet and 2r-m;<tei:lb/>2m-cu with a single bulla. Hind wing with distal abscissa of Ct/i absent; basal cell slender; Sc bearing one<tei:lb/>hamulus. Gaster very long and slender, laterally compressed; tergite 1 slender, with spiracles a little behind<tei:lb/>centre; sternite 1 reaching far behind level of spiracles; tergites 2-3 with laterotergites folded under.<tei:lb/>Ovipositor very long and slender, projecting beyond apex of gaster by more than 6-0 times length of hind<tei:lb/>tibia; apex cylindrical.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. A very distinctive genus easily recognized by its slender facies and characteristic venation. The<tei:lb/>systematic position of this genus is questionable. The mandible and elongate structure suggest a<tei:lb/>relationship with the Labenini, but the position of the petiolar spiracle, venation and shape of propodeum<tei:lb/>suggest that it is perhaps more closely related to the Poecilocryptini, especially Poecilocryptus. Unlike the<tei:lb/>Labenini, Alaothyris does not have fine, file-like teeth on the ovipositor apex, nor apparently does it have a<tei:lb/>lobe at the base of the ovipositor sheath. A single species is known.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Alaothyris elongissimus Gauld</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 63)<tei:lb/>Alaothyris elongissimus Gauld, 1984: 94. Holotype 9, QUEENSLAND (ANIC) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female. Lower face slightly elongate, with a pronounced central tubercle; eye surface finely pubescent;<tei:lb/>ocelli arranged in an equilateral triangle; flagellum with about 28 segments. Mesoscutum polished,<tei:lb/>impunctate; mesopleuron and metapleuron similarly smooth, epicnemial carina dorsally obsolescent;<tei:lb/>submetapleural carina broad anteriorly. Gaster highly polished.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coloration. Predominantly orange-brown species with flagellum, hind leg and gaster darker brown.<tei:lb/>Pterostigma brown, wings hyaline.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male. Similar to female.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The holotype and paratype emerged from the seeds ofAraucaria cunninghamii. What their host<tei:lb/>was is not known. Probably it will be found to be some seed-feeding beetle, but the possibility (given the<tei:lb/>semi-phytophagous tendencies of some labenines) that this is partially a seed-feeding ichneumonid cannot<tei:lb/>be ruled out.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype $, Queensland: Yarraman, vii.1969 (Heather) (ANIC).<tei:lb/>1 O" (paratype), same data as holotype.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>AUSTRALIAN LABENINI &amp; POECILOCRYPTINI 139</tei:p>
         <tei:p>POECILOCR YPTUS Cameron</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Poecilocryptus Cameron, 1901: 527. Type-species: Poecilocryptus nigromaculatus Cameron, by mono-</tei:p>
         <tei:p>typy.<tei:lb/>Poecilopimpla Morley, 1914: 35, 36. [Unnecessary replacement name for Poecilocryptus Cameron.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>[Homonym of Poecilopimpla Cameron, 1903.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Medium-sized species, fore wing length 6-10 mm; clypeus rather small, apically very thin, truncate; labrum<tei:lb/>small, exposed; mandible short, slightly twisted, strongly narrowed, bidenjtate; malar space shorter than<tei:lb/>basal mandibular width. Occipital carina dorsally absent; eye with a weak indentation opposite antennal<tei:lb/>socket. Antenna moderately long, clavate. Mesoscutum polished, virtually impunctate; notauli deep on<tei:lb/>anterior 0-2 of scutum, notaular crests strong. Propodeum abruptly rounded with spiracle oval; area<tei:lb/>superomedia large, quadrate, often confluent with area petiolaris; area externa not usually defined<tei:lb/>laterally; gaster inserted well above level of hind coxae. Fore tibia simple, its apex not bearing a long spine;<tei:lb/>tarsal claws large, simple, or in some species those of the anterior two pairs of legs basally lobate. Fore wing<tei:lb/>with cu-a slightly proximal to base of Rs&amp;M\ 3r-m complete, enclosing a large, transverse pentagonal<tei:lb/>areolet; Im-cu with a single bulla, straight but inclivous. Hind wing with distal abscissa of Cui absent; basal<tei:lb/>cell not exceptionally broad; Sc bearing about two hamuli. Gaster long, quite slender; tergite 1 slender,<tei:lb/>evenly broadened posteriorly with spiracles at or slightly behind centre, sternite reaching to spiracles, that<tei:lb/>of female bearing a pair of knob-like protuberances near anterior end. Ovipositor moderately long,<tei:lb/>projecting beyond apex of gaster by 2-8-3-3 times length of hind tibia, its apex cylindrical, with lower valve<tei:lb/>partially enclosing the upper, with an indistinct matt area laterally, the upper valve with weak dorsal teeth.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Poecilocryptus is an endemic Australian genus with species widely distributed throughout the<tei:lb/>continent. They seem to be associated with a variety of galls on trees of the genera Eucalyptus and Acacia.<tei:lb/>Parrott (1954) recorded three species from Australia. In this work four species are recognized, two of<tei:lb/>which are described as new. One, P. galliphagus, has previously been incorrectly known as P. nigromacula-<tei:lb/>tus. In fact nigromaculatus is a senior synonym of P. stramineus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The relationships of the species. The four species may be placed in two species-groups, the nigromacula-<tei:lb/>tus-group (containing nigromaculatus and galliphagus) which is characterized by having acute lobes on the<tei:lb/>claws of the anterior two pairs of legs, and the nigripectus-group (containing nigripectus and coloratus)<tei:lb/>which has the first lateral area very reduced in size.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to species of Poecilocryptus</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Tergites 1 and 2 of gaster white ; alitrunk predominantly black , only pronotum and anterior parts</tei:p>
         <tei:p>of mesoscutum and mesopleuron orange coloratus sp. n. (p. 139)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- Tergites 1 and 2 of gaster bright yellow, sometimes with black marks; alitrunk predominantly</tei:p>
         <tei:p>bright yellow with profuse black spots</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Propodeum with area superomedia delineated posteriorly by a strong carina (Fig. 56) ; flagellum</tei:p>
         <tei:p>with a subapical pale mark; sternite 1 of gaster with weak antero-ventral sublateral keels;<tei:lb/>tergite 2 entirely yellow nigripectus Turner &amp; Waterston(p. 140)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- Propodeum with area superomedia not delineated posteriorly (Fig. 57); flagellum entirely</tei:p>
         <tei:p>black; sternite 1 of gaster with strong antero-ventral sublateral tubercles; tergite 2 always<tei:lb/>black-marked 3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 Distal apex of hind femur black; ovipositor projecting beyond apex of gaster by 2-0-2-3 times</tei:p>
         <tei:p>length of hind tibia galliphagus sp. n.(p. 140)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- Distal apex of hind femur yellow; ovipositor projecting beyond apex of gaster by 2-8-3-3 times</tei:p>
         <tei:p>length of hind tibia nigromaculatus Cameron(p. 141)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Poecilocryptus coloratus sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male. Small species, fore wing length 4-5 mm. Hypostomal carina, above mandibular base, weakly<tei:lb/>raised. Metapleuron smooth and highly polished. Propodeal carinae quite weak; area superomedia not<tei:lb/>delineated by a carina posteriorly; lateral longitudinal carina present above spiracle; first lateral area quite<tei:lb/>small, less than the area of area dentipara. Fore wing with Rs between 2r-m and 3r-m distinctly shorter than<tei:lb/>length of 2r-m. Fore and mid tarsal claws simple. Gaster with sternite 1 simple.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coloration. Face whitish, head, pronotum and anterior parts of mesothorax orange. Remainder of<tei:lb/>alitrunk black. Gaster with tergites 1 and 2 white, 3 white with a central black mark, 4+ black with<tei:lb/>posterior and lateral margins broadly white. Flagellum black. Fore leg orange; mid leg with femur and</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>140 I. D. GAULD &amp; G. A. HOLLOW AY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>proximal segments white, tibia and tarsus blackish; hind leg black, femur proximally and distally slightly<tei:lb/>reddish orange. Pterostigma blackish, wings infumate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This small species is easily recognized by its atypical colour pattern. It is the only species in the<tei:lb/>genus that is not predominantly yellow. The propodeal carination is also quite distinctive. The simple tarsal<tei:lb/>claws and small first lateral area suggest P. color atus may be related to P. nigripectus .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , Tasmania: Coles Bay, ii-iii.19-- (TC).<tei:lb/>Paratypes. Tasmania: 3 cf , same data as holotype (BMNH, TC); 1 cf , Mt Barrow, 700 m, ii.19-- (TC).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Poecilocryptus galliphagussp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>[Poecilocryptus nigromaculatus Cameron; Parrott, 1954: 240. Misidentification.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female. Medium-sized species, fore wing length 7-10 mm. Hypostomal carina, above mandibular base,<tei:lb/>moderately raised. Metapleuron smooth and highly polished. Propodeal carinae strong; area superomedia<tei:lb/>not delineated by a carina posteriorly; lateral longitudinal carina not complete above spiracle; first lateral<tei:lb/>area very large, more than twice the area of area dentipara. Fore wing with Rs between 2r-m and 3r-m<tei:lb/>about twice as long as length of 2r-m. Fore and mid tarsal claws with a well-developed acute basal lobe.<tei:lb/>Gaster with sternite 1 bearing a pair of antero-ventral sublateral tubercles. Ovipositor projecting beyond<tei:lb/>apex of gaster by 2-0-2-3 times length of hind tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coloration. A bright yellow species with black marks on interocellar area, vertex behind ocelli, three<tei:lb/>longitudinal stripes on mesoscutum, anterior propodeal areae, anterior margin of all abdominal tergites,<tei:lb/>hind femur centrally and hind tibia distally. Flagellum and ovipositor sheath black. Distal tarsal segments<tei:lb/>slightly infuscate. Pterostigma dark brown, wings hyaline.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male. Similar to female though slightly more slender, often with sternal tubercles very weak.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species is rather similar to P. nigromaculatus, with which it is frequently confused in<tei:lb/>collections. The two species may easily be separated by the characters given in the key.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST RECORDS. This species has been reared from galls on Eucalyptus delegatensis and E. pauciflora.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype $ , Victoria: Wiseleigh via Bruthen, ix.1962, ex eucalypt gall (Hobb) (NMV).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. Queensland: 1 $, no further data (Riek) (BMNH). New South Wales: 1 $, Dainer's Gap,<tei:lb/>xi.1972 (ANIC); 1 $, Deer Vale, i.1931 (Burns) (NMV); 1 cf , Mt Victoria, x.1930 (Burns) (NMV); 1 $,<tei:lb/>Sydney (Froggatt) (ANIC). Victoria: 2 $, Eildon area, ix.1959 (Irvine) (NMV); 2 $, Mt Pinniber, iv.1961<tei:lb/>(Taylor) (ANIC); 1 $, Toolangi, xi.1982 (Farrugia) (BMNH); 3 $, Warrandyte, viii-x.1928 (Hill)<tei:lb/>(ANIC); 2 Cf, no further locality data (French) (BMNH). Tasmania: 3 $, Collinsvale, Fairy Glen,<tei:lb/>i-ii.1983 (Williams &amp; Gauld) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Poecilocryptus nigripectus Turner &amp; Waterston</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 56)<tei:lb/>Poecilocryptus nigripectus Turner &amp; Waterston, 1920: 24. Holotype $, TASMANIA (BMNH) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female. Medium-sized species, fore wing length 7-11 mm. Hypostomal carina, above mandibular base,<tei:lb/>strongly raised. Metapleuron with distinct longitudinal wrinkles, moderately polished. Propodeal carinae<tei:lb/>strong; area superomedia rectangular, delineated by a carina posteriorly; lateral longitudinal carina<tei:lb/>complete above spiracle; first lateral area not exceptionally large, of approximately the same area as area<tei:lb/>dentipara. Fore wing with Rs between 2r-m and 3r-m subequal to length of 2r-m. Fore and mid tarsal claws<tei:lb/>simple. Gaster with sternite 1 bearing a pair of weak antero-ventral sublateral keels. Ovipositor projecting<tei:lb/>beyond apex of gaster by 2-2-2-4 times length of hind tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coloration. Bright yellow species with interocellar area, vertex behind eyes, posterior part of mesoscu-<tei:lb/>tum, anterior part of propodeum and metapleuron, anterior 0-7 of tergite 1, and most of tergites 3 and 6<tei:lb/>black. Legs yellow, hind femur broadly black centrally, distal hind tarsal segment infuscate. Flagellum<tei:lb/>black, with a broad subapical yellowish white band. Pterostigma dark brown, wings hyaline.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male. Similar to female but slightly more slender and with gastral tergites more coarsely punctate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This is a particularly characteristically patterned species. Structurally it is more similar to P.<tei:lb/>coloratus than it is to P. nigromaculatus, a species that it superficially resembles in ground-colour.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>AUSTRALIAN LABENINI &amp; POECILOCRYPTINI 141</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST RECORDS. In the BMNH is a specimen reared from anthribid galls.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype $ , Tasmania: Mt Wellington (Turner) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Queensland: 4 $ , Brisbane, ii.1969 (Campbell) (QM); 1 cf , Iron Range, v.1975 (Moulds) (AM); 1 $, no<tei:lb/>data (NMV). New South Wales: 1 cf, Bateman's Bay, x.1969 (Riek) (ANIC); 1 $&gt; Bendigo (Froggatt)<tei:lb/>(ANIC). Australian Capital Territory: 2 $, Canberra, x.1930 (Bruce) (ANIC).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Poecilocryptus nigromaculatus Cameron</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Poedlocryptus nigromaculatus Cameron, 1901: 528. LECTOTYPE $, AUSTRALIA (BMNH), here desig-<tei:lb/>nated [examined] .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Poeciloeryptus (sic) nigro-maculatus Cameron; Cameron, 1911: 335.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Poecilopimpla nigromaculata (Cameron) Morley, 1914: 36.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Poecilopimpla nigromaculata var. straminea Morley, 1914: 36. Holotype $, NEW SOUTH WALES (BMNH)<tei:lb/>[examined]. Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Poecilocryptus stramineus (Morley) Parrott, 1954: 241.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Poecilocryptus nigromaculatus Cameron; Townes et al. , 1961: 117.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female. Medium-sized species, fore wing length 6-10 mm. Hypostomal carina, above mandibular base,<tei:lb/>weakly raised. Metapleuron smooth and highly polished. Propodeal carinae strong; area superomedia not<tei:lb/>delineated by a carina posteriorly; lateral longitudinal carina absent above spiracle; first lateral area very<tei:lb/>large, more than twice the area of area dentipara. Fore wing with Rs between 2r-m and 3r-m about twice as<tei:lb/>long as length of 2r-m. Fore and mid tarsal claws with a well-developed acute basal lobe. Gaster with<tei:lb/>sternite 1 bearing a pair of antero-ventral sublateral tubercles. Ovipositor projecting beyond apex of gaster<tei:lb/>by 2-8-3-3 times length of hind tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coloration. A bright yellow species with black marks on interocellar area, vertex behind ocelli, three<tei:lb/>longitudinal stripes on mesoscutum, anterior propodeal areae, anterior margin of all abdominal tergites<tei:lb/>and hind femur centrally. Flagellum and ovipositor sheath black. Distal hind tarsal segments strongly<tei:lb/>infuscate. Pterostigma dark brown, wings hyaline.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male. Similar to female though slightly more slender, often with sternal tubercles very weak.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. In the BMNH are two specimens labelled as 'Cameron types' of nigromaculatus. They are<tei:lb/>conspecific and one has been labelled and is here designated as lectotype. Morley (1914) clearly referred to<tei:lb/>the female that was reared by Froggatt as the 'typical' specimen, and this must be construed as a valid type<tei:lb/>restriction (Art. 73(a)(i) of the Code). Parrott (1954) was incorrect to refer to the male in Froggatt's<tei:lb/>collection as the holotype. The female holotype is a slightly undersized specimen, but clearly conspecific<tei:lb/>with nigromaculatus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>P. nigromaculatus appears to be the sister-species of P. galliphagus. Both species have a well-developed<tei:lb/>basal lobe on the fore and mid tarsal claws and have the first lateral area of the propodeum greatly<tei:lb/>enlarged. P. nigromaculatus may be recognized by its elongate ovipositor and entirely yellow hind tibia.<tei:lb/>We have examined the differences between this species and galliphagus tabulated by Parrott (1954) and<tei:lb/>have found that only the ovipositor character holds up. We failed to find any difference in the ratio of<tei:lb/>interocellar to orbital-ocellar distance, and the range of numbers of flagellar segments for both species is<tei:lb/>very similar. Small specimens of either species have fewer flagellar segments than large individuals. The<tei:lb/>extent of the black banding on third to fifth gastral tergites is quite variable in both species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST RECORDS. P. nigromaculatus has been reared from anthribid and chalcid galls on Acacia longifolia,<tei:lb/>and eriococcid galls on Eucalyptus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lectotype $ (nigromaculatus Cameron), 'Australia': no further data (BMNH). Paralectotype, 1 $,<tei:lb/>same data (BMNH). Holotype $ (nigromaculata var. straminea Morley), New South Wales: no further<tei:lb/>data (Froggatt) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>'Australia': 1 $ (paralectotype of nigromaculatus) (BMNH). 38 $,34 cf, Queensland, New South<tei:lb/>Wales, Australian Capital Territory, Victoria, Tasmania (ANIC, BMNH, NMV).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>URANCYLA Gauld</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Genus U; Gauld, 1983: 169.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Urancyla Gauld, 1984: 95. Type-species: Urancylafulva Gauld, by original designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Medium-sized species; fore wing length 6 mm; clypeus flat, small, apically truncate with margin thin;</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>142 I. D. GAULD &amp; G. A. HOLLO WAY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>mandible strongly tapered, twisted and with upper tooth slightly the longer; malar space shorter than basal<tei:lb/>mandibular width. Occipital carina absent dorsally , ventrally joining hypostomal carina well above base of<tei:lb/>mandible. Antenna long, neither tapered nor clavate distally. Mesoscutum polished, punctate; notaulus<tei:lb/>present near front margin, with a small crest occluding extreme end; scutellum flat, without lateral carinae;<tei:lb/>propodeum evenly rounded with vestiges of carinae though areae superomedia and petiolaris are not<tei:lb/>defined; gaster inserted low on propodeum, near level of hind coxae. Fore tibia with a small tooth on outer<tei:lb/>side, femur with a weak longitudinal ventral furrow; tarsal claws of female with a basal lobe. Fore wing with<tei:lb/>cu-a subopposite Rs&amp;M; 3r-m present, weakly pigmented, enclosing a small pentagonal areolet; 2m-cu<tei:lb/>with a single bulla. Hind wing with distal abscissa of Cu\ present; first abscissa of Cu\ shorter than cu-a;<tei:lb/>basal cell moderately broad; Sc bearing one hamulus. Gaster moderately long, tergite 1 slender with<tei:lb/>spiracle slightly behind centre; tergites 2 and 3 with pendant laterotergites which are almost membranous.<tei:lb/>Ovipositor about as long as gaster, evenly decurved, apex simply acute with inconspicuous teeth and<tei:lb/>indistinct matt area laterally.<tei:lb/>Male. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. In Townes' (1969) key to Labiinae this genus runs to the tribe Clasini but it does not appear to be<tei:lb/>related to the genera in this group. Clasines have a nodus on the ovipositor apex, long, simple claws and<tei:lb/>two bullae in 2m-cu. They also have no trace of a notaular crest. The twisted mandible and single bulla in<tei:lb/>2m-cu are characters that Urancyla shares with Poecilocryptus and the two genera appear to be closely<tei:lb/>related.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Urancyla fulva Gauld</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 64)<tei:lb/>Urancyla fulva Gauld, 1984: 95. Holotype $, QUEENSLAND (TC) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female. Lower face elongate, regularly punctate; frons polished and finely punctate; ocelli arranged in an<tei:lb/>equilateral triangle. Flagellum with 30 segments. Mesoscutum polished, regularly and finely punctate;<tei:lb/>mesopleuron highly polished, smooth, almost impunctate; metapleuron polished with scattered fine<tei:lb/>punctures; submetapleural carina moderately wide, evenly tapered anteriorly. Gaster highly polished,<tei:lb/>finely punctate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coloration. Predominantly orange-brown species; face, upper orbits, genae, propleuron, anterior<tei:lb/>margin of pronotum, diagonal stripe across mesopleuron, fore coxa and trochanters and a stripe on mid<tei:lb/>coxa pale yellowish; flagellum, except centrally, scape and pedicel, frons centrally, vertex, interocellar<tei:lb/>area, occiput, mesoscutum and ovipositor sheath, pterostigma black.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species is known only from the holotype.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED<tei:lb/>Holotype $, Queensland: Brisbane, xi.1972 (Sedlacek) (TC).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acknowledgements</tei:p>

We are particularly grateful to Dennis Farrugia for collecting<tei:lb/>a considerable amount of material in southern Victoria. IDG would like to thank ABRS for providing a<tei:lb/>grant to study in Australia. GAH would like to thank the New South Wales Premier's Department for<tei:lb/>support whilst overseas, and Nestle (Australia) Ltd for funds.</tei:p>

         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>/. D. Gauld</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In the important field of biological and integrated control of pests the parasitic Hymenoptera<tei:lb/>are of particular significance, and this work considers one of the largest families of Parasitica,<tei:lb/>the Ichneumonidae. The group has received little attention in Australia - though it has already<tei:lb/>been utilized successfully in curtailing the ravages caused by accidentally introduced pests. For<tei:lb/>selective control programmes to be effective, however, a sound knowledge of the biology of<tei:lb/>both the pest and its parasites is essential - and a sound taxonomic base is vital for the<tei:lb/>development of such knowledge.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ironically, considering the group's economic importance, the parasitic Hymenoptera are<tei:lb/>amongst the least studied of any group of living organisms, and taxonomic difficulties have<tei:lb/>presented major problems to many entomologists working with the Parasitica. An<tei:lb/>Introduction to the Ichneumonidae of Australia will go a long way towards rectifying this<tei:lb/>situation, being a taxonomic treatment, by genus, of the Australian ichneumonids, a<tei:lb/>comprehensive illustrated identification guide, and a summary of all available information on<tei:lb/>the group. It will also serve as an introduction to the biology and distribution of Australian<tei:lb/>ichneumonids, and provide a check-list of the described species and an index to their known<tei:lb/>hosts. It provides an important revision of ichneumonid nomenclature in order to bring the<tei:lb/>group into line with the generally accepted principles of zoological nomenclature.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1984, 413pp, 3 maps, 580 figs. Paperback. 565 008% X 40.00</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>

         <tei:p>The tribe Pseudophloeini (Hemiptera:<tei:lb/>Coreidae) in the Old World tropics with a<tei:lb/>discussion on the distribution of the<tei:lb/>Pseudophloeinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>W. R. Dolling</tei:p>

         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>The Bulletin of the British Museum (Natural History), instituted in 1949, is issued in four<tei:lb/>scientific series, Botany, Entomology, Geology (incorporating Mineralogy) and Zoology,<tei:lb/>and an Historical series.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Papers in the Bulletin are primarily the results of research carried out on the unique and<tei:lb/>ever-growing collections of the Museum, both by the scientific staff of the Museum and by<tei:lb/>specialists from elsewhere who make use of the Museum's resources. Many of the papers are<tei:lb/>works of reference that will remain indispensable for years to come.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Parts are published at irregular intervals as they become ready, each is complete in itself,<tei:lb/>available separately, and individually priced. Volumes contain about 300 pages and several<tei:lb/>volumes may appear within a calendar year. Subscriptions may be placed for one or more of<tei:lb/>the series on either an Annual or Per Volume basis. Prices vary according to the contents of<tei:lb/>the individual parts. Orders and enquiries should be sent to:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Publications Sales,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>British Museum (Natural History),<tei:lb/>Cromwell Road,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>London SW75BD,<tei:lb/>England.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>World List abbreviation: Bull. Br. Mus. nat. Hist. (Ent.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trustees of the British Museum (Natural History), 1986</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Entomology series is produced under the general editorship of the<tei:lb/>Keeper of Entomology: Laurence A. Mound<tei:lb/>Assistant EiJi</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ISBN 565 06021 X<tei:lb/>ISSN 0524-6431</tei:p>
         <tei:p>British Museum (Natural History)<tei:lb/>Cromwell Road<tei:lb/>London SW75BD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Entomology series<tei:lb/>Vol 53 No 3 pp 151-212</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Issued 30 October 1986</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>,AL nia</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The tribe Pseudophloeini (Hemiptera: Coreidae) in<tei:lb/>the Old World tropics with a discussion on the<tei:lb/>distribution of the Pseudophloeinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>W. R. Dolling</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Department of Entomology, British Museum (Natural History), Cromwell Road, London<tei:lb/>SW7 5BD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Contents</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Synopsis 151</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Introduction 151</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Diagnosis of Pseudophloeinae and its division into tribes 152</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Rejected genera 154</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abbreviations of depositories 155</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Terminology and measurements 155</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to the genera of Pseudophloeini found in the Old World tropics 156</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Risbecocoris Izzard 156</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HoplolomiaS&amp;l 161</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Indolomia gen. n 163</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paramyla Linnavuori 165</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Psilolomia Breddin 168</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pungragen.n 179</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pseudomyla gen. n 180</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Neomevaniomorpha gen. n 183</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mevaniomorpha Reuter 185</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mevanidea Reuter 187</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Arenocoris Hahn 191</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A/v/flStal 193</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Distribution of Pseudophloeinae 205</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acknowledgements 209</tei:p>
         <tei:p>References 209</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Index 212</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Synopsis</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The major morphological features of the Pseudophloeini are outlined and their bearing on the classifica-<tei:lb/>tion of the tribe is discussed. Twelve genera and 43 species are recognized in the tropical regions of Africa<tei:lb/>and Asia; descriptions and keys for their separation are provided. Four genera and 16 species are described<tei:lb/>as new. Three new synonymies are established at the genus-level and four at the species-level; 10 new<tei:lb/>combinations are established; two 'forms' are raised to the status of species and nine lectotypes are<tei:lb/>designated.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Introduction</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Plant-feeding bugs of the family Coreidae are characteristic inhabitants of the herb and shrub<tei:lb/>layers of tropical and, to a lesser extent, of temperate ecosystems. They are frequently<tei:lb/>encountered in surveys of crop pests, since most of the world's tropical crops are herbs or shrubs,<tei:lb/>and are usually represented in collections made during ecological studies in the tropics. Most of<tei:lb/>the literature available for the identification of Coreidae is out of date, fragmentary or lacks<tei:lb/>identification keys.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pseudophloeinae may be recognized, with a little practice, by their general habitus and size,<tei:lb/>and by the absence of a dorsal sulcus on the tibiae; other groups of Coreoidea lacking tibial sulci</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bull. Br. Mus. not. Hist. (Ent.) 53 (3): 151-212 30 October 1986</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>152 W. R. DOLLING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- Alydidae, Rhopalidae, Stenocephalidae and the coreid subfamily Hydarinae - are unlikely to<tei:lb/>be mistaken for Pseudophloeinae because they are all of characteristic appearance. Coreinae<tei:lb/>similar in size and build to Pseudophloeinae all have very distinct tibial sulci. Twenty-eight valid<tei:lb/>genera and 166 species of Pseudophloeinae have been described. Most of the species are 7-10<tei:lb/>mm in length; a species of typical appearance is illustrated in Fig. 1.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The food plants of all species of the subfamily, where known, are herbaceous legumes<tei:lb/>(Fabaceae). Host plant records for the tropical Pseudophloeini are very scarce, as are other<tei:lb/>details of their biology. There is only a single, New World, species of the subfamily in which<tei:lb/>facultative brachyptery is known; all other species are fully macropterous. Flight, therefore, is<tei:lb/>probably important, yet there are very few records of them being caught in light traps,<tei:lb/>interception traps or yellow trays; presumably they fly only rarely and then not far. Most species<tei:lb/>have rather restricted ranges and only one is recorded from oceanic islands. Tropical-crop<tei:lb/>entomologists and collectors in Europe report them to move sluggishly even when disturbed and<tei:lb/>to be reluctant to fly. The typical habitats of Pseudophloeinae reflect those of their host plants:<tei:lb/>open woodlands and grasslands with scattered trees; a few species have penetrated drier<tei:lb/>grasslands on the one hand and forest clearings on the other, but deserts and dense forests, to<tei:lb/>judge from the distribution patterns of the tropical species, are impenetrable barriers to most of<tei:lb/>them. Several species are restricted to high altitudes, suggesting that low temperatures are not<tei:lb/>barriers to dispersal in the long term, a reasonable supposition in view of the richness of the<tei:lb/>Palaearctic pseudophloeine fauna.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The subfamily is represented in almost all parts of the major land masses except for<tei:lb/>non-tropical Australia. Recent revisions by Froeschner (1963), Dolling (1977) and Dolling &amp;<tei:lb/>Yonke (1976) enable the Nearctic and Neotropical species to be identified. Most Palaearctic<tei:lb/>species are covered by the keys of Stichel (1960), which should be used in conjunction with the<tei:lb/>notes of Chernova (1979). The largest Palaearctic genus, Coriomeris Westwood, was revised by<tei:lb/>Chernova (1978). A new Palaearctic species of Microtelocerus Reuter was described from Sinai<tei:lb/>by Dolling (19796) and a new genus with a single new species was added by Puchkov (1979). The<tei:lb/>tribe Clavigrallini, which is confined to the Old World tropics and contains a number of pest<tei:lb/>species, has been monographed by Dolling (1978: 1979a). The present revision covers all of the<tei:lb/>genera of Pseudophloeinae not treated in the above works.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Diagnosis of Pseudophloeinae and its division into tribes</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Stal's original (1868: 535) diagnosis of Pseudophloeinae mentioned only the presence of an<tei:lb/>antevannal vein. Later (1873: 33-34), he mentioned also the broad cells at the base of the<tei:lb/>hemelytral membrane, the form of the metathoracic scent-gland auricle, the lack of a median<tei:lb/>dorsal impression on the head, the prominent and gently declivent tylus and juga, the prominent<tei:lb/>posterior angles of the seventh abdominal segment in both sexes, and the non-sulcate tibiae.<tei:lb/>Dolling (1978: 282) gave a fuller diagnosis, adding mention of the outer apical processes of the<tei:lb/>antennifers and several features of the genitalia. The antevannal vein is not present in five<tei:lb/>genera: the Neotropical Vilga Stal; the Oriental Hoplolomia Stal and Indolomia gen. n., the<tei:lb/>Afrotropical Paramyla Linnavuori and the Afro- Asian Risbecocoris Izzard. All five of these<tei:lb/>genera accord well with the revised diagnosis of the subfamily and there seems no reason to<tei:lb/>exclude them from it because of the absence of this single character; in fact, Stal (1873) included<tei:lb/>Hoplolomia in Pseudophloeinae, presumably on the basis of other features and in ignorance of<tei:lb/>the venation of the hind wing.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The tribe Clavigrallini was erected (as division Clavigrallaria) by Stal (1873: 81) in a key to the<tei:lb/>African and Asian genera of the subfamily. It was characterized by him as having the scutellum<tei:lb/>convex, the base of the posterior femur devoid of the small tubercle which is present in many<tei:lb/>genera of Pseudophloeinae, the body compressed laterally, the male genital capsule not<tei:lb/>biemarginate posteriorly, the propleuron emarginate on its posterior margin near the postero-<tei:lb/>dorsal angle, the second antennal segment equalling or exceeding the third in length and the<tei:lb/>prescutellar angles of the pronotum armed with a spine. The first couplet of Stal's key contrasted<tei:lb/>Mevania Stal, My la Stal and Hoplolomia with the 'Clavigrallaria', uniting these three non-</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>TRIBE PSEUDOPHLOEINI</tei:p>
         <tei:p>153</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 1 Psilolomia pundaloyae , dorsal view of male .</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>154 W. R. DOLLING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>clavigralline genera on the basis of their common possession of a flat or almost flat scutellum, a<tei:lb/>tubercle at the base of the posterior femur, the posteriorly biemarginate genital capsule with the<tei:lb/>emargination filled by the apices of the parameres, the posterior tibia not or slightly shorter than<tei:lb/>the femur and the second antennal segment shorter than the third. Although Stal did not<tei:lb/>formally diagnose or name a 'division Pseudophloearia' to contrast with his 'Clavigrallaria', his<tei:lb/>recognition of the latter implies the existence of the nominate tribe. An additional feature, both<tei:lb/>universal among Clavigrallini and restricted to them, is the presence of a pair of small tubercles<tei:lb/>at the base of the mesoscutellum adjacent to the posterior margin of the pronotum. In a few<tei:lb/>Clavigrallini, the second antennal segment is shorter than the third, or the scutellum is flat, or<tei:lb/>the genital capsule is biemarginate posteriorly, or the posterior tibiae are subequal in length to<tei:lb/>the femora, or the body is depressed rather than compressed. The emargination of the<tei:lb/>propleuron, the absence of a femoral tubercle and the presence of the basal tubercles of the<tei:lb/>scutellum are constant features of the tribe, as is the presence of an antevannal vein. Among the<tei:lb/>non-clavigralline genera, the scutellum is occasionally convex and the propleuron emarginate<tei:lb/>(both conditions well developed in Vilga westwoodi (Kolenati)). The tubercle at the base of the<tei:lb/>femur is absent in Risbecocoris and Vilga.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>No further tribes have been described, so the subfamily at present comprises the Clavigrallini<tei:lb/>and the nominate tribe, Pseudophloeini. The unique characters of the Clavigrallini are probably<tei:lb/>apomorphies within Pseudophloeinae while those of Pseudophloeini are, in general, plesiomor-<tei:lb/>phies. Both the presence of the basal tubercle of the posterior femur and the presence of the<tei:lb/>antevannal vein of the metathoracic wing are probably apomorphies within the subfamily<tei:lb/>(though it is interesting to note that the genus Spathocera Stein, in the Coreinae, has an<tei:lb/>antevannal vein, and a group of genera including Riptortus Stal, in the Alydinae, have a femoral<tei:lb/>tubercle). Pseudophloeinae can, therefore, be divided into four unequal groups (Table 1): Vilga<tei:lb/>and Risbecocoris, lacking both vein and tubercle; Paramyla, Hoplolomia and Indolomia,<tei:lb/>lacking the vein but possessing the tubercle; Clavigrallini, possessing the vein but lacking the<tei:lb/>tubercle; and all the remaining genera, possessing both vein and tubercle. Assuming that the<tei:lb/>lack of both vein and tubercle is primitive, a possible interpretation of the phylogeny of the<tei:lb/>Pseudophloeinae is that Clavigrallini and most Pseudophloeini are united by descent from a<tei:lb/>common ancestor that had no femoral tubercle but had acquired an antevannal vein; from this<tei:lb/>stock developed two lines: on the one hand Clavigrallini and on the other all those genera with<tei:lb/>both a femoral tubercle and an antevannal vein. On this interpretation, Paramyla, Hoplolomia<tei:lb/>and Indolomia would have acquired their femoral tubercles independently of most Pseudo-<tei:lb/>phloeini; alternatively, these three genera may have secondarily lost their antevannal veins.<tei:lb/>Recently, Stys (1978) suggested that the antevannal vein was primitively present in the common<tei:lb/>ancestor of all Coreidae. This interpretation is rejected here because it would involve recogni-<tei:lb/>tion of a group comprising the genera Vilga, Risbecocoris, Paramyla, Hoplolomia and Indolo-<tei:lb/>mia sharing the apomorphy of the loss of this vein. This group, based on a loss character that<tei:lb/>unites these five morphologically diverse and geographically widely dispersed genera, is unlikely<tei:lb/>to have any phyletic validity.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A classification that reflected the most probable phylogeny of the subfamily would require the<tei:lb/>erection of two or three additional tribes to accommodate Vilga, Risbecocoris and, possibly,<tei:lb/>Paramyla plus Hoplolomia plus Indolomia. An assumption of independent acquisition of the<tei:lb/>antevannal vein by Clavigrallini and the main group of Pseudophloeini would require separate<tei:lb/>tribes for Vilga and Risbecocoris but not the other three of these genera. In the present work<tei:lb/>such new tribes are not erected. The subfamily Pseudophloeinae and the tribe Clavigrallini are<tei:lb/>both believed to be holophyletic in composition, leaving the nominate tribe paraphyletic.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Rejected genera</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Four genera represented in the geographical area covered by the present revision were originally<tei:lb/>described in Pseudophloeinae or associated with genera that belong in the subfamily.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Brotheolus Bergroth (1908: 107) is a replacement name for the preoccupied Brotheus Distant</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>TRIBE PSEUDOPHLOEINI 155</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(19020: 248) which was placed by Distant (p. 246) in Pseudophloeinae. It was transferred to<tei:lb/>Coreinae: Gonocerini by Dolling (19796: 97).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trallianus Distant (19026: 404-405) was originally placed in Pseudophloeinae but was<tei:lb/>transferred to Coreidae: Gonocerini by Dolling (19796: 97).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cristovallia Distant (1920: 149-150) was said by its author to have 'affinity with the genera<tei:lb/>Clavigralla and Ceraleptus' (both Pseudophloeinae). Brown (1958: 514) synonymized its<tei:lb/>type-species, C. typica Distant, with Amblypelta bilineata Stal in Coreinae: Dasynini.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Austrocoris Hsiao (1965: 426) was described in Pseudophloeinae. Later, Hsiao (1977: 253)<tei:lb/>synonymized it with Chariesterus Laporte but placed the latter genus in Pseudophloeinae. Its<tei:lb/>correct position is in Coreinae: Chariesterini.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abbreviations of depositories</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Terminology and measurements</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Antennal and rostral segments are numbered I to IV starting with the segment attached to the<tei:lb/>body. The term 'rostral' is used in preference to 'labial' because the base of the first segment of<tei:lb/>the labium is usually obscured; the first segment of the rostrum is arbitrarily taken to commence<tei:lb/>at the base of the labrum, which is almost always visible. Measurement of antennal segments<tei:lb/>excludes the narrow, unsculptured bases of segments I, II and III and the small ring-segment<tei:lb/>between HI and IV. Ranges of measurements are given where this procedure seems useful (it is<tei:lb/>not used in the case of ratios of lengths of rostral and antennal segments, where it would be too<tei:lb/>cumbersome and would be of minimal use in identifying species). Means were calculated during<tei:lb/>the preparation of this revision but were discarded: because of the unequal representation of<tei:lb/>different populations in the samples available it was felt that they would be unhelpful and<tei:lb/>possibly misleading. Surprisingly often, means were found to fall almost exactly half-way<tei:lb/>between the extremes of the ranges cited. The reliability of the range of measurements of any<tei:lb/>species as a guide to what might be encountered by the reader in examining his own material will<tei:lb/>depend largely on the number of specimens examined by the author and the number of localities<tei:lb/>from which they were collected; this information is given under the heading 'Material examined'<tei:lb/>for each species. It should be borne in mind that the antennae of these insects are fragile and that<tei:lb/>the figures given for the ratios of the lengths of the antennal segments are in all likelihood based<tei:lb/>on progressively fewer specimens as one proceeds towards the distal end of the antenna. The</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>156 W. R. DOLLING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>term 'posterior' as applied to angles and spines of the pronotum is avoided in favour of the<tei:lb/>unambiguous terms 'posterolateral' and 'prescutellar' ; the former usually project laterally or<tei:lb/>anterolaterally from the sides of the body while the latter are situated, if they are present at all,<tei:lb/>on the posterior margin of the pronotum close to the lateral angles of the scutellum and project<tei:lb/>posteriorly. Detailed descriptions of the body sculpture, pubescence and colour are usually<tei:lb/>given either under the description of the genus or under the description of one species of each<tei:lb/>genus that typifies the condition of these characters throughout the genus, and only deviations<tei:lb/>from this pattern, if they occur, are given for the other species. In descriptions of sculpture, the<tei:lb/>term 'granule' is applied to projections that are no higher than their width and 'tubercle' applies<tei:lb/>to projections longer than this; on the femora, there is a continuous gradation from granules<tei:lb/>through tubercles to small spines; all of these structures are probably derived from enlarged hair<tei:lb/>bases that, in the case of spines, have either lost the hair completely or have its insertion<tei:lb/>displaced from the apex of the setiferous tubercle.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to the genera of Pseudophloeini found in the Old World tropics</tei:p>

         <tei:p>11 Pronotum (Fig. 12) coarsely granulate-tuberculate, posterolateral spines arising abruptly from</tei:p>
         <tei:p>posterolateral angles HOPLOLOMIA(p. 161)</tei:p>

         <tei:p>RISBECOCORIS Izzard</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Risbecocoris Izzard, 1949: 478-479. Type-species: Risbecocoris tomentosus Izzard, by original designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Body rather elongate, about 2-5-3-0 times as long as broad, strongly depressed. Connexivum moderately<tei:lb/>expanded.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head about as long as pronotum, strongly convex; eyes small, prominent; ocelli dorsally obscured by<tei:lb/>pads of tomentose pubescence; dorsum of head strongly granulate and, at level of base of antennifers, with<tei:lb/>a pair of prominent setiferous tubercles; each antennifer laterally with two or three similar tubercles and a</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>TRIBE PSEUDOPHLOEINI 157</tei:p>
         <tei:p>broad, weakly deflexed and ventrally incurved apical process. Antennal segment I varying in length from<tei:lb/>about four- fifths to almost equal to head width including eyes, with long, outstanding tubercles, cylindrical<tei:lb/>through most of its length but narrowed gradually towards base in proximal one-quarter; segments II and<tei:lb/>III distinctly more slender than I, tuberculate, II shorter than I, III longest of all; IV shortest, slightly<tei:lb/>thicker than II or III, elongate fusiform, specialized sensory area occupying its apical two-thirds. Bucculae<tei:lb/>occupying about one-half of ventral midline of head. Rostrum at rest reaching to posterior margin of<tei:lb/>mesosternum, segments I and II subequal, HI about half as long as I and IV about two-thirds as long as I.<tei:lb/>Posterior half of head with two rows of tubercles flanking rostrum, in line with bucculae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pronotum shallowly declivent, granulate, posterior margin straight, prescutellar spines absent, postero-<tei:lb/>lateral angles weakly elevated, lateral margins almost straight, with five long, laterally directed spines.<tei:lb/>Scutellum about 1-2 times as long as its basal width, almost flat, apex pointed. Mesosternum deeply sulcate<tei:lb/>longitudinally. Metasternum convex with fine, median, longitudinal groove. Metathoracic scent-gland<tei:lb/>peritreme with dorsal ridge modified into a short, spout-like structure, circular in outline and completely<tei:lb/>surrounding orifice (Fig. 4). Corium with costal margin convex, apical margin weakly convex, all veins very<tei:lb/>strongly prominent; membrane of hemelytron with venation reticulate, prominent. Metathoracic wing<tei:lb/>(Fig. 5) with subcosta free in apical two-thirds, antevannal vein absent. Femora and tibiae with rows of<tei:lb/>prominent tubercles or granules; posterior femur without subapical spines but with one or two small<tei:lb/>tubercles in this position and no apical series; base of femur adjacent to trochanter lacking a tubercle.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdominal sternites III-VII with posterolateral angles produced into progressively longer spines,<tei:lb/>lateral margins of sternites and spines bearing prominent granules and tubercles. Abdominal spiracles<tei:lb/>situated very close to lateral margins of sternites, prominent. Male genital capsule (Figs 9-11) broadly<tei:lb/>emarginate posteriorly, emargination filled by apices of parameres. Phallotheca with a ventral sclerite,<tei:lb/>produced dorsolaterally, and two rather broad dorsal longitudinal sclerites. Conjunctive with median<tei:lb/>dorsal and ventral lobes, distal and apical lobes various. Vesica short, not protected by any basal sclerites,<tei:lb/>wings of ejaculatory reservoir complex articulating with broad, distal dorsolateral sclerites. Spermathecal<tei:lb/>duct short, almost straight except for one sharp bend; bulb narrowly lunate. Anus of female directed<tei:lb/>ventrally.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dense, off-white, tomentose pubescence present on head, pronotum, scutellum, clavus, corium,<tei:lb/>connexivum, underside, antennae up to and including base of segment IV and legs up to and including<tei:lb/>bases of tibiae. Erect hairs of body and of first one or two antennal segments very long and curved,<tei:lb/>remaining parts of antennae and other appendages with shorter, straight, erect hairs.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. All species of this genus have a very distinctive appearance (Fig. 2) by virtue of their long, dense<tei:lb/>pubescence and long, lateral pronotal spines. Reticulate venation of the forewing membrane is characteris-<tei:lb/>tic of ground-dwelling Coreidae. The distally free subcosta in the metathoracic wing is unique in the family.<tei:lb/>The features that give the insects of this genus their remarkable appearance have probably arisen in<tei:lb/>response to the demands of what is, for a coreid, an unusually arid habitat.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. All records come from a belt of semi-arid terrain stretching across Africa from Senegal to<tei:lb/>Kenya and thence into the Indian Desert.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to species</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Larger, length of male 7-2 mm or more, of female 7-7 mm or more; antennal segment III about</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1-3 times as long as segment I. (Sudan, Nigeria, Kenya, Chad) numidianus(p. 160)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- Smaller, length of male 7-1 mm or less, of female 7-6 mm or less; antennal segment III between</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 1 and 1-2 times as long as segment 1 2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Posterior femur with low granules on dorsal surface. (Niger) airensis(p. 159)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- Posterior femur with outstanding tubercles on dorsal surf ace 3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 Spines of posterolateral angles of abdominal segments with weak sigmoid curvature, those of</tei:p>
         <tei:p>segment VII apically divergent. (Pakistan) quadrocephalus(p. 161)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- Spines of posterolateral angles of abdominal segments with stronger sigmoid curvature , those of</tei:p>

         <tei:p>- Smaller, length of female 6-4-6-7 mm, male unknown. (India) delhiensis(p. 160)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Risbecocoris tomentosus Izzard</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 5-11)<tei:lb/>Risbecocoris tomentosus Izzard, 1949: 479-480, pi. 7. Holotype cf , SENEGAL (BMNH) [examined].</tei:p>
