      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>158</tei:p>
         <tei:p>W. R. DOLLING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Figs 2-11 Risbecocoris species. 2, 3, numidianus: (2) dorsal view; (3) apical view of conjunctiva and<tei:lb/>vesica. 4, quadrocephalus , left metapleuron and surrounding area, showing scent-gland peritreme. 5-11,<tei:lb/>tomentosus: (5) metathoracicwing; (6) dorsal view of conjunctiva and vesica; (7) apical view of same; (8)<tei:lb/>ventral view of same; (9) posterior view of male genital capsule with parameres; (10) dorsal view of<tei:lb/>same; (11) lateral view of same.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>TRIBE PSEUDOPHLOEINI 159</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length: &lt;D", 6-7-7-1 mm; $,7-1-7-6 mm.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head quadrate, its dorsal spine-like tubercle shorter than diameter of eye; tubercles on lateral margin of<tei:lb/>antennifer about 4 in number, conspicuous, 2-4 times as long as wide. Antenna with first segment about<tei:lb/>0-95 times as long as width of head including eyes; ratio of lengths of segments about 1-00:0-93: 1-11:0-56.<tei:lb/>Tubercles of segment I about twice as long as wide, those of segment II about 1-5 times as long as wide.<tei:lb/>Ratio of lengths of rostral segments about l-00:0-90:0-43:0-67. Apex of corium at rest reaching to basal<tei:lb/>quarter or basal third of laterotergite VI. Width across hemelytra at rest about 0-72 times abdominal width<tei:lb/>(excluding spines and tubercles) in male, 0-77 times in female; abdominal width about 0-38 times total body<tei:lb/>length. Posterolateral spines of abdominal sternites with strong sigmoid curvature, those of segment VII<tei:lb/>apically slightly convergent. Tubercles on margins of abdominal sternites 1-50-2-25 times as long as wide,<tei:lb/>absent from segments I-IV, absent or single on segment V, one or two (rarely absent) on segment VI, one<tei:lb/>or two on segment VII. All femora dorsally with two rows of short tubercles.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Conjunctiva (Figs 6-8) with low, M-shaped dorsomedian lobe; large, membranous, paired distal<tei:lb/>dorsolateral lobes; globose, membranous apical dorsal lobes, small, membranous, digitiform apical<tei:lb/>ventral lobes, globose, membranous distal ventrolateral lobes and a small, median, apically bifid<tei:lb/>ventromedian lobe. Distal ventrolateral lobes each supported by a slender sclerite along its distal wall, this<tei:lb/>sclerite projecting anteriad as a narrowly triangular appendage, probably representing the totally<tei:lb/>sclerotized mesal lobe of the bilobed distal ventrolateral lobe. Distal dorsolateral lobes each with a strong,<tei:lb/>heavily sclerotized appendage arising near its base, adjacent to the apex of the respective wing of the<tei:lb/>ejaculatory reservoir complex, these sclerotized appendages not expanded apically.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Overall coloration appearing pale grey-brown to the naked eye. Colour of integument mid-brown;<tei:lb/>corium between veins, tibiae except for basal and apical annuli and spines of head yellow; lateral spines of<tei:lb/>pronotum yellow with apices black; apices of abdominal spines black. Forewing membrane slightly milky<tei:lb/>hyaline, veins white with occasional brown markings.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species differs from R. numidianus in its smaller body size and less elongated antennal<tei:lb/>segments III and IV, as well as in the form of the sclerotized distal appendages of the conjunctiva; the other<tei:lb/>known African species, R. airensis, has the tubercles of the femora reduced to granules only about as high<tei:lb/>as wide on the anterior two pairs of legs and obsolete on the posterior pair, whereas in tomentosus these<tei:lb/>tubercles are distinctly longer than wide.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Known only from the type-locality in Senegal.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Senegal: 1 C? (holotype), Bambey, 26.ix.1942 (/. Risbec) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Senegal: 5 C?, 7 $ (paratypes), Bambey, 26.ix.1942 [Izzard, 1949, gives dates as ix.1940, 26.xi.1943 and<tei:lb/>1946.] (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Risbecocoris airensis Villiers<tei:lb/>Risbecocoris airensis Villiers, 1950a: 323-324. Holotype $ , NIGER (MNHN) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length: cf, unknown; 9 , 7-2 mm.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Very similar to R. tomentosus. First antennal segment as long as head. Ratio of lengths of antennal<tei:lb/>segments as 1-00:0-96: 1-18:0-68. Tubercles on lateral margin of antennifer short, hidden among the<tei:lb/>pubescence. Dorsal spine-like tubercle of head much shorter than diameter of eye. Lateral spines of<tei:lb/>holotype all with apices broken (not short as stated in original description). Anterior and intermediate<tei:lb/>femora with two dorsal rows of hispid granules about as high as wide; posterior femora with granules<tei:lb/>obsolete. Apex of corium at rest just reaching base of laterotergite VI. Lateral margins of abdominal<tei:lb/>sternites I-V without long tubercles, VI with a tubercle on one side only, VII with a tubercle on both sides.<tei:lb/>Width of abdomen (excluding spines) 0-38 times body length; width across closed hemelytra 0-82 times<tei:lb/>abdominal width.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species can be distinguished from others of the genus by the obsolete granulation of the<tei:lb/>posterior femora. The male is unknown; the holotype, stated to be of this sex in the original description, is<tei:lb/>in fact a female and it remains the only known specimen.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Air Mountains.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED<tei:lb/>Niger: 1 $ (holotype), Air Sud, Agadez, 525 m, l-5.viii.1947 (A. Villiers &amp; L. Chopard) (MNHN).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>160 W. R. DOLLING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Risbecocorisnumidianussp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 2, 3)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length: cf, 7-2-8-0 mm; $,7-7-8-3 mm.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head quadrate, dorsal spine-like tubercles longer than diameter of eye; antennifers laterally with 4-6<tei:lb/>conspicuous tubercles up to 5 times as long as wide. Antennae with segment I 0-89-0-95 times as long as<tei:lb/>width of head including eyes; ratio of lengths of segments about 1-00:0-90: 1-34:0-72. Tubercles of antennal<tei:lb/>segment I twice as long as wide or more, those of II up to twice as long as wide, those of III and base of IV<tei:lb/>about as long as wide. Ratio of lengths of rostral segments about l-00:0-90:0-43:0-52.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>All femora dorsally with two rows of tubercles about 2-5 times as long as wide, tubercles of tibiae about<tei:lb/>1-5 times as long as wide. Apex of corium at rest reaching one-third or one-half of the way along<tei:lb/>laterotergite VI. Spines of posterolateral angles of abdominal segments with weak sigmoid curvature,<tei:lb/>apices of spines of segment VII weakly divergent. Numbers of tubercles present on lateral margins of<tei:lb/>abdominal sternites (excluding those on the spines themselves) varying from none to three on segments III<tei:lb/>and IV, one to three on V and VI and three to five on VII.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Conjunctiva (Fig. 3) differing from that of tomentosus in that apical dorsal and apical ventral lobes are<tei:lb/>absent and sclerotized appendages of distal dorsolateral lobes are broadly expanded apically.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Overall coloration dark grey-brown; integument generally dark brown; forewing membrane milky<tei:lb/>hyaline, its veins white with some brown streaks; tibiae, except for basal and apical annuli, yellow-brown;<tei:lb/>corium and clavus between veins pale brown; tubercles of head, abdomen and appendages pale brown;<tei:lb/>lateral spines of pronotum and abdomen pale brown, black-tipped; antennal segment IV very dark<tei:lb/>red-brown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This is the largest species of the genus. It differs from all its relatives in the proportionately<tei:lb/>longer antennal segments III and IV and in the apically expanded distal sclerotized appendages of the<tei:lb/>conjunctiva; a distinctive species in an otherwise structurally rather uniform genus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Widespread in the eastern Sahel.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , Sudan: Umm Berembeita [H51' N, 3040' E; spelt Umberumbeita on label], on ground,<tei:lb/>22.iii.1931 (F. G. S. Whitehead) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. Sudan: 1 $, Upper Nile Province, Steamer Falweil, swamps, 21.x. 1933 (A. D. Sherati)<tei:lb/>(BMNH); 2 $, U.N.P., Renk-Malakal, 2-^.i.l963 (R. Linnavuori) (BMNH and R. Linnavuori coll.); 1<tei:lb/>Cf , 1 $, U.N.P., nearMalakal, 5-20.U963 (R. Linnavuori); 1 cf , Blue Nile, IngessanaMts, 17-22. id. 1962<tei:lb/>(R. Linnavuori); 1 cf, Blue Nile, Umm Banein, 14. xi. 1962 (R. Linnavuori) (all R. Linnavuori coll.).<tei:lb/>Chad: 1 cf , Bas-Chari, near Fort-Lamy, Farcha, Forest, 8.viii.l963 (J. Pericart); 1 cf , Bas-Chari, near<tei:lb/>Douggia, 13.viii.1963 (/. Pericart) (both R. Linnavuori coll.). Nigeria: 1 $, NW. State, Badeggi RRS,<tei:lb/>19.iii.1972 (/. T. Medler) (University of Ibadan). Kenya: 1 &lt;j&gt;, Northern Frontier District, Wajeir,<tei:lb/>24.U955, at light (/. Lansbury) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Risbecocoris delhiensis (Bose) comb. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hoplolomia delhiensis Bose, 1946: 75-76. Holotype (sex unknown), INDIA: Delhi, ix.1937, at light (Kerr)<tei:lb/>(Institute of Agricultural Research, New Delhi) [not examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length: cf , unknown; $ , 6-4-6-7 mm.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Very similar to R. tomentosus. Dorsal spine of head much shorter than diameter of eye; antennifers<tei:lb/>bearing four tubercles up to 3 times as long as wide on their lateral margins. Head slightly wider than long.<tei:lb/>First segment of antennae distinctly shorter than head, about 0-85 times as long as head width including<tei:lb/>eyes; ratio of lengths of antennal segments about 1-00:0-85:1-14:0-71. Tubercles of antennal segment I at<tei:lb/>most twice as long as wide, of segment II about 1-5 times as long as wide, of segment III about as long as<tei:lb/>wide. Ratio of lengths of rostral segments about 1-00:0-87:0-54:0-71. Femora with two dorsal rows of<tei:lb/>tubercles about 1-5 times as long as wide, tibiae with granules about as high as wide. Abdominal sternites<tei:lb/>with posterolateral spines stout and with rather strong sigmoid curvature, those of segment VII slightly<tei:lb/>convergent. Abdominal margins between the spines (which themselves bear tubercles) with tubercles up to<tei:lb/>3 times as long as wide, borne singly on segments V-VII. Male unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. In the original description, the body length is given as 7 mm. This species is the smallest of the<tei:lb/>genus. The holotype, said to be in the Agricultural Research Institute at New Delhi, was not available for<tei:lb/>study; the paratype, allegedly deposited in the BMNH, was not found.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>TRIBE PSEUDOPHLOEINI 161</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Eastern fringes of the Indian Desert.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED<tei:lb/>India: 2 $, Rajasthan, Pilani, ix.1965 (5. C. Goel) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Risbecocoris quadrocephalus Ahmad &amp; Shadab<tei:lb/>(Fig. 4)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Risbecocoris quadrocephalus Ahmad &amp; Shadab, 1969: 151-155. Holotype $, PAKISTAN: Karachi, Malir,<tei:lb/>on grass near lucerne field, 7.12.1967 (Fareed Ahmed) (Karachi University Natural History Museum)<tei:lb/>[not examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length: cT, 6-7 mm; $,7-2-7-3 mm.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Similar to R. delhiensis but slightly larger and tubercles of body and appendages slightly longer. Length<tei:lb/>of antennal segment I divided by head width including eyes 0-88-0-92. Ratio of lengths of antennal<tei:lb/>segments I:II:III about 1-00:0-89:1-17; length of segment IV divided by that of segment I 0-66 (type) or<tei:lb/>0-69 in female, 0-77 in male. Posterolateral spines of abdominal sternite VII slightly divergent apically. A<tei:lb/>full description of the female is given in the original description. Conjunctiva of male similar to that of R.<tei:lb/>tomentosus in all respects except that the membranous lobe of the distal ventrolateral lobes is smaller and<tei:lb/>the ventromedian lobe is somewhat larger.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The differences between the Asian species of Risbecocoris are very slight. Substantially more<tei:lb/>material would be required for a definitive treatment of these forms. The orientation of the spines of<tei:lb/>abdominal sternite VII can be seen in the figures given in the original descriptions of delhiensis and<tei:lb/>quadrocephalus and may be reliable characters for distinguishing these two species. The two described<tei:lb/>Asian species are structurally very similar to tomentosus and the Arabian specimen mentioned below.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Southern Pakistan.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pakistan: 1 d", 1 $, Sind, Mainiforest, grass, 7.xi.l975 (Ali Khan) [determined as quadrocephalus by<tei:lb/>Ahmad and Khan] (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Risbecocoris sp.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A single damaged specimen is mentioned here because of its biogeographical interest. It is a male from the<tei:lb/>island of Kamaran in the People's Democratic Republic of the Yemen ('South Yemen'), collected by G. C.<tei:lb/>Champion and deposited in the BMNH. It is 6-5 mm long; the length of its first antennal segment is 0-90<tei:lb/>times the width of the head including the eyes and the second antennal segment is 0-87 times as long as the<tei:lb/>first; the remaining antennal segments are missing. Structurally, it is identical in almost every detail to R.<tei:lb/>tomentosus, including the detailed structure of the conjunctiva. The only differences apparent are the more<tei:lb/>slender vesica, the slightly smaller size and the slightly paler colour. The presence of a tomentosus-like form<tei:lb/>on an island near the Arabian shore of the Red Sea suggests that similar forms were and perhaps still are<tei:lb/>present throughout the northern edge of the Afrotropical Region and it forms a link between the<tei:lb/>Senegalese and Indo-Pakistan species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOPLOLOMIA Stal<tei:lb/>Hoplolomia Stal, 1873: 82, 84. Type-species: Hoplolomia scabricula Stal, by monotypy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Body oblong, slightly depressed, connexivum greatly expanded, insect strongly spinose-tuberculate and<tei:lb/>hispid.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head slightly longer than pronotum, tuberculate; eyes rather small. Antennifers strongly divergent,<tei:lb/>their outer apical processes directed obliquely forwards and downwards, slightly curved inwards apically.<tei:lb/>Antennal segment I clavate, tuberculate; segment III the longest, IV shortest, fusiform, specialized<tei:lb/>sensory area of IV occupying three-quarters of its length. Bucculae rather short, occupying somewhat less<tei:lb/>than one-third of ventral midline of head. Rostrum at rest reaching disc of metasternum; segments I and II<tei:lb/>subequal, IV shorter, III very short.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pronotum (Fig. 12) moderately or weakly declivent, tuberculate; posterolateral angles somewhat<tei:lb/>produced, bearing spines; posterior margin almost straight, prescutellar spines absent. Scutellum<tei:lb/>equilateral, flat or weakly convex, apex slightly raised. Dorsal ridge of metathoracic peritreme reniform,<tei:lb/>prominent. Meso- and metasternum shallowly sulcate. Corium with costal margin shallowly concave,</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>162 W. R. DOLLING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>apical margin straight, apex not produced. Metathoracic wing (Fig. 17) without antevannal vein. Femora<tei:lb/>and tibiae strongly granulate to tuberculate; posterior femur with small basal tubercle, distally (Fig. 14)<tei:lb/>with two major spines and an apical series of three or four.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdominal sternites with lateral margins tuberculate, posterolateral angles spinously produced (Fig.<tei:lb/>13). Male genital capsule posteriorly emarginate, emargination filled by apices of parameres. Conjunctiva<tei:lb/>(Figs 15, 16) with ventral lobes denticulate. Spermatheca with bulb narrowly lunate, duct about twice as<tei:lb/>long as bulb, simply looped.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This small genus is characterized by the presence of a basal tubercle on the posterior femur in<tei:lb/>conjunction with the absence of an antevannal vein in the metathoracic wing and the strongly tuberculate<tei:lb/>and hispid body. Hoplolomia delhiensis Bose is transferred to Risbecocoris (p. 160).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Oriental region.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to species</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Scutellum flat. (India) campbelli(p. 163)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scutellum distinctly convex. (South East Asia) scabricula(p. 162)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hoplolomia scabricula Stal</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 12-14)<tei:lb/>Hoplolomia scabricula Stal, 1873: 84. Holotype $, 'INDIA' (NR) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length: cf, $,6-4 mm.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length of antennal segment I about 0-93 times as long as width of head including eyes ; ratio of lengths of<tei:lb/>antennal segments about l-00:0-81:l-20:0-62 (female). Ratio of lengths of rostral segments about<tei:lb/>l-00:0-96:0-38:0-67.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pronotum (Fig. 12) moderately declivent, spines of posterolateral angles directed laterad and slightly<tei:lb/>anteriad, width across apices of spines divided by width of head including eyes 2-17-2-54. Scutellum weakly<tei:lb/>but distinctly convex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Conjunctiva with dorsomedian lobe deeply cleft, appearing almost as a pair of membranous dorsolateral<tei:lb/>lobes; distal dorsomedian lobe small, conical, membranous; distal dorsolateral lobes rather globular, each<tei:lb/>with a finger-like, membranous lobe arising at junction with dorsomedian lobe and a short, curved,<tei:lb/>sclerotized appendage arising opposite apex of wing of ejaculatory reservoir apparatus and curving<tei:lb/>downwards; apical ventral lobes membranous, globular; distal ventrolateral lobes each divided into a<tei:lb/>slender, finger-like, membranous lobe adjacent to apical ventral lobe, a large, spreading membranous lobe<tei:lb/>and two small, membranous but minutely denticulate ventral lobes. Sclerotized parts of conjunctiva<tei:lb/>consisting of these denticles, appendages of distal dorsolateral lobes and cup-like sclerite protecting base of<tei:lb/>vesica. Vesica moderately long, its apex obliquely truncate. Ejaculatory reservoir apparatus with wings but<tei:lb/>without straps.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head granulate, dorsally with some stout tubercles; antennae granulate, segment I also tuberculate.<tei:lb/>Pronotum punctate, granulate and tuberculate with a pair of large, somewhat irregular, whitish tubercules<tei:lb/>near midline between posterolateral angles. Scutellum granulate-punctate, margins tuberculate. Thoracic<tei:lb/>pleura granulate-punctate. Clavus and corium granulate and deeply punctate, costal margin of corium in<tei:lb/>basal half tuberculate. Femora and tibiae granulate and tuberculate. Connexivum granulate-punctate.<tei:lb/>Abdominal sterna granulate, lateral margins tuberculate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pubescence of body and appendages of moderate length, semidecumbent, with longer, suberect or erect<tei:lb/>hairs arising from larger tubercles of appendages and dorsal surface of body, hairs arising from the<tei:lb/>tubercles of head and pronotum particularly long and erect.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour rufous brown. Anterior midline of pronotum, margins of clavi adjacent to scutellum, distal veins<tei:lb/>of corium, abdominal spines, large areas of laterotergites IV and V and anterior and posterior margins of<tei:lb/>VI and VII and apical two-thirds of posterior femora conspicuously darker. Bases of femora, first segment<tei:lb/>of each tarsus, tibiae except for basal and apical annuli, most of clavus and basal half of corium and spots on<tei:lb/>darker parts of femora stramineous. Hemelytral membrane fuscous hyaline, some groups of somewhat<tei:lb/>reticulate veins dirty white, veins of anal angle conspicuously white, the membrane surrounding them not<tei:lb/>infuscate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The type-locality is cited only as 'India Orientalis'; it is assumed here that it was in South East<tei:lb/>Asia rather than in the Indian subcontinent on the basis of the distribution of the other material seen.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>TRIBE PSEUDOPHLOEINI 163</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. South East Asia. Hsiao (1964: 252) records this species from Yunnan, China.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>South East Asia 'India orientalis': 1 $ (holotype) (Stevens) (NR).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Burma: 1 cf , Bhamo, viii. 1885 (Fea, ex Distant coll.) (BMNH). Vietnam: 1 $ , Dalat, 6 km S. , 1400-1500<tei:lb/>m,9.vi.!961 (N. R. Spencer) (BPBM). Laos: 1 cf, 1 $, WapikhamthongProv.,KhongSedone, 18.ix.1965<tei:lb/>(native collector) and 3. viii. 1965 (Rondon) (BPBM).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hoplolomia campbellisp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 15-17)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length: cf, 5-7-5-8 mm; $,6-7 mm.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Very similar to H. scabricula in size, form and colouring, including in the structure of the conjunctiva<tei:lb/>(Figs 15, 16) but body slightly more depressed and slightly narrower. Length of antennal segment I divided<tei:lb/>by width of head including eyes 85-0 93 ; ratio of lengths of antennal segments about 1 -00 : 83 : 1 22 : 72 .<tei:lb/>Pronotum shallowly declivent, width across apices of posterolateral spines divided by width of head<tei:lb/>including eyes 2-03-2-11. Scutellum flat.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Very similar to H. scabricula, this species is distinguished from it by the slightly more<tei:lb/>dorsoventrally flattened body, this difference being most apparent in the shallower slope of the pronotal<tei:lb/>disc and the flat, not convex, scutellum.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Southern India.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , India: Chikaballapura, iii.1915 (T. V. Campbell) (BMNH).<tei:lb/>Paratypes. India: 1 cf, Chikaballapura (Campbell), ii.1918; 1 $, Chikaballapura ll.i.1918 (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>i</tei:p>
         <tei:p>INDOLOMIA gen. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Type-species: Indolomia conculata sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Body robust, connexivum widely expanded.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head slightly longer than pronotum, with uniform, low granulation. Antennifers weakly divergent,<tei:lb/>outer apical processes triangular, apically curved inwards. Antennal segment I weakly clavate, slightly but<tei:lb/>distinctly shorter than head; segment III slightly shorter than I, II slightly shorter than III, IV shortest.<tei:lb/>Bucculae short, occupying only one-quarter of length of ventral midline of head. Rostrum with segment I<tei:lb/>reaching posteriorly almost to level of posterior margin of eye; segment II slightly shorter than I, III half as<tei:lb/>long as II, IV two-thirds as long as II.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pronotum strongly declivent, its posterolateral angles strongly produced anterolaterally, posterolateral<tei:lb/>margin straight, without prescutellar spines; mostly rather weakly and uniformly granulate, with a pair of<tei:lb/>short, oblique ridges near midline between posterolateral angles, anterior and anterolateral margins and<tei:lb/>anterior half of midline with some larger and more prominent granules. Scutellum equilateral, convex, its<tei:lb/>apex slightly produced and swollen. Meso- and metasternum strongly sulcate longitudinally. Dorsal ridge<tei:lb/>of metathoracic peritreme shortly reniform. Corium with costal margin weakly concave and apical margin<tei:lb/>weakly convex, apex not produced. Metathoracic wing without antevannal vein. Anterior and intermedi-<tei:lb/>ate femora each with a small subapical spine beneath; posterior femur with two or three major subapical<tei:lb/>spines and an apical series of tubercles and with a prominent basal tubercle. Posterior coxae separated by a<tei:lb/>space equal to about two-thirds of the width of a coxa.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdominal sterna HI- VII with posterolateral angles triangularly produced, lateral margins with very<tei:lb/>obsolete granulation. Male genital capsule posteriorly emarginate, emargination filled by apices of<tei:lb/>parameres. Phallotheca with a broad ventral sclerite, produced laterally, and two thin, longitudinal dorsal<tei:lb/>sclerites. Phallotheca, conjunctiva and vesica subequal in length. Conjunctiva with sclerotized, ventrally<tei:lb/>directed distal dorsolateral appendages and a pair of sclerites protecting coiled base of vesica, otherwise<tei:lb/>completely membranous; dorsomedian lobe low, distal dorsomedian lobe conical, apical ventral lobes<tei:lb/>paired, weakly developed, distal ventrolateral lobes trilobed. Ejaculatory reservoir complex with wings<tei:lb/>well developed, straps absent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This genus resembles Hoplolomia in that it lacks an antevannal vein in the metathoracic wing<tei:lb/>and has a basal tubercle on the hind femur. Because of the shape of the pronotum, the short pubescence<tei:lb/>and the absence of prominent tubercles from most of the body surface and appendages, it superficially</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>164</tei:p>
         <tei:p>W. R. DOLLING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>18</tei:p>
         <tei:p>19</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Figs 12-19 12-14, Hoplolomia scabricula: (12) dorsal view of pronotum; (13) ventral view of abdominal<tei:lb/>margin; (14) dorsal view of apical half of posterior femur. 15-17, H. campbelli: (15) dorsal view of<tei:lb/>conjunctiva and vesica; (16) ventral view of same; (17) metathoracic wing. 18, 19, Indolomia conculata:<tei:lb/>(18) dorsal view of pronotum; (19) ventral view of abdominal margin.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>resembles some My la species but the differences in the form of the male genitalia show that the two genera<tei:lb/>are not closely releated.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. A single species, in southern India.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Indolomia conculata sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 18, 19)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length: d", 7-8 mm; $ unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head as long as its width including eyes. Length of antennal segment I divided by head width including<tei:lb/>eyes 0-89. Ratio of lengths of antennal segments as l-00:0-89:0-94:0-83. Specialized sensory setae</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>TRIBE PSEUDOPHLOEINI 165</tei:p>
         <tei:p>occupying about nine-tenths of length of segment IV. Antennae without prominent granules or tubercles.<tei:lb/>Rostral segment 1 0-66 times as long as width of head including eyes; ratio of lengths of rostral segments as<tei:lb/>l-00:0-89:045:0-64.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pr.onotum (Fig. 18) with posterolateral angles terminating in short spines; width across apices of spines<tei:lb/>2-43 times width of head including eyes. Legs moderately long, posterior tibia 0-96 times as long as<tei:lb/>posterior femur. Left femur of holotype with three major spines, the second half as long as the third and<tei:lb/>twice as long as the first, right femur with only two major spines, similar to second and third of left femur;<tei:lb/>an apical series of three spines present on both femora, one tubercle and two granules present between last<tei:lb/>and penultimate spines, a few granules present on rest of apical half of ventral surface of both femora.<tei:lb/>Scutellum, clavus and corium strongly punctate and weakly granulate throughout. Abdominal sterna with<tei:lb/>posterolateral angles triangularly produced but not drawn out into spines (Fig. 19). Pubescence of body,<tei:lb/>antennal segment I and most of femora short, semidecumbent; that of rest of antennae, of tibiae and tarsi<tei:lb/>and parts of femora short or rather short , suberect ; front of head and some large granules of pronotum with<tei:lb/>a few longer, erect hairs.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour various shades of brown. Head with midline and a U-shaped stripe adjacent to eyes and<tei:lb/>interrupted by ocelli conspicuously paler. Pronotum with midline and posterior disc conspicuously darker,<tei:lb/>the two oblique ridges of posterior disc conspicuously paler. Femora piceous with stramineous spots.<tei:lb/>Tibiae stramineous with basal and apical annuli piceous. Tarsi piceous, first segment dorsally stramineous.<tei:lb/>Connexivum banded pale and dark brown, abdominal dorsum rufous brown, anteriorly and anterolateral-<tei:lb/>ly piceous. Thoracic sterna piceous. Abdominal sterna mottled pale brown and piceous, piceous markings<tei:lb/>tending to form five longitudinal stripes. Hemelytral membrane fuscous hyaline; veins darker brown,<tei:lb/>interrupted by milky spots; anal angle of membrane, including veins, milky.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Only the holotype, which is complete but slightly crushed, is known.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED<tei:lb/>Holotype cf , India: Anaimalai Hills, Cinchuna, 3500 ft [1067 m], v.1976 (T. Nathan) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>PARAM YLA Linnavuori stat. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Myla (Paramyla) Linnavuori, 1971: 177-178. Type-species: Myla suspecta Schouteden, by original<tei:lb/>designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Body depressed, narrowly ovate, not conspicuously tuberculate or hispid, connexivum moderately<tei:lb/>expanded.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head slightly shorter than pronotum, slightly longer than antennal segment I, dorsally granulate with<tei:lb/>two conspicuous, smooth, non-granulate lines arising between ocelli and diverging anteriorly, reaching<tei:lb/>half-way to antennifers, and a shorter, smooth line along outer margin of each ocellus. Antennifers<tei:lb/>divergent, outer apical processes of antennifers short, porrect. Antennal segment I longest, weakly but<tei:lb/>rather abruptly clavate, II shortest, III next shortest; I-III densely granulate, granules of I larger; IV with<tei:lb/>specialized sensory area occupying between two-thirds and four-fifths of its length. Bucculae occupying<tei:lb/>about one-quarter of ventral midline of head. Rostrum with segment I distinctly longest, II longer than IV,<tei:lb/>III shortest, apex of rostrum at rest reaching to disc of mesosternum.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pronotum shallowly declivent, posterolateral angles scarcely prominent, bearing a short, triangular<tei:lb/>tooth, lateral margins granulate, disc granulate to tuberculate, posterior margin weakly convex, prescutel-<tei:lb/>lar spines well developed. Scutellum flat, equilateral, apex slightly or strongly elevated. Mesosternum<tei:lb/>sulcate, metasternum convex with slight longitudinal groove in anterior one- third. Dorsal ridge of<tei:lb/>metathoracic peritreme reniform. Metathoracic wing without antevannal vein. All femora granulate,<tei:lb/>anterior two pairs with or without a subapical spine beneath, posterior femur with a moderately<tei:lb/>well-developed basal tubercle and with two or three major subapical spines with only granules between<tei:lb/>them and an apical series of two to four tubercles. Posterior tibiae more than 0-90 times length of posterior<tei:lb/>femora.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdominal sternites with their posterolateral angles not produced, their densely granulate lateral<tei:lb/>margins forming a single, smooth curve. Genital capsule (Fig. 21) short, posteriorly emarginate, emargina-<tei:lb/>tion filled by apices of parameres (Fig. 22).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Members of this genus are readily recognized among tropical Pseudophloeinae by their strongly<tei:lb/>depressed and largely non-tuberculate body. They have more the appearance of some Palaearctic genera,<tei:lb/>but differ from these in the absence of an antevannal vein in the metathoracic wing. Linnavuori (1971)<tei:lb/>included Myla niokoensis Schouteden in his new subgenus Paramyla but the male genitalia of niokoensis<tei:lb/>are typical of the genus Myla and the resemblances between niokoensis and suspecta are confined to the</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>W. R. DOLLING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Figs 20-26 Paramyla species. 20, australis, dorsal view of body with hemelytra at rest and posterior femur<tei:lb/>and tibia. 21-26, suspecta: (21) posterior view of male genital capsule with parameres; (22) dorsomedial<tei:lb/>view of left paramere; (23) lateral view of phallotheca, conjunctiva and vesica; (24) ventral view of same;<tei:lb/>(25) dorsal view of head and pronotum; (26) dorsal view of posterior femur.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>superficial characters of a lack of abdominal spines, very short pronotal spines and very short pubescence.<tei:lb/>DISTRIBUTION. Mountainous regions of central Africa and South Africa.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to species</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Pronotum with prescutellar spines broad, triangular; hairs of pubescence longer than distance</tei:p>
         <tei:p>between adjacent hair insertions. (Mountains of central Africa) suspecta (p. 166)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pronotum with prescutellar spines slender; hairs of pubescence shorter than distance between<tei:lb/>adjacent insertions. (South Africa) australis(p. 167)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paramyla suspecta (Schouteden) comb. n.<tei:lb/>(Figs 21-26)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Myla suspecta Schouteden, 1938: 294. Holotype cf , ZAIRE (MRAC) [examined].<tei:lb/>Myla (Paramyla) suspecta (Schouteden); Linnavuori, 1971: 177-178.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length: cf, 7-4-7-6 mm; $,7-7-8-0 mm.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Antennal segment I with two different sizes of granulation, its length approximately equal (0-89-1-01<tei:lb/>times) to width of head including eyes; ratio of lengths of antennal segments about l-00:0-67:0-81:0-85;</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>TRIBE PSEUDOPHLOEINI 167</tei:p>
         <tei:p>specialized sensory area of segment IV occupying about four-fifths of its length. Ratio of lengths of rostral<tei:lb/>segments about 1-00:0-80:0-45:0-70.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pronotum (Fig. 25) with disc granulate; lateral margins shallowly concave; posterolateral angles scarcely<tei:lb/>elevated above general level of posterior disc, width across apices of blunt posterolateral spines 1-73-1-82<tei:lb/>times width of head including eyes; prescutellar angles with triangular spines. Scutellum with apex slightly<tei:lb/>elevated. Anterior and intermediate femora without subapical spines or tubercles, posterior femur (Fig.<tei:lb/>26) with two major spines, the proximal one about half as long as the other, with only granules between<tei:lb/>them, and an apical series of two or three tubercles. Corium with costal margin markedly convex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male with phallotheca short, consisting of a single ventral sclerite extending laterally almost to meet two<tei:lb/>rather less well-sclerotized dorsal sclerites. Conjunctiva (Figs 23, 24) with dorsomedian lobe large, its<tei:lb/>lateral angles prominent, distal dorsomedian lobe low, scarcely developed, distal dorsolateral lobes<tei:lb/>finger-like, wholly membranous and without sclerotized appendages, apical ventral lobes absent, distal<tei:lb/>ventrolateral lobes each divided into three: a dorsal, wholly membranous part, a ventral, largely<tei:lb/>sclerotized part, denticulate along its anterior edge, and a narrow, denticulate lobe situated anterior and<tei:lb/>medial to the two larger parts. Vesica stout, rather long, protected at base by a pair of sclerites. Ejaculatory<tei:lb/>reservoir complex with wings long, L-shaped, straps absent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head granulate throughout, granules larger along midline of tylus, gular region punctate. Antennal<tei:lb/>segment I with small, densely packed granules and some larger, outstanding granules, segments II-III with<tei:lb/>very small granules. Pronotal disc punctate, with scattered granules, anterior half with some larger<tei:lb/>granules or low tubercles, lateral margins with larger granules; scutellum weakly granulate-punctate;<tei:lb/>thoracic sterna and pleura punctate; femora and tibiae minutely granulate. Clavus and corium punctate<tei:lb/>throughout, punctures of clavus larger, of apex of corium smaller than average size of those on disc of<tei:lb/>corium, veins of clavus and corium granulate. Abdominal sternites and laterotergites minutely granulate,<tei:lb/>laterotergites also minutely punctate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Insect clothed in short, semidecumbent pubescence, the hairs longer than the distances between their<tei:lb/>insertions; tubercles and larger granules of head and pronotum with longer, erect hairs.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour largely mid-brown. Membrane of hemelytra infuscate between veins, veins brown, with short,<tei:lb/>paler interruptions. Antennal segment IV, femora, especially posterior pair, and mesosternum dark brown<tei:lb/>to black; tibiae, except for basal and apical annuli, paler brown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species seems to be one of the tropical Pseudophloeinae most highly adapted for life on the<tei:lb/>ground. The unusual form of the conjunctiva, lacking apical ventral lobes and sclerotized appendages to<tei:lb/>the distal dorsolateral lobes and with very strongly developed distal ventrolateral lobes, is presumably<tei:lb/>characteristic for the genus, and sets it somewhat apart from other genera.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Highlands of central Africa.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Zaire: 1 cf (holotype), Ituri, Nioka, vii.1934 (/. V. Leroy) (MRAC).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Zaire: 4 cf, 4 $, data as holotype except that one male and two females have fuller date: 7. vii.1934<tei:lb/>(probably all paratypes); 1 cf, Ituri, de Buba a Petro (Nizi), 23.iii.1929 (A. Collarf) (paratype); 1 $,<tei:lb/>Kibali-Ituri, Nioka, xii.1952 (J. Hecq) (MRAC). Malawi: 1 cf , Masuku Mts, 6000-7000 ft [1800-2100 m],<tei:lb/>vii.l896(A Whyte) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paramyla australis sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 20)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length: cf , unknown; $,7-5 mm.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Antennae with segment I proportionately longer and segment IV much shorter than in P. suspecta, ratio<tei:lb/>of lengths of segments as l-00:0-71:0-87:0-65; granulation of segment I uniform, segment IV with junction<tei:lb/>of specialized sensory area and area of normal pubescence oblique, specialized area occupying between<tei:lb/>three-quarters and two-thirds of its length. Body form (Fig. 20) slightly narrower than that of suspecta;<tei:lb/>width of pronotum (Fig. 20) across apices of the blunt, triangular posterolateral spines 1-72 times width of<tei:lb/>head including eyes; prescutellar spines slender; posterolateral angles rather strongly elevated above level<tei:lb/>of posterior disc; lateral margins strongly concave. Scutellum with apex strongly raised. Corium with costal<tei:lb/>margin only weakly convex. Intermediate femur with a small subapical spine beneath; posterior femur<tei:lb/>(Fig. 20) with three major spines, of which the first is very small and the second about three-quarters the<tei:lb/>length of the last, a single tubercle between these two biggest spines and an apical series of four tubercles.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Sculpture of body, especially pronotum, rather more pronounced than in suspecta; pronotal disc<tei:lb/>tuberculate. Pubescence of body and appendages very short, semidecumbent, white, the hairs distinctly</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>168 W. R. DOLLING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>shorter than the distances between their insertions; tarsi and apices of tibiae with longer, suberect<tei:lb/>pubescence but body without longer, suberect hairs.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species diverges less from the typical body form of the subfamily than does its congener; the<tei:lb/>body is less flattened and there are more femoral spines. In contrast, the pubescence is abnormally short in<tei:lb/>the new species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Known only from the type-locality in South Africa.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype , South Africa: Cape Province, Cape Peninsula, Red Hill, 30.U968 (/. A. &amp; S. Slater, T.<tei:lb/>Schuh, M. H. Sweet) (J. A. Slater collection).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>PSILOLOMIA Breddin</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Psilolomia Breddin, 1909: 292. Type-species: Psilolomia brevitibialis Breddin, by monotypy.<tei:lb/>Neohoplolomia Distant, 1913: 284. Type-species: Neohoplolomia typica Distant, by monotypy. Syn. n.<tei:lb/>Psilocoris Hsiao, 1964: 251, 259. Type-species: Psilocoris clavipes Hsiao, by original designation. Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Body oblong, not depressed, connexivum rather narrowly to moderately expanded, body not conspicu-<tei:lb/>ously spinose, tuberculate or hairy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head about as long as pronotum, dorsally granulate to rather weakly tuberculate. Antennifers<tei:lb/>divergent, their outer apical processes short, broad, porrect. Antennae with segment I very weakly clavate,<tei:lb/>granulate, without conspicuously outstanding granules or tubercules; segments II and III never of<tei:lb/>conspicuously unequal length, minutely granulate. Bucculae occupying about one-quarter of ventral<tei:lb/>midline of head . Rostrum with segment I much the longest , II to IV subequal in length , apex of IV reaching<tei:lb/>to meso-metasternal suture.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pronotum moderately declivent, its posterolateral angles not or rather weakly elevated and not or rather<tei:lb/>weakly produced laterally, posterolateral spines short, blunt or acute and arising abruptly from the angles,<tei:lb/>directed laterally; posterior margin straight, without humeral spines; disc and lateral margins with large<tei:lb/>granules or tubercles. Scutellum flat or weakly convex, equilateral, anterior angles prominent, apex<tei:lb/>elevated as a minute, whitish blob. Mesosternum shallowly sulcate; metasternum almost flat to distinctly<tei:lb/>convex, anteriorly concavely emarginate. Metathoracic peritreme (Fig. 38) with dorsal ridge bilobed, the<tei:lb/>anterior lobe much the larger. Clavus and corium punctate throughout, corium less heavily so apically and<tei:lb/>with apex not produced. Antevannal vein present in metathoracic wing (Fig. 39) but sometimes weak.<tei:lb/>Anterior and intermediate femora with zero to two small subapical spines beneath, posterior femur with<tei:lb/>three major subapical spines, some smaller ones and an apical series; tubercle at base of posterior femur<tei:lb/>small, sometimes obsolete. Posterior coxae not approximated.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdominal sterna III- VII with posterolateral angles not or slightly produced (maximum development in<tei:lb/>P. brunneofusca, Fig. 42). Spermatheca with bulb lunate, duct short, not convoluted. Male genital capsule<tei:lb/>posteriorly emarginate, emargination filled by apices of parameres. Conjunctiva with dorsomedian lobe<tei:lb/>large, distal dorsomedian lobe smaller, both membranous; distal dorsolateral lobes slender, their posterior<tei:lb/>faces supported for much or, usually, all of their length by sclerites continuous with or articulating with<tei:lb/>wings of ejaculatory reservoir, which lacks straps; no sclerites protecting base of vesica; apical ventral lobe<tei:lb/>obsolete or transverse, sometimes weakly bilobed but never divided into two globular lobes; distal<tei:lb/>ventrolateral lobes membranous; ventral wall of conjunctiva with a pair of posteriorly diverging, toothed,<tei:lb/>sclerotized strips, these weakly developed or absent in the smallest three species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pronotum, scutellum and thoracic pleura granulate-punctate, veins of hemelytra with occasional small<tei:lb/>granules, femora, tibiae, abdominal sternites and laterotergites granulate. Pubescence colourless or<tei:lb/>amber, simple, mostly rather short, semidecumbent to suberect, some species with long, erect hairs on<tei:lb/>pronotum and dorsum of head; pubescence never scale-like or tomentose.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This, one of the largest genera of the tribe, lacks any striking distinguishing features. The<tei:lb/>type-species of Psilolomia and Neohoplolomia are synonymized here. P. brevitibialis, the type-species of<tei:lb/>Psilolomia, is unique in that its vesica is about twice as wide as those of the other species examined and the<tei:lb/>distal dorsolateral lobes of the conjunctiva are sclerotized for only about half their length. It shares with<tei:lb/>only P. parva both the absence of ventral, toothed, sclerotized strips from the conjunctiva and the<tei:lb/>possession of an antennal segment II that is shorter than segment III; these are the only two species in<tei:lb/>which some of the dorsal granules of the head are developed into tubercles that are higher than wide. The<tei:lb/>conjunctiva of P. amphrysia, the third small species, has very weakly developed ventral sclerotized strips<tei:lb/>and thus forms a link between the other two and the large species of the genus. These differences do not<tei:lb/>seem of sufficient value to warrant the separation of P. brevitibialis or of P. brevitibialis plus P. parva from</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>TRIBE PSEUDOPHLOEINI</tei:p>
         <tei:p>169</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Figs 27-35 Psilolomia species, outline dorsal view of right half of pronotum of 27, amphrysia; 28,<tei:lb/>nigeriensis; 29, lamottei; 30, brevitibialis; 31,parva; 32, vulgaris; 33, brunneofusca; 34, steeleae; 35, lata.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>the remaining species at the generic level. Linnavuori (1970) placed the two African species known to him<tei:lb/>in Mevaniomorpha, which is undoubtedly close to Psilolomia and might be regarded as a derivative of it<tei:lb/>with more pronounced pronotal and abdominal spines.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Afrotropical and Oriental regions; wholly continental, with no insular records.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Head dorsally granulate. Antennifers distinctly but not strongly divergent. Length of antennal segment I<tei:lb/>divided by width of head including eyes 0-88-1-00.          <tei:p>Pronotum (Fig. 27) with lateral margins slightly concave, bearing small tubercles that are slightly longer<tei:lb/>than wide; posterolateral spines acute, longer than their basal width; width across apices of spines divided<tei:lb/>by width of head including eyes 1-80-2-07. Length of posterior tibia<tei:lb/>about 0-7 times length of posterior femur.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdominal sternites III-VII with posterolateral angles acute, slightly prominent. Conjunctiva with<tei:lb/>distal dorsolateral lobes (Fig. 49) short, sclerotized throughout their length; ventral sclerotized strips<tei:lb/>weakly developed.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pubescence of most of body and of hemelytra short, curved, semidecumbent; that of antennae and legs<tei:lb/>straighter, suberect; head also with some longer, suberect hairs arising from tubercles and larger granules;<tei:lb/>declivent part of pronotum also with pubescence of erect hairs about as long as diameter of an eye.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour sordid yellow, apical half of posterior femur heavily marked piceous; scattered, small piceous<tei:lb/>markings of greater or less extent present elsewhere on body and appendages, especially abdominal<tei:lb/>laterotergites and sternites. Granules of appendages usually piceous.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This is the smallest of the African species and the only one of them with long pronotal<tei:lb/>pubescence (about as long as diameter of an eye); its pronotal posterolateral spines are longer than those of</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>TRIBE PSEUDOPHLOEINI 171</tei:p>
         <tei:p>other African species. It differs from the two small Asian species in having the second antennal segment<tei:lb/>longer than the third, not shorter.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. West Africa and Zambia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Psilolomia nigeriensis sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 28, 57)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length: cf , 7-9-9-3 mm; $,8-7-9-1 mm.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head dorsally granulate. Antennifers distinctly but not very abruptly divergent. Length of antennal<tei:lb/>segment I divided by width of head including eyes 0-86-1-00. Ratio of lengths of antennal segments in<tei:lb/>northern males about l-00:0-89:0-78:0-93; in southern males about l-00:0-93:0-80:0-82; in northern<tei:lb/>females about l-00:0-93:0-82:0-86; in southern females about l-00:0-93:0-82:0-82. Ratio of lengths of<tei:lb/>rostral segments about 1.00:0-57:0-58:0-55.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pronotum (Fig. 28) with lateral margins very shallowly concave, almost straight, bearing small granules;<tei:lb/>posterolateral angles each with a short, triangular spine; width across apices of spines divided by width of<tei:lb/>head including eyes 1-94:2-02. Metasternum rather strongly convex. Anterior and intermediate femora<tei:lb/>each without or with one small, subapical spine beneath; posterior femur with three major spines, rarely<tei:lb/>with a small spine preceding them, three or four minor spines between the penultimate and last major<tei:lb/>spines and an apical series of four or five. Length of posterior tibia divided by length of posterior femur<tei:lb/>0-82-0-92.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdominal sternites III-VII with posterolateral angles acute and slightly prominent. Conjunctiva with<tei:lb/>ventral toothed sclerotized strips well-developed, distal dorsolateral lobes (Fig. 57) sclerotized throughout<tei:lb/>their length but less strongly so apically and ventrally, dorsomedian lobe bearing a narrow, membranous,<tei:lb/>apically bifid, median process; vesica longer than in any other species of the genus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pubescence of most of body and of hemelytra short, curved, semidecumbent; of antennae and legs<tei:lb/>suberect, longer and more erect ventrally on femora; head with uniform, short, semidecumbent pubesc-<tei:lb/>ence; declivent part of pronotum with longer, less curved, suberect pubescence distinctly shorter than<tei:lb/>diameter of eye.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour sordid yellow- ochreous, usually with a slight ferruginous tinge and with piceous markings along<tei:lb/>apical margin of corium, thoracic and abdominal sterna and laterotergites and apical half of posterior<tei:lb/>femur; all tibiae with basal and apical annuli fuscous.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species differs from the other African species in its almost straight lateral pronotal margins.<tei:lb/>It is very similar to the Asian P. vulgaris but lacks suberect pubescence along the midline of the head and<tei:lb/>differs in the shape of the sclerotized distal dorsolateral lobes of the conjunctiva.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. West Africa.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>

         <tei:p>172 W. R. DOLLING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pronotum (Fig. 29) with anterolateral margins concave, granulate; posterolateral angles prominent,<tei:lb/>bearing broadly triangular posterolateral spines; width across apices of spines divided by width of head<tei:lb/>including eyes 2-05 in male, 1-93 in female. Metasternum rather strongly convex. Anterior femur with one,<tei:lb/>minute, subapical spine beneath, intermediate femur with one small spine, posterior femur with three<tei:lb/>major spines (preceded by a small spine in holotype) with three minor spines between the penultimate and<tei:lb/>last major spines and an apical series of four; tubercle at base of posterior femur obsolete. Length of<tei:lb/>posterior tibia divided by length of posterior femur 0-84-0-85.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdominal sternites V and VI with posterolateral angles slightly prominent, slightly more acute than<tei:lb/>right-angled; those of VII angled at about 85, slightly prominent. Vesica long and slender; conjunctiva<tei:lb/>with ventral toothed strips well developed; distal dorsolateral lobes (Fig. 54) sclerotized throughout, not<tei:lb/>apically angled or expanded.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pubescence rather short, suberect to semidecumbent, of uniform length, no erect hairs present even on<tei:lb/>dorsal midline of head.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coloration of holotype from Guinea sordid yellow with slight rufous tinge, antennal segment IV,<tei:lb/>tubercles of all appendages, basal annulus of posterior tibia and, less conspicuously, of other tibiae, meso-<tei:lb/>and metasterna and extensive mottling on abdominal sterna, laterotergites and apical half of posterior<tei:lb/>femur piceous or black. Male from Nigeria generally ferruginous without black or piceous markings except<tei:lb/>for those of abdomen and thoracic sterna.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. There is a close resemblance in structure, though not in colour, between the two specimens<tei:lb/>examined. This species resembles P. ferruginea in having the first antennal segment longer than the width<tei:lb/>of the head across the eyes and in the prominent posterolateral angles of the pronotum, but it is smaller and<tei:lb/>has fewer minor spines on the posterior femur. The two species are evidently closely related.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Uplands of West Africa.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Head dorsally granulate, tuberculate throughout vertex and midline. Antennifers distinctly divergent.<tei:lb/>Length of antennal segment I divided by width of head including eyes 0-78-0-81. Ratio of lengths of<tei:lb/>antennal segments about l-00:0-79:0-96:0-83.          <tei:p>Pronotum (Fig. 30) with lateral margins straight, tuberculate; posterolateral angles not prominent;<tei:lb/>posterolateral spines short, acute; width across apices of spines divided by width of head including eyes<tei:lb/>1-82-1-92. Metasternum moderately convex. Anterior and intermediate femora each without or with one<tei:lb/>small subapical spine beneath; posterior femur with three major spines, the first about half as long as the<tei:lb/>others, one to three minor spines between the two large ones and an apical series of four. Length of<tei:lb/>posterior tibia divided by length of posterior femur about 0-74.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdominal sternites III-VII with posterolateral angles right-angled, not prominent. Male conjunctiva<tei:lb/>(Fig. 44) with apical ventral lobes obsolete and ventral sclerotized strips absent; distal dorsolateral lobes<tei:lb/>(Fig. 50) short, supported by sclerotizations for only about half their length. Vesica unusually broad.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pubescence suberect, short; tubercles of head and pronotum bearing longer, erect hairs shorter than<tei:lb/>three-quarters of the diameter of an eye.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour ochreous yellow, often sprinkled with minute red dots. Granules of antennae, femora and<tei:lb/>sometimes of tibiae piceous; antennal segment IV often piceous; anterior midline of pronotum, apical and<tei:lb/>basal annuli of tibiae, apical halves of posterior femora and more or less extensive markings of<tei:lb/>connexivum, especially posterior halves of laterotergites IV- VI, of pleura, of thoracic and abdominal<tei:lb/>sterna and of corium, especially in two places on the apical margin, piceous.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The short, broad vesica and only partially sclerotized distal dorsolateral conjunctival lobes of<tei:lb/>this species are unique for the genus. The lack of ventral sclerotized conjunctival strips, the small body size<tei:lb/>and the possession of an antennal segment II that is shorter than segment III are all shared with P. parva.<tei:lb/>The two species can be distinguished externally by the form of the posterolateral angles of the abdominal<tei:lb/>sternites, which are acute in parva but right-angled in brevitibialis .</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Psilolomia parva sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 31, 45, 51)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length: cf , 5-4-5-9 mm; $,5-9-6-5 mm.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head dorsally granulate, tuberculate on vertex and in midline. Antennifers distinctly but rather weakly<tei:lb/>divergent. Length of antennal segment I divided by width of head including eyes about 0-86. Ratio of<tei:lb/>lengths of antennal segments about 1-00:0-73:0-89:0-81. Ratio of lengths of rostral segments about<tei:lb/>l-00:0-55:0-55:0-55. Head and pronotum together constituting more than 0-39 (male) or 0-35 (female) of<tei:lb/>total length.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pronotum with lateral margins (Fig. 31) weakly concave, posterolateral angles scarcely prominent;<tei:lb/>posterolateral spines acute, at least 1-5 times as long as their basal width; width of pronotum across apices<tei:lb/>of spines divided by width of head including eyes 1-74-1-83. Metathoracic wing with antevannal vein weak,<tei:lb/>difficult to see. Metasternum rather strongly convex. Anterior and intermediate femora without or with a<tei:lb/>single subapical spine beneath; posterior femur with three major spines, the first about half as long as the<tei:lb/>other two, one to three minor spines between the two large spines and an apical series of four. Length of<tei:lb/>posterior tibia divided by length of posterior femur about 0-72.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdominal sternites III- VII with posterolateral angles acute, slightly but distinctly prominent. Male<tei:lb/>conjunctiva (Fig. 45) without ventral sclerotized strips, distal dorsolateral lobes (Fig. 51) short, supported<tei:lb/>by sclerotization throughout their length; vesica slender.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pubescence short, semidecumbent on hemelytra and most of body, slightly longer and less decumbent<tei:lb/>on legs and antennae, tubercles of head and pronotum bearing longer, almost erect hairs about as long as<tei:lb/>two-thirds diameter of an eye.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour ochreous yellow; ground colour of clavus, corium and posterior half of pronotum pale cinereous,<tei:lb/>without yellow tinge. Grey or piceous markings of greater or lesser extent present on midline and posterior<tei:lb/>border of pronotum, on scutellum, on hemelytra, especially costal and apical areas of corium; on anterior<tei:lb/>and posterior borders of laterotergites, including more than posterior halves of laterotergites IV and V; on<tei:lb/>apical halves of femora, especially posterior pair; and on thoracic pleura and abdominal sterna. Mesoster-<tei:lb/>num and metasternum entirely piceous. Tibiae with basal, apical and median annuli grey.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This is the smallest species of the genus. It differs from the African P. amphrysia in having the<tei:lb/>second antennal segment shorter than the third and from the Asian P. brevitibialis in having the<tei:lb/>posterolateral angles of the abdominal sternites acute. The antevannal vein is very indistinct, probably<tei:lb/>because it is functionally obsolete in such a small wing.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. South-east Asia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , Laos: Wapikhamthong Prov., Khong Sedone, 15.viii.1965 (native collector) (BPBM).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes.          <tei:p>Psilolomia dispar (Walker) comb. n.<tei:lb/>(Figs 36, 37, 48)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Clavigralla dispar Walker, 1872: 6. Holotype cf (no locality cited) (BMNH) [examined].<tei:lb/>[Clavigralla aliena (Walker); Distant, 1901: 426. Misidentification.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length: cf, 8-4-9-0 mm; $,8-9-9-9 mm.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head (Figs 36, 37) dorsally granulate, with antennifers very short, slightly divergent, outer apical<tei:lb/>process obsolete; a large, granular tubercle, almost as large as the eye, present on side of head above each<tei:lb/>antennifer.          <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>TRIBE PSEUDOPHLOEINI 175</tei:p>
         <tei:p>lengths of antennal segments in male about l-00:l-01:0-88:0-87, in female about l-00:0-99:0-84:0-92. Ratio<tei:lb/>of lengths of rostral segments about 1-00:0-63:0-55:0-61.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pronotum with lateral margins shallowly concave, granulate, posterolateral angles elevated but only<tei:lb/>weakly produced laterally, posterolateral spines acute, about 1-5 times as long as their basal width; width of<tei:lb/>pronotum across apices of spines divided by width of head including eyes 1-96-2-04. Metasternum weakly<tei:lb/>convex. Anterior femur with one small subapical pine beneath, intermediate femur with one small spine<tei:lb/>and one very small one, posterior femur with three major spines, the first pair with no minor spines<tei:lb/>between them, the second and last with three or four minor spines between them and with an apical series<tei:lb/>of four; holotype and some other specimens with a small spine preceding the three major spines.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdominal sternites IH-VII with posterolateral angles slightly more acute than right-angled and slightly<tei:lb/>prominent. Conjunctiva (Fig. 48) with ventral, toothed sclerotized strips well developed, distal dorso-<tei:lb/>lateral lobes sclerotized throughout, L-shaped.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coloration generally ferruginous; dorsal midline of head with distinct, narrow, yellow stripe; antennal<tei:lb/>segments III-VII yellow with granulation piceous; segment IV ferruginous; pronotum with anteromedian<tei:lb/>macula and posterolateral spines brown; legs yellow but extensively covered with brown granules, tibiae<tei:lb/>with basal, apical and median annuli brown, femora extensively mottled brown or ferruginous, especially<tei:lb/>apically; thoracic sterna brown; abdominal sterna yellow with brown markings largely confined to two<tei:lb/>longitudinal bands; laterotergites yellow with brown markings medially and posteriorly; clavus and corium<tei:lb/>ferruginous, the latter with a few obscure spots on veins brown, membrane fuscous, veins spotted darker,<tei:lb/>apex of corium and membrane throughout with large, cream spots.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pubescence rather short, semidecumbent to suberect; erect hairs about as long as two-thirds diameter of<tei:lb/>eye present rather densely on declivent part of pronotum and on ventral surfaces of femora; main<tei:lb/>pubescence of head consisting of short, almost decumbent hairs but larger granules, especially of dorsal<tei:lb/>midline, bearing short, suberect to erect hairs.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species is immediately recognizable by the presence of the large tubercles above the<tei:lb/>antnnifers; these could be mistaken for the antennifers themselves in dorsal view. The first antennal<tei:lb/>segment is unusually short for one of the larger species of the genus. Walker's original description refers to<tei:lb/>three longitudinal brown bands on the pronotum; the lateral ones are, in fact, shadows in the shallow<tei:lb/>troughs between the gently convex pronotal disc and the elevated posterolateral angles. Distant (1901:<tei:lb/>426) redescribed the type-specimen of Clavigralla dispar Walker under the impression that it was the type<tei:lb/>of Cletus alienus Walker. The latter, which is now missing, was a female from New Guinea whereas the type<tei:lb/>of dispar was specified by Walker as a male without locality data donated by Saunders.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>.DISTRIBUTION. India.</tei:p>
