         <tei:p>MFLAStal<tei:lb/>Myla Stal, 1866: 111. Type-species: Myla nigrispina Stal, by monotypy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Body form parallel-sided, length about 3 times breadth, sometimes broader (M. lata), sometimes<tei:lb/>somewhat depressed (M. niokensis), connexivum narrow to broad.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head about as long as broad, weakly granulate. Antennifers weakly divergent, their outer apical<tei:lb/>processes porrect. Antennae with segment I varying in length from about 0-50-1-25 times width of head<tei:lb/>including eyes, almost isodiametric throughout its length, weakly granulate; segment III about 1-25 times<tei:lb/>as long as II, both segments slender and weakly granulate; segment IV elongate, cylindrical, variable in<tei:lb/>length between the species so that in some it is the longest and in others the shortest segment, its specialized<tei:lb/>sensory area occupying nine-tenths of its length or more. Bucculae occupying about one-third of ventral<tei:lb/>length of head. Rostrum at rest reaching posteriorly to base of metasternum.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pronotum strongly declivent anteriorly, disc weakly or very weakly granulate; lateral margins with many<tei:lb/>small granules or a few large granules or tubercles; posterolateral angles scarcely to very strongly produced<tei:lb/>anterolaterally or laterally, bearing obsolete to long, slender and acute posterolateral spines; posterior<tei:lb/>margin weakly convex, smoothly rounded, sometimes appearing slightly trilobed but without distinct<tei:lb/>emarginations or projections. Scutellum equilateral or slightly elongate, its apex slightly elevated above<tei:lb/>clavi at rest, usually white; lateral margins, especially anteriorly, slightly elevated; disc flat, weakly<tei:lb/>granulate-punctate. Mesosternum sulcate throughout. Metasternum strongly convex, sulcate only anter-<tei:lb/>iorly. Metathoracic scent-gland peritreme with dorsal ridge reniform. Corium with distal margin weakly or<tei:lb/>very weakly concave, its apex reaching to level of suture between laterotergites V and VI when at rest.<tei:lb/>Metathoracic wing with antevannal vein present. Anterior and intermediate femora usually with a single,<tei:lb/>prominent, subapical granule or tubercle beneath; posterior femur with well-developed basal tubercle and<tei:lb/>subapically beneath with three major spines, of which the first (proximal) one is very small, two to four<tei:lb/>small granules or tubercles between the two larger spines and an apical series of four tubercles. Posterior<tei:lb/>coxae separated by a distance equal to approximately half the width of a coxa.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdominal sterna III to VII with posterolateral angles acute, weakly to strongly produced, lateral<tei:lb/>margins of these sternites finely or obsoletely granulate. Male genital capsule posteriorly emarginate, the<tei:lb/>emargination with a central cusp; parameres with blades flat, their apices not occluding emargination of<tei:lb/>capsule (Fig. 96), proximal tooth of paramere simple, apical tooth long, upcurved. Phallotheca (Figs<tei:lb/>111-113) comprising a single dorsal and a single ventral sclerite, both broad, each with a narrow, median,<tei:lb/>posterior projection, ventral sclerite proximally produced dorsad on each side to meet dorsal sclerite.<tei:lb/>Conjunctiva (Figs 111-114) with dorsomedian lobe membranous, transverse, its lateral angles prominent;<tei:lb/>distal dorsolateral lobes membranous, arising close together over ejaculatory reservoir, finger- like,<tei:lb/>reflexed anteriad; apical ventral lobes large, membranous, paired; distal ventrolateral lobes deeply bifid,<tei:lb/>wings of ejaculatory reservoir complex extending into the dorsal, descending arm of each lobe, ventral,<tei:lb/>anteriorly directed arm of each lobe membranous and without sclerotized support; ventral lobes lightly<tei:lb/>sclerotized, wide apart, narrow, anteriorly directed and slightly upcurved; base of vesica without<tei:lb/>protective sclerites. Sclerites of wall of gynatrium in female each comprising a curved plate parallel to rami<tei:lb/>bearing a longer, ventral, mesal and a shorter, dorsal, lateral process, both directed posteriorly.<tei:lb/>Spermatheca (Figs 115, 116) with bulb lunate, duct adjacent to bulb tightly convoluted, connected with<tei:lb/>gynatrium by an S-shaped portion of the duct.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Main pubescence of body, hemelytra, femora and first antennal segment consisting of short, semidecum-</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>194 W. R. DOLLING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>bent to adpressed, white, flattened, scale-like hairs. Coloration, probably of all species, variable, basically<tei:lb/>grey-brown with more or less of a yellowish or reddish suffusion.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This genus differs from all others in the tribe in the form of the parameres, of which the distal<tei:lb/>tooth is long and sharply upcurved at right angles to the blade and the apices do not fill the posterior<tei:lb/>emargination of the genital capsule. The form of the phallotheca is also unique within the tribe. The<tei:lb/>scale-like pubescence is sufficient to distinguish Myla species from all other African Pseudophloeinae<tei:lb/>except Paramyla australis. Myla species are sometimes mistaken for members of the tribe Clavigrallini<tei:lb/>which, however, lack the tubercle that is present in Myla at the base of the posterior femur. Eleven species,<tei:lb/>all African, are accepted here as members of the genus. For M. concolor Dohrn and M. cornuta Hsiao, see<tei:lb/>Pseudomyla; for M. suspecta Schouteden, see Paramyla. M. schnelli Villiers was transferred to Clavigralla<tei:lb/>by Dolling (19790: 34).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Africa south of the Sahara, including Ethiopia. Not so far recorded from any islands or from<tei:lb/>Arabia.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Myla nigrispina Stal, 1866: 111. LECTOTYPE $, 'GUINEA' (NMV), here designated [examined]. Syn. n.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Length: cf, 9-8-11-7 mm; $,9-7-12-0 mm.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head (Fig. 79) slightly longer than wide, broadly rounded anteriorly. Length of antennal segment I<tei:lb/>divided by width of head including eyes in male 88-1 16 , in female 89-1 09 . Ratio of lengths of antennal<tei:lb/>segments in male about l-00:0-80:l-03:0-96, in female about l-00:0-84:l-04:0-85. Length of rostral<tei:lb/>segment I divided by width of head including eyes in both sexes 0-69-0-81, ratio of lengths of rostral<tei:lb/>segments about 1 -00:0-84:0-43 :0-64.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pronotum (Figs 79, 84) with posterolateral angles produced anterolaterally and terminating in short<tei:lb/>spines, lateral margins very weakly granulate. Width across apices of posterolateral spines divided by width<tei:lb/>of head including eyes in male 2-14-2-84, in female 2-20-2-92. Length of posterior tibia divided by that of<tei:lb/>posterior femur 0-89-1-06.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdomen rather narrow, its lateral margin (Fig. 91) weakly convex, posterolateral angles of sternites<tei:lb/>III- VII projecting as fairly short, narrow, posteriorly directed spines; abdominal laterotergites narrow,<tei:lb/>laterotergite V usually at least twice as long as wide, rarely slightly less. Paramere (Figs 96, 99, 100) with<tei:lb/>apical tooth long, upcurved, its posterior margin projecting distinctly beyond apex of shaft. Aedeagus very<tei:lb/>similar in all respects to that of M. calida, q.v. Female with second valvula of ovipositor (Fig. 119)<tei:lb/>terminating in an apically rounded lobe.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pubescence of head, all exposed parts of thorax, abdominal laterotergites, antennal segment I, femora,<tei:lb/>clavus and corium composed of short, flattened, scale-like, decumbent or adpressed, white hairs, each hair<tei:lb/>much shorter than the distance between its own insertion and that of its nearest neighbour, each insertion<tei:lb/>borne on a large granule on the head and a small granule elsewhere, granules of thoracic pleurites,<tei:lb/>posterior lobe of pronotum, scutellum and hemelytra each positioned on the anterior (or proximal on<tei:lb/>hemelytra) border of a large puncture. Pubescence of disc of abdominal venter suberect, not scale-like,<tei:lb/>grading laterally into white, scale-like type. Pubescence of antennal segments II to IV, tibiae and tarsi<tei:lb/>suberect, rather short, not scale-like.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>General coloration of body and appendages greyish yellow, more or less heavily suffused red. Antennal<tei:lb/>segments II and III, tibiae and tarsi stramineous. Apex of rostral segment IV, posterolateral angles and<tei:lb/>spines of pronotum and often a line along lateral margins of pronotum piceous. Membrane of hemelytra<tei:lb/>whitish hyaline, its veins brown with frequent whitish hyaline interruptions. Elevated apex of scutellum<tei:lb/>and dorsal ridge of metathoracic peritreme white, the latter often margined piceous.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This and the next four species form a group of closely related taxa which are probably all rather<tei:lb/>variable in pronotum shape, size and coloration. Examination of the genitalia is the only completely<tei:lb/>reliable way of distinguishing between this species and M. calida, with which it is partly sympatric.<tei:lb/>Although the genitalia of the female lectotype of M. nigrispina were not dissected out, the specimen<tei:lb/>corresponds in every other way with the West African species recognized here as M. hoploxys. No other<tei:lb/>species of this complex was detected in the area of the type-locality of M. nigrispina ('Guinea', = West<tei:lb/>Africa). There is no justification for Linnavuori's (1971: 175, 176) recognition of two, largely sympatric<tei:lb/>subspecies distinguished by size, colour and some slight, probably allometric structural features. Large,<tei:lb/>red individuals with long posterolateral pronotal spines predominate in the western part of the range of the<tei:lb/>species and are rare in the eastern part. This species includes cowpea (Vigna) in its diet and, according to<tei:lb/>Professor A. E. Akingbohungbe (pers. comm.), it is approaching the pest status of the Clavigralla species<tei:lb/>on this crop.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Proven distribution covers West Africa from Senegal and Gambia eastwards to Zaire and<tei:lb/>Angola. Linnavuori (1978: 36) records a single specimen from Sudan.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gambia: 1 cf (holotypeof hoploxys), (no other data) (BMNH). 'Guinea': 1 $ (lectotype of nigrispina)<tei:lb/>(coll. Signoret), (NMV).</tei:p>

         <tei:p>TRIBE PSEUDOPHLOEINI 197</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(64 km) SW. of San, 300 m, 26.viii.1966 (Ross, Lorenzen) (CAS).          <tei:p>Myla abyssinica Linnavuori<tei:lb/>(Figs 92, 97, 102)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Myla abyssinica Linnavuori, 1971: 175. Lectotype cf , ETHIOPIA: near Nazareth, 20-21.vi.1963 (Linna-<tei:lb/>vuori) (R. Linnavuori coll.), designated by Linnavuori, 1978: 36 [not examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length: cf , 9-9-10-1 mm; $ unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Very similar to M. hoploxys. Length of antennal segment I divided by width of head including eyes<tei:lb/>0-88-0-93. Ratio of lengths of antennal segments about 1-00:0-80: 1-05: 1-04. Length of rostral segment I<tei:lb/>divided by width of head including eyes 0-69-0-75. Ratio of lengths of rostral segments about<tei:lb/>1 -00:0-84:0-45 :0-64. Pronotum with posterolateral spines as short as in the shortest-spined examples of M.<tei:lb/>hoploxys; width across apices of spines divided by width of head including eyes 2-16-2-21. Connexivum<tei:lb/>narrow, laterotergite V about 2-5 times as long as wide. Posterolateral spines of sternites III to VII short<tei:lb/>(Fig. 92). Length of posterior tibia divided by length of posterior femur 0-96. Paramere (Fig. 102) with<tei:lb/>apical tooth relatively shorter than that of M. hoploxys.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species was described by Linnavuori (1971: 175) in a dichotomous key. Subsequently, the<tei:lb/>same author (Linnavuori, 1978: 21, 36, 103, figs 16f, 16g, 69d) provided a fuller description, with figures,<tei:lb/>suggesting at the same time that it might be only a race of M. hoploxys. In his 1978 publication, he<tei:lb/>designated his unique specimen as holotype. As he already validly described the species in 1971, without<tei:lb/>designating a type-specimen, his 1978 action must be regarded as a lectotype designation. In view of the<tei:lb/>small differences separating species in this genus it seems appropriate to accord full specific status to this<tei:lb/>taxon, especially as the two specimens examined here are very similar to the one described by Linnavuori.<tei:lb/>The strong reddish suffusion noted by Linnavuori (1978) in the type-specimen is not apparent in the two<tei:lb/>specimens I have seen.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Endemic to Ethiopia on the available evidence.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ethiopia: 1 cf , Djoudjou Abayi, Didessa R., Goma, 2000 ft (600 m), lO.v.1905 (Zaphiro) (BMNH); 1<tei:lb/>Cf, Gemu-Gofa Prov., 45 km N. of Demika, near Jinka road, 1460 m, 30. iv. 1974 (de Rougemont)<tei:lb/>(MRAC).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Myla calida sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 87, 88, 101, 111-114, 120)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length: cf , 9-0-10-6 mm; $ , 9-0-10-3 mm.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Very similar to M. hoploxys. Length of antennal segment I divided by width of head including eyes in<tei:lb/>male and female 0-92-1-05. Ratio of lengths of antennal segments in male about l-00:0-75:0-95:0-94, in<tei:lb/>female about l-00:0-80:0-95:0-82. Length of rostral segment I divided by width of head including eyes in<tei:lb/>male 0-66-0-75, in female 0-69-0-79. Ratio of lengths of rostral segments in male about<tei:lb/>l-00:0-85:0-43:0-64, in female about 1-00:0-85:0-42:0-61.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pronotal shape variable (Figs 87, 88), posterolateral spines on average more strongly divergent than<tei:lb/>those of M . hoploxys; width across apices of posterolateral spines divided by width of head including eyes<tei:lb/>in male 2-30-2-85, in female 2-31-2-62. Granulation of lateral margins of pronotum slightly more<tei:lb/>pronounced than in M. hoploxys. Length of posterior tibia divided by length of posterior femur 0-89-0-95.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Connexivum and abdominal spines as in M. hoploxys. Paramere (Fig. 101) with apical tooth shorter than<tei:lb/>that of M. hoploxys, its posterior margin not or scarcely projecting posteriad of apex of shaft. Aedeagus</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>198 W. R. DOLLING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 111-114) of the form usual in the genus. Ovipositor with second valvula (Fig. 120) obliquely truncate,<tei:lb/>apex acute and slightly upturned.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coloration on average more yellowish than greyish, never as deeply suffused red as the most extreme<tei:lb/>examples of M. hoploxys.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The second valvula of this species is very distinctive. The shape of the paramere is rather variable<tei:lb/>but it is never so long as that of M. hoploxys, nor is its apical tooth so long or so prominent. The shape of the<tei:lb/>pronotum is also variable (compare Figs 87, 88), as is the colour. In many individuals there is a conspicuous<tei:lb/>black line along the lateral margins of the pronotum.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Eastern, central and southern Africa. Absent from West Africa. Northern limit unknown.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Myla somalica Linnavuori<tei:lb/>(Figs 81, 103)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Myla somalica Linnavuori, 1982: 14-16. Posterior<tei:lb/>tibia long, its length divided by that of posterior femur 0-96-1-03.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paramere (Fig. 103) with shaft long, as in M. hoploxys, teeth of blade short, as in M. calida.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species is readily distinguished from all others of the genus by its enormous ocelli. The<tei:lb/>paratype was received after the above measurements were taken. It is 9-8 mm long, its first antennal<tei:lb/>segment is 0-90 times the width of the head and the antennal ratio is 1-00:0-79: 1-07: 1-08. The paramere is<tei:lb/>indistinguishable from that of the inland specimens with which it seems to be conspecific despite the<tei:lb/>difference in habitat.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Highlands of eastern central Africa to the Somali coast.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Myla lata sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 89, 93, 95, 107)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length: cf , 9-8-10-8 mm; $ unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A very broad-bodied species. Length of antennal segment I divided by width of head including eyes in<tei:lb/>holotype 0-88. Remainder of antennae in holotype and whole of antennae in paratype missing. Length of<tei:lb/>rostral segment I divided by width of head including eyes in paratype 0-70; ratio of lengths of its rostral<tei:lb/>segments as l-00:0-80:0-45:0-63; rostrum not visible in holotype mount.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pronotum (Fig. 89) very broad, lateral margins strongly granulate, posterolateral angles weakly<tei:lb/>produced, terminating in small, laterally directed spines; width across apices of posterolateral spines<tei:lb/>divided by width of head including eyes 2-52-2-56.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdomen broad, its lateral margins (Fig. 93) strongly convex, posterolateral angles of sternites III to VII<tei:lb/>produced into broad, triangular spines. Connexivum broad, laterotergite V about five-sixths as broad as<tei:lb/>long. Paramere (Fig. 107) with both teeth of blade on a common stem.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coloration ferruginous; all tibiae stramineous with basal, median and apical annuli piceous (Fig. 95).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species is very distinctive by reason of its great breadth. It is the only species of the genus in<tei:lb/>which the tibiae are conspicuously bicolorous.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>TRIBE PSEUDOPHLOEINI 201</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Central Africa.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , Zambia: N. Lake Bangweolo, 4200 ft [1260 m], Luwingu, 21.vii.1908 (Neave) (UM).<tei:lb/>Paratype. Zaire: 1 cf , Katanga, Lufira River, 3500 ft [1050 m], 10.ix.1907 (Neave) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Myla niokensis Schouteden<tei:lb/>(Figs 85, 90, 106)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Myla niokensis Schouteden, 1938: 294. LECTOTYPE cf , ZAIRE (MRAC), here designated [examined].<tei:lb/>Myla (Paramyla) niokensis Schouteden; Linnavuori, 1971: 178.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length: cf, 8-2-9-3 mm; $,8-7-9-7 mm.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head similar in shape to that of M. hoploxys. Antennae, especially segment I, short. Length of antennal<tei:lb/>segment I divided by width of head including eyes in male 0-56-0-74, in female 0-55-0-69. Ratio of lengths<tei:lb/>of antennal segments in male about l-00:0-95:l-14:l-48, in female about l-00:l-04:l-09:l-33. Length of<tei:lb/>rostral segment I divided by width of head including eyes in both sexes 0-64-0-75 . Ratio of lengths of rostral<tei:lb/>segments about l-00:0-85:0-44:0-64.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pronotum (Fig. 85) with posterolateral angles produced forward, their apices directed laterally but very<tei:lb/>weakly produced in that direction, terminating in very short spines, margins behind the produced angles<tei:lb/>concave, diverging posteriorly so that in most cases greatest width of pronotum is not across apices of<tei:lb/>posterolateral spines but across posterior lobe; width across apices of posterolateral spines divided by<tei:lb/>width of head including eyes in male 1-88-2-16, in female 2-00-2-22. Length of posterior tibia divided by<tei:lb/>length of posterior femur in both sexes 0-94-1-06.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdomen with lateral margin (Fig. 90) moderately convex; posterolateral angles of sternites III to VI<tei:lb/>weakly prominent. Connexivum moderately broad, laterotergite V about 1-7 times as long as wide.<tei:lb/>Paramere (Fig. 106) very similar to that of M. hoploxys.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour yellow-brown with punctures of pronotum and hemelytra and often parts of underside and<tei:lb/>posterior femora piceous or black; body and appendages often with a reddish tinge. The darkest species of<tei:lb/>the genus. Pubescence as in M. hoploxys. Granules of lateral margins of pronotum about as prominent as<tei:lb/>those of M. hoploxys.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species may easily be recognized by the form of the pronotum, except that it might be<tei:lb/>confused with M. abyssinica from which it differs in that its antennal segment I is much shorter and segment<tei:lb/>IV is very long compared with I. Specimens from Zaire have the apical tooth of the paramere slightly<tei:lb/>shorter than it is in those from Ethiopia and Kenya. Ethiopian specimens differ from the others in having a<tei:lb/>slightly longer rostral segment IV. Antennal segment I is shortest, both in proportion to head width and in<tei:lb/>proportion to the other segments, in Kenyan specimens and longest in those from Zaire. The numbers of<tei:lb/>specimens available are too low for it to be certain that these distinctions are not artefacts of sampling.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Records suggest that the species occurs at high altitudes in three separate areas: Ethiopia;<tei:lb/>near Nairobi in Kenya; and on the common borders of Zaire, Uganda, Tanzania and Rwanda.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Zaire: 1 cf (lectotype), Ituri, Nioka, 7.vii.l934 (Leroy) (labelled: 'holotypus') (MRAC).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ethiopia: 1 cf , Mt Chilalo, forest, ca 8500 ft (2550 m), 24.xi.1926 (Scott); 1 cf , Gojjam, Fasilo Bahr Dar,<tei:lb/>scrub, 2.viii.l965 (Kitching); 1 cf, Addis Ababa, Filoa, vii.1941 (Meneghetti); 1 $, Simien, Atgheba<tei:lb/>Ghiyorghis, ca 10,900 ft (3270 m), 4.xii.l952, arable land (Scott); 1 ? , Urgessa R., Jimu, 2300 ft (690 m),<tei:lb/>3.V.1905 (Zaphiro); 1 $, Mt Zuqala, in crater, ca 9000 ft (2700 m), 26.X.1926 (Omer Cooper) (BMNH).<tei:lb/>Zaire: 3 $ (paralectotypes), Ituri, Nioka, vii.1934 (Leroy); 1 $ (paralectotype), Ituri, Nioka, 7.vii.l934<tei:lb/>(Leroy); 1 cf , Nioka, vii.1934 (Leroy); 1 cf , Tshamgussa, 8-15. viii. 1934 (de Witte); 1 $, Pare Nat. Kibuye, 12.ii.1953 (Basilewsky) (MRAC). Tanzania: 1 $, Mt Mem, Olkokola,<tei:lb/>facing NW. , 2800 m, 24.vi-l.viu.1957 (Basilewsky, Leleup) (MRAC). No data: 1 cf (ex coll. Schouteden)<tei:lb/>(MRAC).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>202 W. R. DOLLING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Myla microphthalma Linnavuori</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 82, 105, 115, 117)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Myla microphthalma Linnavuori, 1971: 175, 176-177. Holotype cf , IVORY COAST: Lamto, 3.iii-21.iv.l967<tei:lb/>(Gillon) (R. Linnavuori coll.) [not examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length: cf, 8-3-9-7 mm; $,8-6-9-9 mm.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head (Fig. 82) more elongated and more acutely pointed anteriorly than is usual in the genus, eyes small.<tei:lb/>Length of antennal segment I divided by width of head including eyes in males from the type-locality (Ivory<tei:lb/>Coast) 0-91-0-97, in females from type-locality 0-90-0-97, in males and females from elsewhere respective-<tei:lb/>ly 0-76-0-93 and 0-76-0-91. Ratio of lengths of antennal segments in males and females from Ivory Coast<tei:lb/>respectively about l-00:0-86:l-05:0-98 and l-00:0-88:l-04:0-85; in males and females from elsewhere<tei:lb/>respectively about 1-00:0-88:1-05:1-17 and 1-00:0-90:1-05:1-03. Length of rostral segment I divided by<tei:lb/>width of head including eyes in both sexes 0-72-0-84; ratio of lengths of rostral segments about<tei:lb/>l-00:0-85:0-44:0-67.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pronotum (Fig. 82) with posterolateral angles rather strongly produced anterolaterally and lateral<tei:lb/>margins finely granulate with a few larger granules; width of pronotum across apices of posterolateral<tei:lb/>spines divided by width of head including eyes 2-15-2-65, not differing significantly between the sexes.<tei:lb/>Length of posterior tibia divided by length of posterior femur 0-89-0-98.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdomen with posterolateral angles of sternites III to VII produced as short, acute spines. Paramere<tei:lb/>(Fig. 105) with blade broad, distal margin of apical tooth evenly curved, apical tooth rather longer than<tei:lb/>basal tooth. Spermatheca (Fig. 115) with bulb short, duct tightly convoluted. Second valvula of ovipositor<tei:lb/>(Fig. 117) apically narrow, elongate, parallel-sided.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coloration reddish or greyish brown, dorsal midline of head always with median fuscous stripe;<tei:lb/>pronotum with anterolateral margins, posterolateral spines and anterior half of midline fuscous. Colour<tei:lb/>pattern otherwise and pubescence as in M. hoploxys.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The fuscous midline of the head distinguishes this species from all others in the genus. The series<tei:lb/>from the type-locality (Ivory Coast: Lamto, Toumodi) was found to differ from the rest of the material<tei:lb/>examined in several biometric ratios, as indicated above. A particularly striking difference was found in the<tei:lb/>ratio of the lengths of antennal segments I and IV. The length of segment IV divided by that of segment I in<tei:lb/>five males and two females from the Ivory Coast was, respectively, 0-91-1-00 and 0-84-0-86; in 12 males<tei:lb/>and six females from the rest of Africa this value was, respectively, 1-02-1-30 and 1-00-1-10. Although the<tei:lb/>Ivory Coast sample size is small, the measurements of this ratio fall completely outside the range<tei:lb/>determined for specimens from the rest of Africa. It may be that the Ivory Coast population has been<tei:lb/>isolated from the remainder for a considerable period. Perhaps an ancestral population of this species was<tei:lb/>isolated in mountain refugia in east Central Africa and Guinea and has re-invaded the lower-lying areas<tei:lb/>from these two centres. One male is omitted from the description above because of its even more elongate<tei:lb/>head and its aberrant measurements. It is from Zaire: Mongende; its length is 9-0 mm; the width of its<tei:lb/>pronotum, length of antennal segment I and length of rostral segment I, all divided by the width of the<tei:lb/>head, are respectively 2-82, 1-03 and 0-84. The lengths of the four antennal segments are in the ratio of<tei:lb/>1-00:0-84:0-97:1-00.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. The species is known from two widely separated areas: (1) Ivory Coast and (2) southern<tei:lb/>Africa, avoiding desert and dense forest and extending northwards to 4S in the west and 2N in the<tei:lb/>equatorial mountains of the east.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Myla onceroma sp. n.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Pronotum (Fig. 80) with posterolateral angles shortly produced anteriorly, bearing short spines; width<tei:lb/>across apices of spines divided by width of head including eyes in male 1-99-2-20, in female 2-03.          <tei:p>Abdominal sternites III to VII with posterolateral angles produced into short, acute spines. Male<tei:lb/>genitalia similar to those of M. microphthalma. Female with bulb of spermatheca (Fig. 116) longer than<tei:lb/>that of M. microphthalma and with apical projection of second valvula (Fig. 118) very short.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>General coloration dark red-brown or brown. Midline of head and pronotum concolorous, without<tei:lb/>darker median stripe.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This small species is probably most closely related to M. microphthalma but may be disting-<tei:lb/>uished from it by the much shorter antennae, shorter head and much less strongly produced pronotal<tei:lb/>angles, which approach the form of those of M. niokensis but bear longer apical spines. It is a montane</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>204 W. R. DOLLING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>form, perhaps descended from the ancestral population that gave rise to M. microphthalma but is now<tei:lb/>greatly specialized, particularly in the form of the second valvulae of the ovipositor, after long isolation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Known only from three localities at high altitudes in Cameroun and south-eastern Nigeria.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Myla gracilis Schouteden<tei:lb/>(Figs 83, 94, 98, 108-110)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Myla gracilis Schouteden, 1938: 293. LECTOTYPE cf , ZAIRE (MRAC), here designated [examined].<tei:lb/>Myla graciloides Linnavuori, 1971: 175. Lectotype cf, SUDAN: Equatoria prov., Yei-Maridi, 13-</tei:p>
         <tei:p>15. iv. 1963, swampy meadow (Linnavuori) (R. Linnavuori coll.), designated by Linnavuori, 1978: 36</tei:p>
         <tei:p>[not examined]. Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length: cf, 8-4-9-8 mm; $, 9-00-10-0 mm.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head distinctly longer than wide, narrowly rounded anteriorly. Length of antennal segment I divided by<tei:lb/>width of head including eyes in male 1-06-1-27, in female 1-06-1-25. Ratio of lengths of antennal segments<tei:lb/>in male about l-00:0-87:0-94:0-86, in female about 1-00:0-87:0-93:0-80.          <tei:p>Pronotum (Fig. 83) with posterolateral angles strongly produced anterolaterally, terminating in slender<tei:lb/>spines, anterolateral margins with one to three prominent, piceous or black tubercles; width across apices<tei:lb/>of posterolateral spines divided by width of head including eyes in male 2-57-3-18, in female 2-74-3-09.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdomen with posterolateral angles of sternites III to VII produced as fine spines (Fig. 94). Connex-<tei:lb/>ivum rather narrow; laterotergite V twice as long as wide. Paramere (Figs 108-110) slender, with apical<tei:lb/>tooth long and both teeth on a common stem that arises terminally or subterminally from the blade. Female<tei:lb/>with second valvula tapering to narrowly rounded apex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pubescence of head, pronotum, scutellum, thoracic pleura, abdominal venter laterally and basally,<tei:lb/>laterotergites, clavus, corium, antennal segment I, coxae, trochanters, femora and rostrum comprising<tei:lb/>fairly short, flattened, scale-like, decumbent (except on appendages), white hairs; hairs on thoracic pleura<tei:lb/>(Fig. 98) and declivent area of pronotum very distinctly longer than distance between adjacent hair<tei:lb/>insertions and tending to form three or four transverse bands on deolivent area of pronotum. Areas of<tei:lb/>abdominal venter and appendages that are devoid of scale-like pubescence with short, suberect, colourless<tei:lb/>hairs.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coloration generally as in M. hoploxys but never heavily tinged red. Scutellum with midline and small,<tei:lb/>apical knob usually creamy white. Large tubercles of anterolateral margins of pronotum and apices of<tei:lb/>posterolateral spines piceous to black. Veins of hemelytral membrane brown, uninterrupted.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species differs from all others of the genus in the greater length of the scale-like pubescence.<tei:lb/>The posterolateral pronotal angles are more strongly produced in this species than in any of its congeners.<tei:lb/>The combination of these two features gives M. gracilis a superficial resemblance to Clavigralla schnelli<tei:lb/>(Villiers). Indeed, the type-series of M. gracilis contains three individuals of C. schnelli, one of which bears<tei:lb/>a label with the legend, 'holotypus'. This type designation has never been published and Schouteden's very<tei:lb/>detailed description of the antennifers, rostrum, antennae, femoral spines and male genital capsule leaves<tei:lb/>no doubt that he was describing a species of Myla. I have, therefore, ignored the unpublished 'holotype'<tei:lb/>designation and here select one of the 'paratypes' as lectotype. Linnavuori (1971: 175; 1978: 35-36) used<tei:lb/>the name M. gracilis for what is evidently C. schnelli and established the unnecessary new nominal species<tei:lb/>Myla graciloides for M. gracilis proper. In his 1971 paper, Linnavuori cites the localities Sudan, Congo and<tei:lb/>Ivory Coast but in 1978 he cites only the 'type' from Sudan; this citation is effectively a lectotype<tei:lb/>designation. There is some variation in the pronotal posterolateral spines which are usually laterally<tei:lb/>directed but sometimes anterolaterally directed.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. West and Central Africa.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>TRIBE PSEUDOPHLOEINI</tei:p>
         <tei:p>205</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Ivory Coast: 14 cf, 20 $, Lamto, variously 'Lamto (Toumodi)', various dates from 4.xii.l962 to<tei:lb/>14.viii.1964, all months except i, ii, xi, greatest numbers in vi; 5 cf , 1 $ , Bouake, 22.V.1962, 21.vii.1962; 1<tei:lb/>CT, Dabov, S.v.1964 (BMNH).          <tei:p>Paralectotypes of My la gracilis Schouteden not belonging to this species. 3 exx determined as Clavigralla<tei:lb/>schnelli (Villiers) by Dolling, 1979: 36, q.v.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Distribution of Pseudophloeinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Preamble</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Without a complete phylogenetic analysis of the subfamily, incorporating the Palaearctic<tei:lb/>genera, a comprehensive account of its zoogeography is not possible. In undertaking the present<tei:lb/>revision I have considered every species of the subfamily, including the Palaearctic ones, in<tei:lb/>relation to the diagnostic features of every genus, and I am reasonably certain that all of the<tei:lb/>genera currently recognized are monophyletic in origin and holophyletic in composition.<tei:lb/>However, I have not fully investigated the relationships among all the genera of the subfamily.<tei:lb/>Two presumably holophyletic groups of genera are recognized: the tribe Clavigrallini (see<tei:lb/>Dolling, 1978; 1979a) and a large group of genera including all of those confined to the North<tei:lb/>Temperate Zone and all of the tropical genera except for Vilga, Risbecocoris, Paramyla,<tei:lb/>Hoplolomia and Indolomia. The first two of these genera are probably not descended from the<tei:lb/>most recent common ancestor of the two big groups while the last three may be related to the<tei:lb/>non-clavigralline group in some way (see Table 1). The distribution of the various genera of<tei:lb/>Pseudophloeinae in the major zoogeographical regions is summarized in Table 2. The Afro-<tei:lb/>tropical region in this table excludes the Mascarene area (Madagascar, Mauritius, Reunion and<tei:lb/>Rodriguez), which is shown separately. The Oriental region is taken to include New Guinea and<tei:lb/>the Solomon Islands but Australia is excluded and its pseudophloeine fauna is tabulated in a<tei:lb/>separate column.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Table 1 Distribution of two characters in the subfamily Pseudophloeinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Antevannal vein<tei:lb/>absent</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Antevannal vein<tei:lb/>present</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Posterior femur without basal tubercle<tei:lb/>Posterior femur with basal tubercle</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vilga,<tei:lb/>Risbecocoris</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hoplolomia,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Indolomia,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paramyla</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Clavigrallini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Remaining<tei:lb/>genera</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Neotropical</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The only genus of Pseudophloeinae represented in the Neotropical region is Vilga, which is<tei:lb/>endemic to the New World. The 14 species were divided among six subgenera by Dolling (1977),</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>206 W. R. DOLLING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>who commented that the differences among these subgenera were of the same degree as those<tei:lb/>separating some Palaearctic genera. One subgenus, whose single species is facultatively<tei:lb/>brachypterous, occurs from the extreme southern U.S.A. to El Salvador; all the other<tei:lb/>subgenera are confined to the Neotropical region and are widely sympatric there, with the<tei:lb/>exception of one subgenus whose three species are confined to the temperate and largely<tei:lb/>mountainous regions of Argentina, Chile and Peru. This latter subgenus, through a general<tei:lb/>reduction of spininess of the body and legs and a flattening and broadening of the body,<tei:lb/>superficially resembles the tropical montane and temperate South African genus Paramyla and<tei:lb/>the Palaearctic Arenocoris and Bathysolen Fieber.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Nearctic</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The presence of a single species of the otherwise Neotropical genus Vilga in Mexico and adjacent<tei:lb/>areas has been mentioned above. In addition, two genera of Pseudophloeini are shared between<tei:lb/>the Palaearctic and Nearctic regions.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coriomeris Westwood has 16 species in the Palaearctic and another four in the Nearctic. The<tei:lb/>Nearctic species (see Dolling &amp; Yonke, 1976) are mutually very similar and have strictly<tei:lb/>parapatric distributions, suggesting recent entry into and radiation within the region. Species of<tei:lb/>Coriomeris are found within the Arctic Circle in Alaska, Yakutia and Karelia, so there would<tei:lb/>seem to be no climatic barrier to migration across the Bering Straits even today.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ceraleptus Costa has five Palaearctic and four Nearctic species, none of them shared between<tei:lb/>the two regions. Its nearest relatives appear to be Microtelocerus Reuter and Urartucoris<tei:lb/>Puchkov, both genera with very restricted distributions in the mountains of the central southern<tei:lb/>Palaearctic, so a Palaearctic origin for Ceraleptus seems probable. Its American species are<tei:lb/>rather diverse and fall geographically into two pairs, one pair sympatric along the Pacific coast of<tei:lb/>North America and the other pair sympatric in the south-eastern U.S.A. (Froeschner, 1963).<tei:lb/>Members of the genus do not occur at such high latitudes as the extremes penetrated by<tei:lb/>Coriomeris and this fact, coupled with the greater diversity and more complex distribution<tei:lb/>pattern shown by the species of Ceraleptus, suggests that the genus has been present in the<tei:lb/>Nearctic region longer than has Coriomeris, presumably arriving in one or more immigration<tei:lb/>episodes during an era of warmer climate than that of the present day.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Palaearctic</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Twelve genera and about 39 species of Pseudophloeini occur in the Palaearctic region; only one<tei:lb/>of these species is shared with another region: Arenocoris intermedius , whose range includes<tei:lb/>western temperate Asia, Iberia and the northern coastal countries of Africa and extends<tei:lb/>southwards into Chad and Ethiopia. As indicated above, the Palaearctic genera Coriomeris and<tei:lb/>Ceraleptus have both entered North America and have endemic species there.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Palaearctic intrusions of two species of the tribe Clavigrallini, Clavigralla scutellaris (into<tei:lb/>Afghanistan) and Gralliclava horrens (into Japan) are mentioned below; no other genus of the<tei:lb/>subfamily is represented in both the Palaearctic and Afrotropical or the Palaearctic and Oriental<tei:lb/>regions.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Afrotropical and Oriental Clavigrallini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The well-defined tribe Clavigrallini comprises four genera whose interrelationships are unclear.<tei:lb/>With the exception of two minor intrusions into the Palaearctic region, mentioned below, the<tei:lb/>tribe is confined to the tropical regions of the Old World.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Clavigralla Spinola is the largest genus of Pseudophloeinae, with 46 described species. It has<tei:lb/>clearly undergone most of its radiation on the African mainland, where 38 of its species are<tei:lb/>found. Only one species, C. elongata Signoret, which is widespread on the African mainland, is<tei:lb/>present on the smaller offshore Afrotropical islands. It has reached Sao Tome and the Cape<tei:lb/>Verde Islands in the Atlantic (Dolling, 1979a: 28 erroneously reported it from the Canary<tei:lb/>Islands on the basis of a mislabelled specimen from the Wollaston collection; the card bears a</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>TRIBE PSEUDOPHLOEINI 207</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Table 2 Number of species of each genus of Pseudophloeinae in the regions indicated. Species occurring<tei:lb/>in more than one region are scored in parentheses in regions other than those of their putative origin as<tei:lb/>are genera with no endemic species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Anoplocerus, Bathysolen, Bothrostethus, Loxocnemis, Microtelocerus, Nemocoris, Strobilotoma, Ulmicola, Urar-<tei:lb/>tucoris.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>colour-coded mark that indicates its true provenance as the Cape Verde Islands), and Madagas-<tei:lb/>car, Mauritius, Reunion, Rodriguez and the Seychelles in the Indian Ocean. It has also been<tei:lb/>reported from Arabia. In 1979 1 had seen no specimens of the species from the mainland of West<tei:lb/>Africa, where it seems to be largely replaced by C. shadabi Dolling and C. breviceps Dolling. I<tei:lb/>have now seen specimens of it from two localities in Senegal. C. elongata is the only<tei:lb/>representative of the subfamily in these Atlantic and Indian Ocean islands with the exception of<tei:lb/>six endemic species in Madagascar. One of these, C. tuberculicollis (Reuter), is a taxonomically<tei:lb/>isolated species with several plesiomorphic features; it has probably been present in Madagascar<tei:lb/>much longer than any other species of the tribe. Three Malagasy species are closely similar to C.<tei:lb/>elongata and may be either local derivatives of it or descendants of a single, elongata-like<tei:lb/>immigrant. The other two endemics are members of the C. tomentosicollis Stal group but belong<tei:lb/>to different subgroups and clearly derive from two separate immigrations. Thus, Madagascar<tei:lb/>seems to have been colonized on at least four and possibly five separate occasions by<tei:lb/>Clavigrallini, but there is evidence for local radiation stemming from only one of these invasions.<tei:lb/>Clavigralla is evidently a recent arrival in the Oriental region. Its three Oriental species all<tei:lb/>belong to the same subgroup of the tomentosicollis-group. One of them, C. scutellaris (West-<tei:lb/>wood), which is probably the sister-species of C. tomentosicollis, is also found in north-eastern<tei:lb/>Africa and Arabia; in Asia it extends as far northwards as Afghanistan. The other two are<tei:lb/>vicariant sister-species, one confined to Sri Lanka and southern India and the other distributed<tei:lb/>from northern India to southern China and Vietnam; the Indian population of this second<tei:lb/>species is recognizably distinct from the populations further east.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>208 W. R. DOLLING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Oncaspidia Stal has a single, widespread species endemic to Africa.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Clavigralloides Dolling has the most easterly centre of distribution of any genus of Pseudo-<tei:lb/>phloeinae. Three of its five species occur in New Guinea; one of these three is, so far as is known,<tei:lb/>endemic while the other two extend southwards into northern Australia and one of these also<tei:lb/>spreads northwards to southern China. Closely related to these two is a species restricted to the<tei:lb/>Lesser Sunda Islands. The fifth member of the genus is rather isolated taxonomically and is<tei:lb/>divided into northern Indian and a southern Chinese subspecies.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gralliclava Dolling species are distributed from India to Australia. They fall into two groups,<tei:lb/>one with a plesiomorphic condition of the male genital capsule and a variety of unusual<tei:lb/>paramere shapes, and the other with an apomorphic condition of the capsule and rather uniform<tei:lb/>parameres. The first group comprises six known species with restricted distributions; three of<tei:lb/>these are Indian; one is found in the Himalayas and at high altitudes in southern China and Laos,<tei:lb/>one is known only from its high altitude type-locality in Java and one, surprisingly, is known<tei:lb/>from a single specimen taken on a small Australian island in the Torres Strait. The four species of<tei:lb/>the second group between them occupy an almost continuous range from Sri Lanka and India to<tei:lb/>Japan, the Solomon Islands and tropical Australia. One is known from two specimens, one from<tei:lb/>Timor and the other from Flores. The most widespread species, G. horrens Dohrn, is also<tei:lb/>known from Timor, from Wetter and the Sulawesi group, and thence northwards to Japan<tei:lb/>(Japanese records, all from Kyushu, are summarized by Kawazawa, 1978) and westwards to<tei:lb/>India and Sri Lanka. A third species is common in New Guinea and is also recorded from<tei:lb/>Ambon and the Admiralty, Bismarck and Solomon groups. The fourth species has been<tei:lb/>collected from many localities in Queensland and the Northern Territory of Australia but it has<tei:lb/>never been found elsewhere, nor has any other species of the genus been taken in Australia. The<tei:lb/>almost complete allopatry of these four species and the fact that the Torres Strait separates two<tei:lb/>of them suggests a very recent radiation of this group.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Afrotropical and Oriental Pseudophloeini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Apart from the intrusive Arenocoris intermedius , the present revision recognizes seven genera<tei:lb/>with 25 species in the Afrotropical region and six genera with 17 species in the Oriental. Two of<tei:lb/>these genera and none of the species are shared between the two regions. The largest genera are<tei:lb/>the wholly Afrotropical My la, with 11 species, and the shared Psilolomia, with 13.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Risbecocoris , with five described species, occupies a probably almost continuous belt of<tei:lb/>grassland and semi-desert from Senegal via Arabia to Delhi, taking in the Air mountains and<tei:lb/>northern Kenya as well. This type of habitat has probably been available in the area for a very<tei:lb/>long time and dispersal across it between Africa and Asia would present no problems for an<tei:lb/>organism as well adapted to it as is Risbecocoris. It makes little sense to attribute part of this arid<tei:lb/>zone to the Afrotropical region and part to the Oriental in the context of the biogeography of<tei:lb/>such organisms.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Psilolomia displays its greatest diversity in the Oriental region. A group of dark-coloured<tei:lb/>species, whose characteristic habitat is probably forest clearings, extends no further westwards<tei:lb/>than eastern India while a group of yellowish species, probably characteristic of dry, open<tei:lb/>woodland, is distributed from West Africa to South East Asia. Only four species of this group<tei:lb/>occur in Africa; they have had little or no success south of the Equator. One of them, Psilolomia<tei:lb/>nigeriensis, shows a tendency to split into northern and southern races in Nigeria, perhaps in<tei:lb/>response to differing climatic conditions. A single migration in the fairly recent past from India<tei:lb/>into Africa via a more humid Arabia seems the most probable explanation for its occurrence in<tei:lb/>both continents. Large areas of apparently suitable terrain remain unoccupied by this genus in<tei:lb/>eastern and southern Africa.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mevanidea is the only genus of Pseudophloeinae, apart from Clavigralla, to have been found<tei:lb/>in Madagascar. The two species of the genus show classic allopatry, one in mainland Africa and<tei:lb/>the other endemic to Madagascar.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>TRIBE PSEUDOPHLOEINI 209</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Discussion</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The faunistic picture that emerges is one of greatest diversity in the tropics of the Old World with<tei:lb/>rather less diverse but long established faunas in the Palaearctic and Neotropical regions. The<tei:lb/>Neotropical and Palaearctic faunas seem to have developed in almost complete isolation from<tei:lb/>each other and from the Palaeotropical faunas. The Nearctic region, Australia and Madagascar<tei:lb/>have no endemic genera and have played only a peripheral part in the evolutionary history of the<tei:lb/>subfamily. Apart from Risbecocoris, whose range is in a transitional zone, only one genus,<tei:lb/>Psilolomia, is shared between the Oriental and Afrotropical regions. It is the only genus that can<tei:lb/>be shown to have successfully invaded and begun to diversify in a region where a diverse<tei:lb/>pseudophloeine fauna was already present.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The genus Vilga has evidently been present in the Neotropics for a very long time, perhaps<tei:lb/>since before the opening of the Atlantic Ocean; this would place the early radiation of the<tei:lb/>subfamily before the end of the Cretaceous period. Among tropical Coreoidea it is frequently<tei:lb/>the case that the distribution of the subfamilies is pantropical while the tribes are restricted to<tei:lb/>either the Old World or the New.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dense forest and water seem to have been very effective barriers to dispersal of Pseudo-<tei:lb/>phloeini but less effective in the case of Clavigrallini. The more elongate condition of the<tei:lb/>hemelytra of the latter, with a tendency for the corium to extend apically along the costal margin<tei:lb/>of the hemelytron, and the deeper thorax, presumably housing larger flight-muscles, are<tei:lb/>suggestive of a more sustained power of flight which would enable its possessor to overcome the<tei:lb/>obstacles that inhibit the dispersal of Pseudophloeini. The distribution patterns of two groups of<tei:lb/>recently differentiated species illustrate this difference in dispersal ability, and hence in rates of<tei:lb/>genetic interchange. The genus Coriomeris in North America has split into four recognizably<tei:lb/>distinct though closely related species without any intervening barriers of forest or water,<tei:lb/>whereas the species of the horrens-group of the clavigralline genus Gralliclava are, with one very<tei:lb/>minor exception, separated by sea barriers. Parapatric speciation may also be in progress in the<tei:lb/>case of the northern and southern forms of Psilolomia nigeriensis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acknowledgements</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Occasional Papers on Systematic Entomology</tei:p>
         <tei:p>New Series</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The economic importance of insects, and the enormous number of species, have resulted in a<tei:lb/>vast literature written in many languages; that which is of direct economic importance and<tei:lb/>recently published can, to an increasing extent, be searched by using computerized data bases,<tei:lb/>but a great amount of more general information is unlikely to be available so readily in the<tei:lb/>near future. The objective of this new occasional series is to make available in hard copy some<tei:lb/>of the basic data that is essential to the preparation of comprehensive accounts of the world<tei:lb/>insect fauna. The papers have been fully researched bibliographically and consist of checklists<tei:lb/>of nominal taxa, and faunal lists with information on host plants and localities, based mainly<tei:lb/>on the collections and libraries of the British Museum (Natural History).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>No. 1. A checklist of Neotropical arctiine and pericopine tiger moths.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A. Watson &amp; D. T. Goodger</tei:p>
         <tei:p>72pp. inc. 4 colour plates 27 February 1986</tei:p>
         <tei:p>No. 2. An annotated checklist of the Carabidae (including Cicindelinae, Rhysodinae and</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paussinae) recorded from Borneo.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>N. E. Stork</tei:p>
         <tei:p>26pp. , 1 map 29 May 1986</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Catalogues of BM (NH) Bulletins and Books free on request to Publication Sales.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>

         <tei:p>pRr</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bulletin of the</tei:p>
         <tei:p>British Museum (Natural History)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The songs of the western European<tei:lb/>grasshoppers of the genus Omocestus in<tei:lb/>relation to their taxonomy (Orthoptera:<tei:lb/>Acrididae)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>D. R. Ragge</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Entomology series</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vol53 No 4 27 November 1986</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>The Bulletin of the British Museum (Natural History), instituted in 1949, is issued in four<tei:lb/>scientific series, Botany, Entomology, Geology (incorporating Mineralogy) and Zoology,<tei:lb/>and an Historical series.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Papers in the Bulletin are primarily the results of research carried out on the unique and<tei:lb/>ever-growing collections of the Museum, both by the scientific staff of the Museum and by<tei:lb/>specialists from elsewhere who make use of the Museum's resources. Many of the papers are<tei:lb/>works of reference that will remain indispensable for years to come.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Parts are published at irregular intervals as they become ready, each is complete in itself,<tei:lb/>available separately, and individually priced. Volumes contain about 300 pages and several<tei:lb/>volumes may appear within a calendar year. Subscriptions may be placed for one or more of<tei:lb/>the series on either an Annual or Per Volume basis. Prices vary according to the contents of<tei:lb/>the individual parts. Orders and enquiries should be sent to:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Publications Sales,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>British Museum (Natural History),<tei:lb/>Cromwell Road,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>London SW75BD,<tei:lb/>England.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>World List abbreviation: Bull. Br. Mus. nat. Hist. (Ent.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>"rustees of the British Museum (Natural History), 1986</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Entomology series is produced under the general editorship of the</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Keeper of Entomology: Laurence A. Mound</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Assistant Editor: W. Gerald Tremewan</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ISBN 565 06022 8<tei:lb/>ISSN 0524-6431</tei:p>
         <tei:p>British Museum (Natural History)<tei:lb/>Cromwell Road<tei:lb/>London SW7 5BD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Entomology series<tei:lb/>Vol53No4pp213-249</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Issued 27 November 1986</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>The songs of the western European grasshoppers of<tei:lb/>the genus Omocestus in relation to their taxonomy<tei:lb/>(Orthoptera: Acrididae)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>D. R. Ragge</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Department of Entomology, British Museum (Natural History), Cromwell Road, London<tei:lb/>SW75BD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Contents</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Synopsis 213</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Introduction 213</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acknowledgements 214</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abbreviations of depositories 214</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Methods 215</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Recording and analysing the songs 215</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Song terminology 215</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Presentation 215</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The song as a taxonomic character 219</tei:p>
         <tei:p>New lectotype designations 220</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Omocestus Bolivar 221</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Keys to the principal western European species of Omocestus 222</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key based primarily on morphological characters 222</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key based on song characters 224</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The songs of the western European Omocestus 226</tei:p>
         <tei:p>References .- 246</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Index 249</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Synopsis</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The male calling songs of 11 western European and one Canary Island species of the Gomphocerine genus<tei:lb/>Omocestus are described and fully illustrated with oscillograms at three or four different speeds. The<tei:lb/>courtship song is also described for the six species in which such a song is known. The songs of six species<tei:lb/>(panteli, bolivari, uhagonii, minutissimus, llorenteae and simony i} are described for the first time. For each<tei:lb/>species a full list is provided of references to any past published work on the songs, classified according to<tei:lb/>the kind of information given. Notes on recognition, using both morphology and song, are given for each<tei:lb/>species, and two identification keys are provided, one based mainly on morphology and the other on song.<tei:lb/>The value of the song as a taxonomic character is discussed.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Introduction</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Gomphocerinae, of which Omocestus is one of the better known Old World genera, include<tei:lb/>most of the common European grasshoppers of open grassland and moorland. They produce the<tei:lb/>most highly developed communicative sounds of all grasshoppers and are widely used in<tei:lb/>bio-acoustic, ecological and cytogenetic research. The subfamily includes about 150 European<tei:lb/>species, of which over 20 are pests in parts of their range, seven of them being regarded as major<tei:lb/>ones (Tsyplenkov, 1970).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Omocestus is a widespread Palaearctic genus, including some 40 species living in habitats<tei:lb/>ranging from lush lowland meadow to steppe, open woodland and high mountains. Twenty<tei:lb/>species have been recorded from western Europe, of which three, rufipes, petraeus and<tei:lb/>particularly haemorrhoidalis , become pests when they occur in sufficient numbers, causing<tei:lb/>damage to cereal grasses, hayfields, alfalfa and other cultivated plants in western and,<tei:lb/>especially, eastern Europe (Bei-Bienko &amp; Mishchenko, 1951; Tsyplenkov, 1970).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The conspicuous songs of Gomphocerine grasshoppers have attracted attention for centuries,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bull. Br. Mus. not. Hist. (Ent.) 53 (4): 213-249 Issued 27 November 1986</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>214 D. R. RAGGE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>but it is only since the pioneering work of Faber (1928) that they have been considered seriously<tei:lb/>as an aid to identification, and only during the past 30 years that their importance in taxonomic<tei:lb/>research, and particularly in resolving complexes of sibling species, has been fully recognized.<tei:lb/>This importance stems from the current belief that they provide the main mate recognition<tei:lb/>system in these insects and are thus able to maintain reproductive isolation in groups of<tei:lb/>sympatric species that would otherwise be able to interbreed freely. Perdeck (1957) established<tei:lb/>experimentally that this is true of the well-known sibling pair Chorthippus brunneus (Thunberg)<tei:lb/>and C. biguttulus (Linnaeus), and, although comparable studies on other groups of Gom-<tei:lb/>phocerinae are still greatly needed, it seems likely that such studies would confirm that this<tei:lb/>function of the song is widespread in the subfamily.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Grasshopper songs can be quite easily recorded on tape and their rhythmic patterns, which<tei:lb/>provide the most useful taxonomic information, lend themselves well to oscillographic analysis.<tei:lb/>It is thus rather surprising that there has so far been no comprehensive account of these songs,<tei:lb/>presented group by group and illustrated with oscillograms. The main aim of the present paper,<tei:lb/>and of similar papers in preparation on other groups of Orthoptera, is to provide such an<tei:lb/>account, arranged systematically by group and fully illustrated with oscillograms at several<tei:lb/>different speeds. It is hoped that this form of presentation will make the information most useful<tei:lb/>in identification and taxonomy, as well as providing a basic reference work on the songs of these<tei:lb/>insects.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>No information has previously been published on the songs of six of the 12 species included in<tei:lb/>this study (panteli, bolivari, uhagonii, minutissimus, llorenteae and simonyi) and no oscillograms<tei:lb/>have previously been published for a further two (petraeus and raymondi). For the species in<tei:lb/>which published information on the song is already available, references to the sources are<tei:lb/>given, classified according to the kind of information published. O. simonyi, known only from<tei:lb/>the Canary Islands, is not strictly within the scope of this paper but is included for convenience.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The song is still unknown in the following nine species of Omocestus recorded from western<tei:lb/>Europe: antigai, burri, corsicus, femoralis, kaestneri, knipperi, lopadusae, navasi and uvarovi.<tei:lb/>These species, which are all very local and often of doubtful status, are therefore excluded from<tei:lb/>this study.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acknowledgements</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I am much indebted to the following, who have kindly lent me type-specimens or other material from their<tei:lb/>respective institutions: Drs R. Danielsson, M. Donskoff, P. Grootaert, K. K. Giinther, A. Kaltenbach, V.<tei:lb/>Llorente, F. Pascual and J. J. Presa.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>My thanks are also due to Dr N. D. Jago, who kindly provided me with tape recordings of the song of O.<tei:lb/>viridulus made by him in the French Alps; to Mr W. G. Tremewan, who was kind enough to collect live<tei:lb/>males of O. panteli for me in Teruel Province, Spain; and to Mr B. Alexander, who kindly brought me a live<tei:lb/>male of O. simonyi from Lanzarote, Canary Islands.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I am particularly grateful to my colleague Mr W. J. Reynolds, who made the studio recordings used in<tei:lb/>this study, helped me in reviewing the past literature on the songs, tested the identification key based on<tei:lb/>morphological characters and provided valuable comments at various stages in the preparation of the<tei:lb/>paper.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Finally I wish to thank my wife, who has given me invaluable help in all my field-work.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abbreviations of depositories</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BMNH British Museum (Natural History), London</tei:p>
         <tei:p>IRSNB Institut Royal des Sciences Naturelles de Belgique, Brussels</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MNCN Museo Nacional de Ciencias Naturales, Madrid</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MNHN Museum National d'Histoire Naturelle, Paris</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MNHU Museum fur Naturkunde der Humboldt-Universitat, Berlin</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ZI Zoologiska Institution, Lunds Universitet, Lund</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>SONGS OF THE WESTERN EUROPEAN OMOCESTUS 215</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Methods</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Recording and analysing the songs</tei:p>
         <tei:p>All the field recordings of the songs used in this study were made while the insects were in full<tei:lb/>sunshine using a Uher 4000, 4200 or 4200IC tape recorder and AKG D202 or (recording 222/3<tei:lb/>only) Shibaden microphone; the tape speed was always 19 cm/s. The subjects were approached<tei:lb/>stealthily so that the microphone could be held (or rested on the ground) about 10 cm from them<tei:lb/>without causing any disturbance.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The studio recordings were made in the BMNH Acoustic Laboratory using a Kudelski Nagra<tei:lb/>IV tape recorder and Sennheiser MKH405 microphone; the tape speed was 19 or 38 cm/s. In<tei:lb/>every case a bench lamp was used to provide light and radiant heat.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Further data are given in Tables 1 and 2 for the recordings used for the oscillograms<tei:lb/>reproduced in Figs 12-128. However, the song descriptions given for each species are in most<tei:lb/>cases based on many more recordings of numerous songs, all of which were analysed oscillo-<tei:lb/>graphically. The oscillograms reproduced in the figures were chosen as being typical of the<tei:lb/>species concerned and, in some cases, showing the extent of intraspecific variation. Although I<tei:lb/>have given in Tables 1 and 2 the ambient air temperatures at the time of recording, it is really the<tei:lb/>body temperature of the singing insect that is important, and this is more dependent on radiant<tei:lb/>heat than on the air temperature; as the insects were always receiving radiant heat from the sun<tei:lb/>or a bench lamp, the conditions under which the recordings were made were more uniform than<tei:lb/>the different air temperatures might suggest.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>All the oscillograms were made from recorded songs with a Mingograf 34T ink- jet recorder.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Song terminology</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The bio-acoustic terms used are defined as follows.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Calling song. The song produced by an isolated male.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Courtship song. The special song produced by a male when close to a female.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Syllable. The sound produced by one complete up and down movement of the hind legs</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig- 1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Echeme. A first-order assemblage of syllables (Fig. 1).<tei:lb/>Echeme-sequence. A first-order assemblage of echemes (Fig. 1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Momentary breaks in the sound (of at least 1-25 ms) during the course of a syllable are<tei:lb/>referred to as 'gaps'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Presentation</tei:p>
         <tei:p>As the main purpose of this paper is to give information on songs, I have not included either a full<tei:lb/>synonymy or a formal morphological diagnosis in the account of each species. I have, however,<tei:lb/>listed references to all past descriptive accounts of the songs (of any significance), classified<tei:lb/>according to whether they include oscillograms (including sound-level tracings), diagrams (i.e.<tei:lb/>hand-drawn representations of the songs), frequency information, musical notation, or verbal<tei:lb/>description without any of these additions; any commercially available disc or cassette record-<tei:lb/>ings of the songs are also listed. These references are not intended to be exhaustive - there are<tei:lb/>many brief statements about the songs, especially in the earlier literature, that do not warrant<tei:lb/>inclusion; my aim has been to list all sources that the reader might find useful to refer to for<tei:lb/>additional or confirmatory information on the songs. The only reference I have included to a<tei:lb/>work published before the present century is to Yersin's (1854) short but admirable account of<tei:lb/>the songs of 38 European species of Orthoptera (including two of Omocestus), in which he<tei:lb/>attempted, with some success, to represent them in terms of musical notation; in this largely<tei:lb/>forgotten work he demonstrated clearly for the first time the striking differences between the<tei:lb/>songs of the three closely similar species Chorthippus brunneus (Thunberg), C. biguttulus<tei:lb/>(Linnaeus) and C. mollis (Charpentier).<tei:lb/>Notes are given for each species on recognition by both morphology and song, and these are</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>216</tei:p>

         <tei:p>ECHEME</tei:p>

         <tei:p>SYLLABLE</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Omocesfus raymonc/i</tei:p>
