         <tei:p>I 0-05 s</tei:p>
         <tei:p>+-*</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HMH-H &gt; I</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ECHEME</tei:p>
         <tei:p>0-05 s</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Omocesfus pefraeus</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 1 Oscillograms of the male calling songs of two species of Omocestus, showing the terminology used<tei:lb/>in this paper.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>SONGS OF THE WESTERN EUROPEAN OMOCESTUS 219</tei:p>
         <tei:p>followed by a more detailed descriptive account of the calling song and, when known, courtship<tei:lb/>song. I have not attempted to describe any further kinds of sound produced by the males (e.g.<tei:lb/>'rivalry song', 'copulation song') as these are not stereotypically patterned and seldom of<tei:lb/>diagnostic value. Neither have I considered it appropriate to describe the songs produced by<tei:lb/>females when in a sexually receptive state; these songs are seldom heard in the field and are in<tei:lb/>any case broadly similar in pattern to the calling songs of conspecific males.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The songs of each species are illustrated by oscillograms at three, or sometimes four, different<tei:lb/>speeds. As the scale lines indicate, the three speeds given for all species are (after reduction for<tei:lb/>printing) 10 mm/s, 80 mm/s and 320 mm/s, and the fourth speed included for the songs of three<tei:lb/>species (see below) is 1280 mm/s. In addition, oscillograms at 10 mm/s of typical male calling<tei:lb/>songs of all 12 species are shown together in Figs 12-23 so that the more obvious differences<tei:lb/>between them can be seen at a glance.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Grasshopper songs are normally produced by both hind legs being rubbed simultaneously<tei:lb/>against the fore wings, and oscillograms of such 'two-legged' songs show the sounds produced by<tei:lb/>the movement of one hind leg superimposed on those produced by the other. The two hind legs<tei:lb/>are not always well synchronized and in some species follow different patterns of movement, so<tei:lb/>that there is sometimes a degree of 'blurring' of the oscillogram. Moreover, in 'two-legged'<tei:lb/>oscillograms that are fast enough to show the impacts of individual stridulatory pegs, it is<tei:lb/>impossible to determine which peg-impacts are produced by one leg since these are mixed with<tei:lb/>those produced by the other. Although these points are not particularly relevant to the<tei:lb/>diagnostic value of the songs, I have thought it worth including for three species (viridulus,<tei:lb/>rufipes and panteli} oscillograms taken from the calling songs of males with only one hind leg.<tei:lb/>The difference between the 'one-legged' and 'two-legged' oscillograms is hardly apparent at the<tei:lb/>slower speeds, but becomes more obvious at 320 mm/s and clearer still at 1280 mm/s. The highest<tei:lb/>speed 'one-legged' oscillogram of panteli (Fig. 89) shows the individual peg-impacts with<tei:lb/>particular clarity.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The song as a taxonomic character</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Recognition of the diagnostic value of the songs of Orthoptera may be said to have begun in the<tei:lb/>mid-nineteenth century, when Fischer (1849, 1850, 1853) published a number of song descrip-<tei:lb/>tions in primarily faunal or systematic works, and Yersin (1852, 1853 and especially 1854)<tei:lb/>produced a series of papers specifically on the songs and their value in identification. Yersin's<tei:lb/>work of 1854, in which he described the songs of 38 European species of Orthoptera, was<tei:lb/>particularly noteworthy in that it included the first attempt to illustrate the songs graphically, in<tei:lb/>the form of musical notation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Little further progress was made in exploiting the songs in taxonomy until Faber's work of<tei:lb/>1928, in which he gave, for the first time, an identification key to the German Orthoptera based<tei:lb/>on their songs. Many German studies on the songs of the European Orthoptera followed,<tei:lb/>notably by Faber (especially 1929, 1932 and 1936) and Jacobs (especially 1950), culminating in<tei:lb/>two major works published almost simultaneously (Faber, 1953; Jacobs, 1953). Most of this<tei:lb/>work was concerned with the detailed description of the songs and associated behaviour, and<tei:lb/>there was still no serious attempt to use the songs in taxonomic research.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Jacobs (1950, 1953) used simple diagrams against a time scale to illustrate the rhythmic<tei:lb/>patterns of the songs. Ragge (1965) introduced a more sophisticated kind of diagram, amounting<tei:lb/>to a simplified oscillogram, and diagrams of this kind have since been used by Hoist (1970),<tei:lb/>Luquet (1978), Wallin (1979) and, in a slightly different form, by Duijm &amp; Kruseman (1983) and<tei:lb/>Bellmann (1985). Identification keys based on the songs were provided, for restricted parts of<tei:lb/>Europe, by Luquet (the Mont Ventoux area of the French Alps, Acrididae only), Wallin<tei:lb/>(Sweden), Duijm &amp; Kruseman (Benelux) and Bellmann (West Germany). All these studies are<tei:lb/>concerned with regional faunas and contain no taxonomic research, although Luquet gives much<tei:lb/>emphasis to the importance of the songs in taxonomy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The first serious application of the songs of Orthoptera to their taxonomy was in work on the<tei:lb/>North American crickets (Gryllidae). Following the pioneering work of Fulton (1931, 1952),</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>220 D. R. RAGGE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Alexander (1957) and Alexander &amp; Thomas (1959) reviewed the taxonomy of North American<tei:lb/>species of Acheta and Nemobius, and Walker (1962, 1963) carried out similar studies on<tei:lb/>Oecanthinae; in all these studies the songs played a crucial part in resolving the taxonomy of<tei:lb/>morphologically similar species. Similar work on other groups followed, some of it reviewed by<tei:lb/>Alexander (1962) and Walker (1964). In 1972 Alexander, Pace &amp; Otte produced an account of<tei:lb/>the 'singing insects' of Michigan in which they gave keys based mainly on the songs for all the<tei:lb/>Ensifera.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>More recent taxonomic studies on Orthoptera in which the songs have played a significant part<tei:lb/>include those of Bailey (1975, 1980) on African and Australian Copiphorine Tettigoniidae,<tei:lb/>Walker &amp; Greenfield (1983) on Caribbean Neoconocephalus (Tettigoniidae), Otte &amp; Alexander</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(1983) on Australian Gryllidae, Otte &amp; Cade (1983 and later) on African Gryllidae, Heller</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(1984) on Poecilimon (Tettigoniidae) and Ragge &amp; Reynolds (1984) on western European<tei:lb/>Euchorthippus (Acrididae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>As can be seen at a glance from Figs 12-23, the male calling songs of the western European<tei:lb/>species of Omocestus provide most useful taxonomic characters. Recorded songs, with<tei:lb/>appropriate oscillographic analyses, can be used to identify the species even if no specimens are<tei:lb/>available for morphological study (see the key on p. 224).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The calling songs of the 12 species embraced by the present study fall into two clearly different<tei:lb/>kinds: the rapid sequence of echemes produced by petraeus, minutissimus and llorenteae, and<tei:lb/>the single or widely separated echemes produced by the remaining species. As would be<tei:lb/>expected, the rapidly repeated echemes of petraeus, minutissimus and llorenteae are composed<tei:lb/>of very rapidly repeated syllables, almost always more than 80/s, whereas the syllable repetition<tei:lb/>rate of the remaining species is almost always less than 40/s. Within this trio of species petraeus<tei:lb/>stands a little apart from the other two in having even shorter and more rapidly repeated<tei:lb/>echemes, but the songs of minutissimus and llorenteae are broadly similar to each other in<tei:lb/>pattern, differing mainly in the duration of the echeme-sequence and the number of echemes of<tei:lb/>which it is composed.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Among the remaining species, viridulus and rufipes have much longer echemes than all the<tei:lb/>others; they are very similar to each other in both calling and courtship songs, differing mainly in<tei:lb/>the duration of the calling song echeme. The songs of all the other species consist of relatively<tei:lb/>short echemes distinguished from one another by duration, syllable repetition rate, and number<tei:lb/>and distribution of gaps. The song differences shown by the four brachypterous species bolivari,<tei:lb/>uhagonii, minutissimus and llorenteae are particularly useful for field identification; two or three<tei:lb/>of these species sometimes occur together in the same locality and are sufficiently similar in<tei:lb/>appearance to be quite easily confused with one another.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Extreme caution has to be used in drawing phylogenetic conclusions from resemblances or<tei:lb/>differences in grasshopper songs, since it is well known from studies on the Chorthippus<tei:lb/>biguttulus group that apparently closely related species, capable of producing vigorous and<tei:lb/>fertile hybrids, can have strikingly different songs. From the known songs of Omocestus I am<tei:lb/>inclined to make such inferences in only two cases of song resemblance. The first is the<tei:lb/>well-known pair viridulus and rufipes, in which the strong resemblance in both calling and<tei:lb/>courtship songs suggests that they are sister species. The second is the pair of brachypterous,<tei:lb/>montane species minutissimus and llorenteae, in which the close resemblance in calling song (as<tei:lb/>well as morphology) also suggests a comparatively recent common ancestry.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>New lectotype designations</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In the course of examining type-material I have taken the opportunity of designating lectotypes<tei:lb/>for the following species included in this study.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gryllus rufipes Zetterstedt, 1821: 90.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Following Ander (1943: 10) I am regarding only two adult males from Zetterstedt's original material (in the</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ZI, Lund) as being eligible as syntypes, and I have selected and labelled one of these, bearing Zetterstedt's</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>SONGS OF THE WESTERN EUROPEAN OMOCESTUS 221</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ochre-yellow label (indicating Ostergotland), as lectotype. I have labelled the other eligible adult male,<tei:lb/>which bears no colour-coded label, as a paralectotype.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acridium petraeum Brisout, 1855: cxiv.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>There is in the IRSNB, Brussels a long series of both sexes of this species, all labelled 'Lardy', the<tei:lb/>type-locality. These specimens are also labelled as being from the collection of de Selys Longchamps, who<tei:lb/>had earlier acquired Brisout's collection, and it seems almost certain that they include at least part of<tei:lb/>Brisout's type-series. I have selected and labelled a male bearing the handwritten label 'Lardy pres de<tei:lb/>Paris' as lectotype. As there are many other specimens of this and various other species of Omocestus (and<tei:lb/>other genera) in the de Selys Longchamps Collection labelled 'Lardy', I have not attempted to determine<tei:lb/>which of these are also likely to belong to Brisout's type-series and so have labelled no specimens as<tei:lb/>paralectotypes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Stenobothrus Brolemanni Azam, 1906: 128.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dr M. Donskoff of the MNHN, Paris has kindly sent me the male from Azam's type-series that seems most</tei:p>
         <tei:p>eligible as a lectotype and I have so-labelled it.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Omocestus BolivariChopard, 1939: 172.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The type-series of this species (in the MNHN, Paris) consists of one male and one female, and I have<tei:lb/>selected and labelled the male as lectotype. The altitude given in the original description, '2000 m.<tei:lb/>environ', clashes with the '3000 m' given on the locality label, which I think is more likely to be accurate. I<tei:lb/>have labelled the female as a paralectotype.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gomphocerus (Stenobothrus) Uhagonii Bolivar, 1876: 324.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dr J. J. Presa of the Universidad de Murcia very kindly delivered to me by hand a male syntype of this<tei:lb/>species (from the MNCN, Madrid) labelled as being from Navarredonda, one of the type-localities, and I<tei:lb/>have labelled it as lectotype.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>OMOCESTUS Bolivar</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Omocestus Bolivar, 1878: 427 [as subgenus of Gomphocerus Thunberg]; Burr, 1904: 320 [raised to genus].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Type-species: Gryllus Locusta viridulus Linnaeus, by subsequent designation (Kirby, 1910: 172).<tei:lb/>Dirshius Harz, 1975: 710 [as subgenus of Omocestus Bolivar]. Type-species: Gryllus haemorrhoidalis</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Charpentier, by original designation. Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS, cf $ Head of typical Gomphocerine shape, foveolae well developed. Antennae not clubbed.<tei:lb/>Pronotal lateral carinae varying from sharply incurved to almost straight. Brachypterous to macropterous.<tei:lb/>Fore wings without bulge on anterior margin of precostal area; medial area not conspicuously widened<tei:lb/>(except in O. uvarovi Zanon , whose generic assignment is uncertain) . Hind wings varying from transparent<tei:lb/>to strongly smoky. Ovipositor varying in length, normally without lateral teeth but sometimes showing<tei:lb/>tendency towards their development (e.g. O. broelemanni). Tympanal aperture slit-like.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISCUSSION. Omocestus can be defined only on negative characters: it lacks the precostal bulge of<tei:lb/>Chorthippus Fieber, the toothed ovipositor of Stenobothrus Fischer, and the clubbed antennae of<tei:lb/>Gomphocerus Thunberg, Gomphocerippus Roberts and Myrmeleotettix Bolivar. Like several other genera<tei:lb/>in the large and rather intractable subfamily Gomphocerinae, it is no more than a group of convenience and<tei:lb/>is very unlikely to be holophyletic. Harz (1975) attempted to split it into two subgenera on the basis of the<tei:lb/>degree of curvature of the pronotal lateral carinae, but the species show every gradation between sharply<tei:lb/>incurved and almost straight carinae, and it is thus impossible to draw a clear dividing line between two<tei:lb/>subgroups.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Jago (1971) treated Omocestus as a subgenus of Stenobothrus, thus reverting to the status accorded to it<tei:lb/>by Bolivar (1897) and Yakobson &amp; Bianki (1902). Jago's study was based entirely on males, however, and<tei:lb/>so did not take into account the toothed ovipositor as the main diagnostic character of Stenobothrus s. str. I<tei:lb/>prefer to follow Harz (1975) and other recent workers on the European fauna in regarding this character as<tei:lb/>sufficient for a generic distinction. Jago also regarded Kirby 's designation of viridulus as the type-species of<tei:lb/>Omocestus as invalid on the grounds that, at the time of the original description of the genus, this species<tei:lb/>was listed by Bolivar (1878: 460) under Chorthippus rather than Omocestus. However, on p. 427 of<tei:lb/>Bolivar's work, where Omocestus is first established and diagnosed, viridulus is clearly included in it; the<tei:lb/>heading 'Chorthippus' in the list on p. 460 has clearly been inadvertently misplaced, appearing above<tei:lb/>rufipes instead of in its correct position above pullus. I am therefore accepting Kirby 's type-species<tei:lb/>designation as valid.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The male callings songs show a wide range of patterns in Omocestus, varying from the prolonged single</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>222 D. R. RAGGE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>echemes of viridulus and rufipes to the rapid sequence of short echemes oipetraeus. This is not in itself an<tei:lb/>indication of polyphyly, however, as some complexes of sibling grasshopper species that are capable of<tei:lb/>interbreeding (e.g. the Chorthippus biguttulus group) show equally striking differences in male calling<tei:lb/>song.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. All Europe, the larger Mediterranean islands, North Africa and temperate Asia as far as<tei:lb/>China.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>INCLUDED SPECIES. O. alluaudi Uvarov, O. antigai (Bolivar), O. aymonissabaudiae Salfi, O. bolivari<tei:lb/>Chopard, O. broelemanni (Azam), O. burri Uvarov, O. caucasicus Tarbinskii, O. corsicus Chopard, O.<tei:lb/>cuonaensis Yin, O. demokidovi Ramme, O. enitor Uvarov, O. femoralis Bolivar, O. haemorrhoidalis<tei:lb/>(Charpentier), O. heymonsi (Ramme), O. hingstoni Uvarov, O.. kaestneri (Harz), O. knipperi Harz, O.<tei:lb/>lecerfi Chopard, O. lepineyi Chopard, O. llorenteae Pascual, O. lopadusae La Greca, O. lucasii (Brisout),<tei:lb/>O. minutissimus (Bolivar), O. minutus (Brulle), O. megaoculus Yin, O. motuoensis Yin, O. nanus Uvarov,<tei:lb/>O. navasi Bolivar, O. nyalamus Xia, O. panteli (Bolivar), O. petraeus (Brisout), O. raymondi (Yersin), O.<tei:lb/>rufipes (Zetterstedt), O. simony i (Krauss), O. tibetanus Uvarov, O. tzendsureni Giinther, O. uhagonii<tei:lb/>(Bolivar), O. uvarovi Zanon, O. viridulus (Linnaeus), O. znojkoi Mishchenko.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Keys to the principal western European species of Omocestus</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The only western European species not included in these keys are very local forms, usually of<tei:lb/>doubtful status, in which the song is so far unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Two keys are provided here, one based on morphological characters but with notes on song<tei:lb/>differences added where appropriate, and one based entirely on the male calling songs. Some of<tei:lb/>the species are very difficult to separate morphologically and, in the absence of song informa-<tei:lb/>tion, some specimens may not be correctly identified using the morphological key. Reference<tei:lb/>should in any case always be made to the notes given on recognition in the accounts of each<tei:lb/>species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key based primarily on morphological characters</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This key is for sexually mature adults, either freshly collected or showing good colour preservation.<tei:lb/>O. simony i, which is known only from the Canary Islands, is not included.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Key based on song characters (see especially Figs 12-23)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This key is based on the calling songs produced by isolated males in warm, sunny conditions. As far as<tei:lb/>couplet 5 the song differences can be easily detected by the human ear assisted by the second hand (or<tei:lb/>digital count) of a watch. From couplet 6 onwards some of the differences require oscillographic analysis,<tei:lb/>or at least the ability to play back the recorded song at a slower tape speed.<tei:lb/>See p. 00 for definitions of the terms 'echeme', 'syllable' and 'gap'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Song a series of echemes in rapid succession (at least 1/s) 2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- Song a single echeme or a series of echemes separated by intervals of at least 3s 4</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Echemes repeated at the rate of at least 3/s (Figs 55-63) petraeus(p. 233)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Echemes repeated at the rate of about 2/s 3</tei:p>

         <tei:p>- Song consisting of about 6-10 echemes and lasting about 3-5 s (Figs 117-1 19) minutissimus(p. 243)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4 Song consisting of a single echeme lasting more than 4s 5</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Song consisting of one or more echemes, each lasting less than 4s 6</tei:p>

         <tei:p>10 Gaps becoming obscured towards the end of the echeme (Figs 64-72). (Widespread in Iberian</tei:p>

         <tei:p>The songs of the western European Omocestus</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Omocestus viridulus (Linnaeus)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 2, 6, 24-33)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gryllus Locusta viridulus Linnaeus, 1758: 433. Lectotype cf, SWEDEN: Gotland, Burgsvik (Linnean<tei:lb/>Society of London), designated by Marshall (1983: 394) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REFERENCES TO SONG. Oscillogram: Eisner, 1974, 1975; Grein, 1984; Haskell, 1957, 1958; Kutsch, 1976;<tei:lb/>Kutsch &amp; Schiolten, 1979; Loher &amp; Broughton, 1955; Zhantiev, 1981. Diagram: Bellmann, 1985a; Duijm<tei:lb/>&amp; Kruseman, 1983; Haskell, 1957; Hoist, 1970; Jacobs, 1950, 1953; Ragge, 1965; Wallin, 1979. Frequency<tei:lb/>information: Haskell, 1957, 1958. Musical notation: Yersin, 1854. Verbal description only: Beier, 1956;<tei:lb/>Faber, 1928, 1953; Haskell, 1955; Harz, 1957; Skovmand &amp; Pedersen, 1978, 1983; Weber, 1984; Weih,<tei:lb/>1951. Disc recording: Grein, 1984; Ragge, Burton &amp; Wade, 1965. Cassette recording: Bellmann, 19856;<tei:lb/>Wallin, 1979.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>RECOGNITION. Males of this common species may be easily distinguished from the rather similar species<tei:lb/>rufipes and haemorrhoidalis by the lack of any red colouring on the abdomen, and females by the<tei:lb/>conspicuously longer ovipositor (Fig. 2). Both sexes also lack the dark markings in the medial area of the<tei:lb/>fore wings that are normally present in the other two species, and the pronotal lateral carinae are usually<tei:lb/>much less incurved in the prozona (Fig. 6).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In the field the conspicuously loud calling song of the male provides an easy means of identifying this<tei:lb/>species. Although similar in the quality of sound to the songs of rufipes and haemorrhoidalis, the song of<tei:lb/>viridulus is more prolonged, usually lasting for more than 12 s.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SONG (Figs 24-33). The calling song is an echeme usually lasting about 12-25 s and consisting of<tei:lb/>syllables repeated at the rate of about 15-20/s. The echeme beings quietly (the first few leg<tei:lb/>movements producing no audible sound) and gradually increases in loudness until the maximum<tei:lb/>intensity is reached after a few seconds; the echeme then continues at a constant intensity until<tei:lb/>reaching an abrupt end. The syllable repetition rate is highest at the beginning of the echeme<tei:lb/>(usually 18-20/s), gradually lessening towards the end (when it is usually 15-18/s). The song is a<tei:lb/>conspicuous summer sound in much of the European countryside, louder than the songs of most<tei:lb/>other common grasshoppers.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In the presence of a female the male produces longer echemes, usually lasting more than 30 s<tei:lb/>and occasionally more than a minute; one of the hind legs is moved through a noticeably wider<tei:lb/>angle than the other and produces most of the sound. After a series of these echemes with short<tei:lb/>pauses (about 10-15 s) between them, there is a quite different and much quieter echeme lasting<tei:lb/>about 3-5 s and composed of syllables repeated at the rate of about 12-16/s (Fig. 26). This is<tei:lb/>normally followed by a series of loud syllables and an attempt to copulate with the female. If this<tei:lb/>attempt is unsuccessful the male will usually produce a series of sharp 'ticks' (Fig. 27) by kicking<tei:lb/>backwards with the hind tibiae (as in the calling song of Stethophyma grossum (Linnaeus))<tei:lb/>before beginning another sequence of courtship echemes. Usually the two hind tibiae are kicked<tei:lb/>simultaneously, but sometimes one at a time, changing haphazardly (rarely regularly) from one<tei:lb/>side to the other. The number of ticks is very variable but is usually between 5 and 15, and the<tei:lb/>repetition rate is rather irregular, generally about 1-2/s.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. This common species occurs in fairly moist habitats throughout Europe, except for the<tei:lb/>extreme north and the southern parts of the Iberian, Italian and Balkan peninsulas; its range extends<tei:lb/>eastwards to Siberia and Mongolia.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>SONGS OF THE WESTERN EUROPEAN OMOCESTUS 227</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Omocestus rufipes (Zetterstedt)<tei:lb/>(Figs 3, 7, 34-45)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gryllus rufipes Zetterstedt, 1821: 90. LECTOTYPE cf , SWEDEN: Ostergotland, Larketorp (ZI, Lund),<tei:lb/>here designated (see p. 220) [examined]. [Validity established by von Borck (1848: 124) under Article 24<tei:lb/>of the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature.}</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gryllus ventralis Zetterstedt, 1821: 89. Holotype $, SWEDEN: Skane, near Tranas, Asperod ['Esperod']<tei:lb/>(ZI, Lund) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REFERENCES TO SONG. Oscillogram: Broughton, 1955; Grein, 1984; Loher &amp; Broughton, 1955; Schmidt &amp;<tei:lb/>Baumgarten, 1977. Diagram: Bellmann, 1985a; Duijm &amp; Kruseman, 1983; Hoist, 1970; Jacobs, 1950,<tei:lb/>1953; Luquet, 1978; Ragge, 1965; Wallin, 1979. Frequency information: Busnel, 1955; Loher &amp; Brought-<tei:lb/>on, 1955. Musical notation: Yersin, 1854. Verbal description only: Beier, 1956; Chopard, 1922; Faber,<tei:lb/>1953; Harz, 1957; Weih, 1951. Disc recording: Andrieu &amp; Dumortier, 1963; Grein, 1984; Ragge, Burton &amp;<tei:lb/>Wade, 1965. Cassette recording: Bellmann, 19856; Wallin, 1979.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>RECOGNITION. The red colouring on the underside of the abdomen and the conspicuously pale-tipped palps<tei:lb/>enable both sexes of this species to be distinguished from its relatives. The distal part of the hind wings is<tei:lb/>much more strongly smoky than in haemorrhoidalis , in which the male abdomen is occasionally reddish on<tei:lb/>the underside.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In the field the calling song of the males enables them to be recognized easily. Although quite similar in<tei:lb/>basic pattern to those ofviriduku and haemorrhoidalis, the song of rufipes differs in duration, lasting about<tei:lb/>half as long as that of viridulus and about three times as long as that of haemorrhoidalis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SONG (Figs 34-45) . The calling song is an echeme usually lasting 5-10 s and consisting of syllables<tei:lb/>repeated at the rate of about 13-23/s. The echeme begins quietly and gradually increases in<tei:lb/>loudness until reaching an abrupt end, thus resembling the first half of the calling song of<tei:lb/>viridulus. As in viridulus the syllable repetition rate is highest at the beginning of the echeme<tei:lb/>(usually 17-23/s), gradually lessening towards the end (when it is usually 13-17/s).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In the presence of a female the male produces a courtship song quite similar to that of<tei:lb/>viridulus. There is first a series of echemes similar to those of the calling song but usually rather<tei:lb/>longer; this is followed by a quite different and quieter echeme lasting about 5-10 s and<tei:lb/>composed of syllables repeated at the rate of about 10-15/s (Fig. 37) . There are then several loud<tei:lb/>syllables followed by an attempt to copulate with the female. The 'ticks' produced by backward<tei:lb/>kicks of the hind tibiae during the courtship song of viridulus seem never to occur in that of<tei:lb/>rufipes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. This species can tolerate drier conditions than viridulus and often occurs in more shaded<tei:lb/>habitats. Its distribution is very similar, but extends further south in the Iberian, Italian and Balkan<tei:lb/>peninsulas.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Omocestus haemorrhoidalis (Charpentier)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 8, 46-54)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gryllus haemorrhoidalis Charpentier, 1825: 165. Syntypes of both sexes, POLAND/CZECHOSLOVAKIA:<tei:lb/>'Silesia'. There are a male (in bad condition) and two females in the MNHU, Berlin that have been<tei:lb/>regarded as syntypes of this species, but none is labelled 'Silesia' and there is some doubt that they belong<tei:lb/>to the type-series.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REFERENCES TO SONG. Oscillogram: Grein, 1984; Schmidt &amp; Schach, 1978. Diagram: Bellmann, 1985a;<tei:lb/>Duijm &amp; Kruseman, 1983; Jacobs, 1950, 1953; Wallin, 1979. Verbal description only: Faber, 1953; Harz,<tei:lb/>1957; Weber, 1984. Disc recording: Grein, 1984. Cassette recording: Bellmann, 1985ft; Wallin, 1979.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>RECOGNITION. For the distinction between this species and petraeus see the remarks under that species.<tei:lb/>Both sexes may be distinguished from viridulus, rufipes and raymondi by the almost transparent hind wings<tei:lb/>(strongly smoky in the distal part in those three species). In the field the males can be recognized quite<tei:lb/>easily by their calling song, in which the echemes are shorter than those of viridulus and rufipes, but much<tei:lb/>longer than those of raymondi.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SONG (Figs 46-54). The calling song is an echeme lasting about 2-4 s and consisting of syllables</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>

      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>SONGS OF THE WESTERN EUROPEAN OMOCESTUS 233</tei:p>
         <tei:p>repeated at the rate of about 25-40/s (about double the rate of viridulus and rufipes). The<tei:lb/>echeme begins quietly but soon reaches maximum intensity. The syllable repetition rate<tei:lb/>gradually lessens during the course of the echeme.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Widely distributed in continental Europe, but not known from the Scandinavian mainland<tei:lb/>and limited to mountains in the southern peninsulas. The range extends eastwards across central Asia to<tei:lb/>Mongolia, Manchuria and Korea.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Omocestus petraeus (Brisout)<tei:lb/>(Figs 9, 55-63)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acridium petraeum Brisout, 1855: cxiv. LECTOTYPE cf , FRANCE: near Paris, Lardy (Brisout) (IRSNB,<tei:lb/>Brussels), here designated (see p. 221) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REFERENCES TO SONG. Diagram: Luquet, 1978. Verbal description only: Faber, 1953; Harz, 1957.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>RECOGNITION. This species lacks the smoky coloration of the distal part of the hind wings shown by<tei:lb/>viridulus, rufipes and raymondi, and is also noticeably smaller. Distinguishing it from haemorrhoidalis is<tei:lb/>more difficult, especially if reliably identified specimens of both species are not available for comparison.<tei:lb/>O. petraeus is again noticeably smaller, and the head is larger in comparison to the pronotum and more<tei:lb/>convex above with shorter foveolae. The males lack the red colouring shown by the distal part of the<tei:lb/>abdomen in haemorrhoidalis, showing a yellowish colouring in this region instead.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The highly distinctive calling song, consisting of about 10-20 rapidly repeated echemes, enables males of<tei:lb/>this species to be recognized easily in the field.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SONG (Figs 55-63). The calling song consists of a sequence of about 10-20 echemes lasting about<tei:lb/>2-5 s. The sequence begins quietly, reaching maximum intensity after about 6 echemes; even at<tei:lb/>its maximum intensity the song is rather quiet. The echeme repetition rate is usually about 4/s,<tei:lb/>and the syllable repetition rate within each echeme about 80-1 10/s. Each of the louder echemes<tei:lb/>lasts for about 150 ms and contains about 10-15 syllables.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In the presence of a female the male produces echemes of a quite different kind (Figs 57, 60,<tei:lb/>63). Each echeme begins with a relatively long syllable, lasting about 20-50 ms, and this is<tei:lb/>immediately followed by a series of very short sounds, each lasting less than 5 ms, repeated at the<tei:lb/>rate of about 50/s. These echemes are produced either singly or, more often, in groups of about<tei:lb/>2-5.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Western, central and eastern Europe, Asia Minor and southern Siberia. Largely absent<tei:lb/>from the Iberian Peninsula, but quite widespread in Italy and the Balkan Peninsula.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Omocestus raymondi ( Yersin)<tei:lb/>(Figs 10, 64-72)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Stenobothrus raymondi Yersin, 1863: 289. Syntypes of both sexes, FRANCE: Var, near Hyeres (Raymond)<tei:lb/>(lost); the two 'neotypes' designated by Harz (1975: 713) are clearly invalid.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REFERENCES TO SONG. Diagram: Luquet, 1978. Verbal description only: Chopard, 1922, 1952.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>RECOGNITION. This all-brown species is most likely to be confused with haemorrhoidalis, but can be<tei:lb/>distinguished from it in both sexes by the strongly smoky distal part of the hind wings (almost transparent in<tei:lb/>haemorrhoidalis). In the field males may be distinguished from those of haemorrhoidalis by the very short<tei:lb/>echemes (lasting about 1 s) and slower syllable repetition rate (less than 20/s) of the calling song.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SONG (Figs 64-72). The calling song is an echeme lasting about 1-0-1-5 s and consisting of about<tei:lb/>18-25 syllables repeated at the rate of 15-20/s. Each echeme usually begins quietly, rapidly<tei:lb/>increasing in intensity. Oscillograms show the syllables to have a characteristic pattern of gaps,<tei:lb/>which often becomes obscured towards the end of the echeme (Figs 67-69). The echemes are<tei:lb/>often produced singly and repeated at irregular intervals (10-15 s is typical), but sometimes they<tei:lb/>are in groups of 2-4 with much shorter intervals between them (often 2-5 s) (Figs 65, 66).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Known only from southern France, the Iberian Peninsula, north-western Italy and North<tei:lb/>Africa.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>

         <tei:pb/>

      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>236 D. R. RAGGE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Omocestus panteli (Bolivar)<tei:lb/>(Figs 11, 73-89)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Stenobothrus panteli Bolivar, 1887: 95. Syntypes of both sexes, SPAIN: Cuenca, near Ucles (7MNCN,<tei:lb/>Madrid).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REFERENCES TO SONG. No published work known to me.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>RECOGNITION. In the Iberian Peninsula, to which it is confined, panteli is most likely to be confused with<tei:lb/>viridulus; it is, however, much smaller than that species and can be further distinguished from it by the red<tei:lb/>tip of the male abdomen and the relatively short ovipositor. There is also a superficial resemblance to<tei:lb/>Stenobothrus stigmaticus (Rambur), which is similar in size and also widespread in the Iberian Peninsula,<tei:lb/>but the pronotal lateral carinae are straighter in panteli, the male cerci are conical throughout (laterally<tei:lb/>compressed at the tip in stigmaticus) and the female lacks the teeth on the ovipositor shown by all species of<tei:lb/>Stenobothrus. There is a large form (var. meridionalis Bolivar) found in the south of the peninsula,<tei:lb/>especially in mountains; this form is even more like viridulus, but confusion is unlikely as that species does<tei:lb/>not occur in southern Spain.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In the field the song may be recognized by its short duration (less than 2 s) and high syllable repetition<tei:lb/>rate (usually more than 20/s).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SONG (Figs 73-89). The calling song is an echeme lasting 1-2 s and consisting of about 30-55<tei:lb/>syllables repeated at the rate of about 18-30/s. The echeme begins quietly (sometimes after a few<tei:lb/>louder syllables) but soon reaches maximum intensity. The syllable repetition rate gradually<tei:lb/>lessens during the course of the echeme.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In the presence of a female the male first produces a different kind of echeme lasting about 2-3<tei:lb/>s, and this is immediately followed by an echeme similar in duration and syllable repetition rate<tei:lb/>to that of the calling song but with an increase in intensity continuing through the whole echeme<tei:lb/>(Figs 77, 82, 87).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. This species is confined to the Iberian Peninsula, where it is widespread and very common.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Omocestus broelemanni ( Azam)<tei:lb/>(Figs 90-98)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Stenobothrus Brolemanni Azam, 1906: 128. LECTOTYPE cf , FRANCE: Pyrenees-Orientales, Val d'Eyne,<tei:lb/>1700-2200 m, 14.viii.1905 (Brolemann) (MNHN, Paris), here designated (see p. 221) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REFERENCES TO SONG. Oscillogram: Reynolds, 1986.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>RECOGNITION. This Pyrenean species is brachypterous, the fore wings not usually reaching the hind knees in<tei:lb/>the male and reduced to short lobes (about 1-5 times the length of the pronotum) in the female; in both<tei:lb/>sexes the hind wings fall short of the fore wings by quite a large gap. There is thus no risk of confusion with<tei:lb/>viridulus, rufipes, haemorrhoidalis and the other fully winged species of Omocestus. Confusion is also<tei:lb/>unlikely with the brachypterous species occurring further south in Spain, such as uhagonii and minutissi-<tei:lb/>mus, which are much smaller and not known from the vicinity of the Pyrenees. The relationship of O.<tei:lb/>broelemanni with O. antigai (Bolivar) and O. navasi Bolivar has been recently discussed by Reynolds<tei:lb/>(1986).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In the field the calling song of the male is quite distinctive, consisting of echemes lasting about as long as<tei:lb/>those of haemorrhoidalis but with about half the syllable repetition rate of that species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SONG (Figs 90-98). The calling song, recently described for the first time by Reynolds (1986), is a<tei:lb/>series of echemes, each lasting about 1-5-3-0 s and consisting of about 25-45 syllables repeated<tei:lb/>at the rate of about 15-16/s. Each echeme begins quietly, reaching maximum intensity after<tei:lb/>about 1 s. Although the echemes are sometimes produced singly, they are more often repeated<tei:lb/>fairly regularly, about every 5-10 s, in a series of indefinite duration.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>During the courtship song, which has also been described by Reynolds (1986), the male often<tei:lb/>produces a series of rather longer echemes (each lasting up to 5 s) and this is followed by a<tei:lb/>variable number of short echemes of small numbers of syllables (or even single syllables)</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>SONGS OF THE WESTERN EUROPEAN OMOCESTUS 237</tei:p>
         <tei:p>produced by one leg only (Figs 92, 95, 98). There is then a series of single syllables produced by<tei:lb/>both legs, followed by an attempt at copulation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Known only from the vicinity of the Pyrenees, particularly the eastern end of the range.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Omocestus bolivari Chopard<tei:lb/>(Figs 99-107)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Omocestus Bolivari Chopard, 1939: 172. LECTOTYPE cf , SPAIN: Granada, Sierra Nevada, slopes of<tei:lb/>Mulhacen, 3000 m ['2000 m. environ' according to Chopard, loc. cit.], 10.vii.1934 (Balachowsky)<tei:lb/>(MNHN, Paris), here designated (see p. 221) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REFERENCES TO SONG. No published work known to me.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>RECOGNITION. This species, known only from the higher parts of the Sierra Nevada in southern Spain, is<tei:lb/>very similar to uhagonii, llorenteae and minutissimus . Males may be distinguished from all three of these<tei:lb/>species by their short hind wings, which are less than half the length of the fore wings, and the females by<tei:lb/>their short fore wings, which are usually less than 1-3 times longer than the pronotum.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In the field the isolated echemes of the calling song enable males to be easily distinguished from<tei:lb/>llorenteae and minutissimus; from uhagonii they may be distinguished by the much faster syllable repetition<tei:lb/>rate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SONG (Figs 99-107) . The calling song is an echeme lasting 0-5-2-0 s and consisting of about 10-30<tei:lb/>syllables repeated at the rate of 14 16/s. Each echeme begins quietly, soon reaching maximum<tei:lb/>intensity. Oscillographic analysis shows that there are gaps in each syllable (mainly in the later<tei:lb/>part of the syllable) and that they occur throughout the echeme; there are, however, only 2-4<tei:lb/>gaps per syllable (Figs 102-107), many fewer than in uhagonii. As in uhagonii the echemes are<tei:lb/>repeated at irregular intervals, varying from a few seconds to over a minute.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Known only from the higher parts of the Sierra Nevada in southern Spain, usually at<tei:lb/>altitudes above 1500 m.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Omocestus uhagonii (Bolivar)<tei:lb/>(Figs 4, 108-116)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gomphocerus (Stenobothrus) Uhagonii Bolivar, 1876: 324. LECTOTYPE cf , SPAIN: Madrid, Navarre-<tei:lb/>donda (Avila) (MNCN, Madrid), here designated (see p. 221) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REFERENCES TO SONG. No published work known to me.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>RECOGNITION. Males of this brachypterous montane species can be distinguished from the rather similar<tei:lb/>species bolivari, llorenteae and minutissimus by the cerci, which are laterally compressed towards the tip<tei:lb/>(simply conical in the other three species). Females can be separated from bolivari and llorenteae by the<tei:lb/>length of the fore wings, which are 1-4-1-8 times longer than the pronotum (the corresponding ratios for<tei:lb/>bolivari and llorenteae are 0-9-1-3 and 2-1-2-5, respectively), and from minutissimus by the much less<tei:lb/>strongly sigmoid ventral profile of the lower valves of the ovipositor (cf. Figs 4,5).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In the field the calling song of the males enables this species to be easily distinguished from llorenteae and<tei:lb/>minutissimus, which produce echeme-sequences of a quite different kind (cf. Figs 20-22); from bolivari it<tei:lb/>may be distinguished by the much slower syllable repetition rate (cf. Figs 19, 20).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SONG (Figs 108-116). The calling song is an echeme lasting 1-2 s and consisting of about 10-15<tei:lb/>syllables repeated at the rate of 6-7/s. Each echeme begins quietly, rapidly increasing in<tei:lb/>intensity. Oscillographic analysis shows that each syllable has a large number of gaps (commonly<tei:lb/>as many as 8) and that this pattern of gaps is maintained until the end of the echeme (Figs 111,<tei:lb/>112). The echemes are repeated at irregular intervals, varying from a few seconds to over a<tei:lb/>minute.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In the presence of a female the male produces a series of slightly longer echemes (lasting 2-3 s)<tei:lb/>at much more regular intervals (usually 6-8 in 40 s) (Fig. 110). The echemes consist of about<tei:lb/>15-20 syllables and at the end of some of them (usually about half) there is a group of 3-4<tei:lb/>syllables of a different kind (Figs 113, 116), repeated more rapidly (at the rate of about 16/s). In</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>238</tei:p>
         <tei:p>D. R. RAGGE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>o</tei:p>
         <tei:p>00</tei:p>
         <tei:p>00</tei:p>
         <tei:p>cs</tei:p>
         <tei:p>00</tei:p>
         <tei:p>II</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ijj</tei:p>
         <tei:p>o H a</tei:p>
         <tei:p>|&lt; .W&gt;"O</tei:p>
         <tei:p>|.s 2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>a ja</tei:p>
         <tei:p>8 | g</tei:p>
         <tei:p>" J2 O</tei:p>

         <tei:p>^ 4) (SO</tei:p>

         <tei:p>oo<tei:lb/>o</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ex<tei:lb/>o</tei:p>
         <tei:p>D. R. RAGGE<tei:lb/>I</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CM</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CO</tei:p>
         <tei:p>OB &lt;L&gt;<tei:lb/>C J=</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- E</tei:p>

         <tei:p>C C PS<tei:lb/>O T3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>^ 13</tei:p>
         <tei:p>li-a</tei:p>
         <tei:p>&lt;*- &lt;u 2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>8.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>00 *</tei:p>
         <tei:p>z ^</tei:p>
         <tei:p>o o _c</tei:p>
         <tei:p>" S 5</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5- S</tei:p>
         <tei:p>^ c</tei:p>
         <tei:p>?:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>o</tei:p>
         <tei:p/>
         <tei:p>2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>&lt;u</tei:p>
         <tei:p>^</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SO O</tei:p>
         <tei:p>^</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1=1 C o</tei:p>
         <tei:p>o 5</tei:p>
         <tei:p>n</tei:p>
         <tei:p>OX)</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>SONGS OF THE WESTERN EUROPEAN OMOCESTUS 243</tei:p>
         <tei:p>the intervals between the echemes there are quieter 'ticking' sounds repeated fairly regularly at<tei:lb/>the rate of about 3-4/s. The number of echemes in the series is variable but can be more than 20.<tei:lb/>The series of echemes is followed by a variable period (often more than a minute) in which the<tei:lb/>quiet ticking continues and which ends in a number of sequences of a different kind of sound, still<tei:lb/>quiet, and then an attempt at copulation. If this is unsuccessful the cycle begins again with<tei:lb/>another series of echemes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. This species has been previously known only from the mountains of central and northern<tei:lb/>Spain, but my wife and I collected a series of adults of both sexes at El Chorillo (2700 m), south of the<tei:lb/>Mulhacen peak in the Sierra Nevada, on 31 July 1983.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Omocestus minutissimus (Bolivar)<tei:lb/>(Figs 5, 117-119)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gomphocerus (Omocestus) minutissimus Bolivar, 1878: 424. Syntypes of both sexes, SPAIN: Navarra,<tei:lb/>Cascante (Perez Areas); Madrid, Escorial (MNCN, Madrid; BMNH, London; probably other deposi-<tei:lb/>tories) [$ syntype from Escorial in BMNH examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REFERENCES TO SONG. No published work known to me.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>RECOGNITION . Males of this small upland species may be distinguished from uhagonii by the cerci , which are<tei:lb/>simply conical (laterally compressed towards the tip in uhagonii}. They can be separated from bolivari and<tei:lb/>llorenteae by the length of the hind wings, which are more than half the length of the fore wings but do not<tei:lb/>reach the fore wing-tips. Females can be distinguished from bolivari and llorenteae by the length of the fore<tei:lb/>wings, which are usually 1-4-2-1 times the length of the pronotum; the corresponding ratios for bolivari and<tei:lb/>llorenteae are 0.9-1-3 and 2-1-2-5, respectively (these two species are in any case known only f r om the<tei:lb/>Sierra Nevada or Sierra Espuna, where minutissimus does not apparently occur). Females of minutissimus<tei:lb/>may be separated from those of uhagonii by the strongly sigmoid ventral profile of the lower valves of the<tei:lb/>ovipositor (cf. Figs 4, 5).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In the field the calling song of the males, consisting of a rapid sequence of echemes, enables this species<tei:lb/>to be easily distinguished from uhagonii and bolivari; from llorenteae it may be distinguished by being<tei:lb/>shorter (usually lasting less than 6 s) and having fewer echemes in each sequence (usually fewer than 10).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SONG (Figs 117-119). The rather quiet calling song is a sequence of about 6-10 echemes lasting<tei:lb/>about 3-5 s. The sequence begins very quietly, reaching maximum intensity after about 3-4<tei:lb/>echemes. The echemes are separated by intervals of about 100-200 ms, often becoming more<tei:lb/>widely spaced towards the end of the sequence. Each echeme begins and ends very quietly,<tei:lb/>giving a spindle-shaped oscillogram (Fig. 118). Each of the later echemes in the sequence lasts<tei:lb/>about 300-400 ms and contains about 20-30 syllables repeated at the rate of about 80-90/s. The<tei:lb/>calling song is thus very similar to that of llorenteae, but is quieter and shorter, and has fewer<tei:lb/>echemes composed of fewer syllables.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. North-eastern, central and south-eastern Spain.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Omocestus llorenteae Pascual<tei:lb/>(Figs 123-128)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Omocestus llorenteae Pascual, 1978: 159. Holotype O" , SPAIN: Granada, Sierra Nevada, Dornajo, 2000 m,<tei:lb/>19. ix. 1975 (Pascual) (Universidad de Granada) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REFERENCES TO SONG. No published work known to me.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>RECOGNITION. This species, known only from the Sierra Nevada and Sierra Espuna in southern Spain, can<tei:lb/>be distinguished from the similar montane species uhagonii and bolivari by the dark spots in the medial<tei:lb/>area of the fore wings and by the longer hind wings, which reach the tips of the fore wings; the longer hind<tei:lb/>wings also enable this species to be distinguished from minutissimus, which is in any case not known to<tei:lb/>occur in the Sierra Nevada or Sierra Espuna. Females of llorenteae also differ from those of uhagonii and<tei:lb/>bolivari in that the fore wings are more than twice the length of the pronotum.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In the field the calling song of the males, consisting of a rapid sequence of echemes, provides an easy<tei:lb/>means of distinguishing this species from most other species of Omocestus occurring in southern Spain.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>244</tei:p>
         <tei:p>D. R. RAGGE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>10<tei:lb/>6</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CN</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CN<tei:lb/>CN</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>SONGS OF THE WESTERN EUROPEAN OMOCESTUS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>245</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CO<tei:lb/>CM</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CN</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>00<tei:lb/>CN</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>246 D. R. RAGGE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>From minutissimus , which has a similar song-pattern, it may be distinguished by being longer (usually<tei:lb/>lasting more than 6 s) and having more echemes in each sequence (usually more than 11).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SONG (Figs 123-128). The calling song is a sequence of about 11-15 echemes lasting about 6-8 s.<tei:lb/>The sequence begins quietly, reaching maximum intensity after about 5-6 echemes. The<tei:lb/>echemes are usually separated by intervals of about 100-200 ms, often becoming more widely<tei:lb/>spaced towards the end of the sequence. Each echeme begins and ends quietly, giving a<tei:lb/>spindle-shaped oscillogram (Figs 125, 126). By the middle of the sequence each echeme lasts<tei:lb/>about 350-600 ms and contains about 30-50 syllables repeated at the rate of about 85-95/s. The<tei:lb/>calling song is thus remarkably similar to that of Myrmeleotettix maculatus (Thunberg), though<tei:lb/>usually of shorter duration and composed of fewer echemes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Known only from the Sierra Nevada and Sierra Espuna in southern Spain.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Omocestus simony i (Krauss)<tei:lb/>(Figs 120-122)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Stenobothrus simonyi Krauss, 1892: 166. Syntypes of both sexes, CANARY ISLANDS: Lanzarote (Simony)<tei:lb/>(lost).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REFERENCES TO SONG. No published work known to me.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>RECOGNITION. This is the only species of Omocestus known from the Canary Islands and so in practice there<tei:lb/>is no problem in recognizing it. It is similar in appearance to raymondi but is smaller (total length less than<tei:lb/>14 mm in the male, less than 19 mm in the female). The calling song of the male is superficially very similar<tei:lb/>to that of uhagonii, oscillographic analysis being required to show that it has far fewer gaps in each syllable;<tei:lb/>it differs from that of raymondi in having a much slower syllable repetition rate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SONG (Figs 120-122). The calling song is an echeme lasting about 1-0-2-5 s and consisting of<tei:lb/>about 10-20 syllables repeated at the rate of 5-10/s. Each echeme begins quietly, reaching<tei:lb/>maximum intensity about midway through its duration. Oscillographic analysis shows that there<tei:lb/>are gaps in each syllable, similar in number to those in the calling song of raymondi (far fewer<tei:lb/>than in uhagonii) but not arranged in the same pattern and maintained until the end of the<tei:lb/>echeme (Figs 121, 122). The echemes are repeated at irregular intervals.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Known only from the Canary Islands, where it occurs on Lanzarote and Fuerteventura.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Occasional Papers on Systematic Entomology</tei:p>
         <tei:p>New Series</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The economic importance of insects, and the enormous number of species, have resulted in a<tei:lb/>vast literature written in many languages; that which is of direct economic importance and<tei:lb/>recently published can, to an increasing extent, be searched by using computerized data bases,<tei:lb/>but a great amount of more general information is unlikely to be available so readily in the<tei:lb/>near future. The objective of this new occasional series is to make available in hard copy some<tei:lb/>of the basic data that is essential to the preparation of comprehensive accounts of the world<tei:lb/>insect fauna. The papers have been fully researched bibliographically and consist of checklists<tei:lb/>of nominal taxa, and faunal lists with information on host plants and localities, based mainly<tei:lb/>on the collections and libraries of the British Museum (Natural History).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>No. 1. A checklist of Neotropical arctiine and pericopine tiger moths.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A. Watson &amp; D. T. Goodger</tei:p>
         <tei:p>72pp. inc. 4 colour plates 27 February 1986</tei:p>
         <tei:p>No. 2. An annotated checklist of the Carabidae (including Cicindelinae, Rhysodinae and</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paussinae) recorded from Borneo.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>N. E. Stork</tei:p>
         <tei:p>26pp., 1 map 29 May 1986</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Catalogues of BM (NH) Bulletins and Books free on request to Publication Sales.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>

         <tei:p>By W. R. Dolling</tei:p>

         <tei:p>19</tei:p>
         <tei:p>PRE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bulletin of the</tei:p>
         <tei:p>British Museum (Natural History)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The structure and affinities of the<tei:lb/>Hedyloidea: a new concept of the<tei:lb/>butterflies</tei:p>
         <tei:p>M. J. Scoble</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Entomology series</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vol53 No 5 18 December 1986</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>The Bulletin of the British Museum (Natural History), instituted in 1949, is issued in four<tei:lb/>scientific series, Botany, Entomology, Geology (incorporating Mineralogy) and Zoology,<tei:lb/>and an Historical series.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Papers in the Bulletin are primarily the results of research carried out on the unique and<tei:lb/>ever-growing collections of the Museum, both by the scientific staff of the Museum and by<tei:lb/>specialists from elsewhere who make use of the Museum's resources. Many of the papers are<tei:lb/>works of reference that will remain indispensable for years to come.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Parts are published at irregular intervals as they become ready, each is complete in itself,<tei:lb/>available separately, and individually priced. Volumes contain about 300 pages and several<tei:lb/>volumes may appear within a calendar year. Subscriptions may be placed for one or more of<tei:lb/>the series on either an Annual or Per Volume basis. Prices vary according to the contents of<tei:lb/>the individual parts. Orders and enquiries should be sent to:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Publications Sales,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>British Museum (Natural History),<tei:lb/>Cromwell Road,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>London SW75BD,<tei:lb/>England.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>World List abbreviation: Bull. Br. Mus. nat. Hist. (Ent.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trustees of the British Museum (Natural History), 1986</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Entomology series is produced under the general editorship of the</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Keeper of Entomology: Laurence A. Mound</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Assistant Editor: W. Gerald Tremewan</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ISBN 565 06023 6</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ISSN 0524-6431 Entomology series</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vol53No5pp251-286<tei:lb/>British Museum (Natural History)<tei:lb/>Cromwell Road<tei:lb/>London SW7 5BD Issued 18 December 1986</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>The structure and affinities of the Hedyloidea: a</tei:p>
         <tei:p>new concept of the butterflies</tei:p>
         <tei:p>..</tei:p>
         <tei:p>M. J. Scoble</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Department of Entomology, British Museum (Natural History), Cromwell Road, London SW7<tei:lb/>5BD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Contents</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Synopsis .................................................................................................... 25 1</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Introduction .............................................................................................. 25 1</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Material ................................................................................................. 253</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hedylidae Guenee ...................................................................................... 253</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Generic synonymy .................................................................................... 254</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Macrosoma Hiibner ..................................................................................... 254</tei:p>
         <tei:p>General appearance ..................................................................................... 254</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Description ................................................................................................ 254</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Comments on selected structures .................................................................... 260</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Adult .................................................................................................... 260</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Juvenile stages ......................................................................................... 280</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Discussion ................................................................................................. 281</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Epilogue : a suggested phylogeny ..................................................................... 284</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acknowledgements ..................................................................................... 284</tei:p>
         <tei:p>References ................................................................................................ 284</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Synopsis</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The affinities of the Hedylidae, a group of about 40 Central and South American Lepidoptera, are<tei:lb/>reassessed. Currently, the taxon is treated as a tribe ('Hedylicae') of the Oenochrominae (Geometridae),<tei:lb/>but evidence is presented here to show that hedylids are butterflies although they look moth-like in many<tei:lb/>respects. The five generic names in the family are synonymized in this work with the oldest, Macrosoma<tei:lb/>Hiibner.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The taxonomic history of the Hedylidae is discussed, and the reasons for the proposed assignment of the<tei:lb/>family to the Rhopalocera are given. A description of the family is followed by comments on characters<tei:lb/>selected for their biological or systematic interest. In this section comparisons are made between the<tei:lb/>Hedylidae and other Lepidoptera, particularly the butterflies, and their phylogenetic relationships are<tei:lb/>discussed. Hedylidae + Hesperioidea -I- Papilionoidea (s.str.) probably form a monophyletic taxon,<tei:lb/>although doubts have been expressed about the relationship between skippers and true butterflies. It is<tei:lb/>tentatively suggested that within the Rhopalocera, the Hedylidae are more closely related to the<tei:lb/>Papilionoidea than are the Hesperiidae to the Papilionoidea; that is, the butterflies without the Hedylidae<tei:lb/>are paraphyletic.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The evidence of the butterfly affinities of hedylids comes from adults, larvae, and pupae; the structure of<tei:lb/>the thorax and the base of the abdomen of the adult was found to be particularly revealing.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key words: Lepidoptera, Rhopalocera, Hedyloidea stat. n., Hedylidae, Geometridae, morphology,<tei:lb/>phylogeny.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Introduction</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Guenee (1857) described the Hedylidae as one of the 26 component families of the Phalenites.<tei:lb/>The Phalenites are, with modification, the equivalent of what are now called the Geometridae.<tei:lb/>The Hedylidae were treated by Prout (1910; 1931) as a tribe ('Hedylicae') of the Oenochromi-<tei:lb/>nae (Geometridae), and no reassessment of the relationships of the group has been attempted<tei:lb/>subsequently. In fact the Hedylidae are misplaced in the Geometridae, the most obvious reason<tei:lb/>being the absence of tympanal organs from the base of the abdomen in the former - structures<tei:lb/>that are characteristic of the latter.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bull. Br. Mus. nat. Hist. (Ent.) 53 (5): 251-286 Issued 18 December 1986</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>252 M. J. SCOBLE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Hedylidae consist of some 40 species, from South or Central America. Below, I argue<tei:lb/>that not only is this group misplaced in the Geometridae but also that its phylogenetic affinities<tei:lb/>are with the butterflies (Rhopalocera: Hesperioidea or skippers, and Papilionoidea or true<tei:lb/>butterflies) despite the moth-like external appearance of the adult insects.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Both Guenee (1857) and Prout (1910; 1931) noted certain similarities between hedylids and<tei:lb/>butterflies. Guenee even went so far as to name one species napiaria because it resembled the<tei:lb/>pierid butterfly Pieris napi (L.). He named another species heliconiaria since it reminded him of<tei:lb/>certain species of the papilionoid genus Heliconius Kluk. Prout (1910; 1931) noted the<tei:lb/>butterfly-like shape of the adults, and the remarkable girdled pupa in the two species for which<tei:lb/>he had information. However, neither of these workers suggested that these features meant that<tei:lb/>hedylids and butterflies were related, and they presumably regarded the similarities as indepen-<tei:lb/>dent derivations. Prout (1931) was clearly uncomfortable about the geometrid affinities of the<tei:lb/>group since he suggested that the 'Hedylicae' might deserve even a separate family status.<tei:lb/>However, neither he nor Guenee apparently considered that the butterfly-like features they<tei:lb/>observed might actually be homologous in the taxa concerned and thus indicative of true affinity.<tei:lb/>Why?</tei:p>
         <tei:p>There are two reasons, one philosophical and one practical. We tend to develop a conception<tei:lb/>of a given taxon. We think of butterflies as a package, and develop what might be termed a<tei:lb/>butterfly Gestalt - colourful, diurnal lepidopterans with clubbed antennae and amplexiform<tei:lb/>rather than frenate wing-coupling. This is not to say that we do not recognize exceptions. Males<tei:lb/>of the skipper Euschemon Doubleday have a frenulum and retinaculum; satyrines generally are<tei:lb/>not brightly coloured, many butterflies do not have strongly clubbed antennae, and a few are<tei:lb/>nocturnal. By definition, exceptions do not destroy a Gestalt. But hedylids do not conform to the<tei:lb/>traditional butterfly package. They do not have clubbed antennae; in some species these<tei:lb/>structures are even bipectinate. In males of most species the frenulum and retinaculum are very<tei:lb/>well developed, and the wing pattern in most species bears little resemblance to that of<tei:lb/>butterflies (Figs 1-18). Most species seem to be nocturnal.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Most taxa are diagnosed by a set of attributes rather than by a single character or very few<tei:lb/>characters. Even so, such diagnoses often need qualification to incorporate those taxa that do<tei:lb/>not fit - for example, primitive species that have not yet acquired all the attributes of the<tei:lb/>majority, or those specialized species that have lost them secondarily. Crowson (1970), noting<tei:lb/>the essentialist nature of such diagnoses, called the groups Aristotelian to distinguish them from<tei:lb/>taxa delimited phylogenetically. Crowson also coined the phrase 'the non-congruence principle'<tei:lb/>to suggest that it is most unlikely that a taxon can be defined on more than one or two characters,<tei:lb/>since when a taxon originates many of the characters found in later members of the group have<tei:lb/>not yet evolved. Characters we regard as typical of a given taxon do not evolve at once.<tei:lb/>Therefore, in the present case, we should not expect the ground plan of the butterflies as a whole<tei:lb/>or even the true butterflies to exhibit the characteristics of the more advanced members of the<tei:lb/>group. It should not, then, be unexpected to find a group strongly affiliated to the butterflies that<tei:lb/>does not fit our conception of them . However , if it is our stated aim to produce , as far as possible ,<tei:lb/>a phylogenetic classification, then merely one derived character shared between two taxa<tei:lb/>provides evidence of monophyly. In fact, the Hedylidae possess several such characters.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Having rejected the idea that hedylids might be related to butterflies, neither Guenee nor<tei:lb/>Prout looked further. This may largely have been because morphological studies were less<tei:lb/>extensive in Guenee's time than they are today. Much the same can be said of Prout, who had a<tei:lb/>remarkable ability to observe structures and their significance on dried specimens, but did little<tei:lb/>dissection. (Only late in his career did he study genitalia.) In fact many of the characters that<tei:lb/>support the suggestion that hedylids are butterflies are to be observed only after detailed<tei:lb/>examination of the sclerites of the thorax and the base of the abdomen.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The present study evolved from a project to re-diagnose the Oenochrominae (Geometridae),<tei:lb/>and to exclude those groups that currently make the subfamily unnatural (non-monophyletic).<tei:lb/>The extraordinary combination of attributes of the Hedylidae demonstrates that their affinities<tei:lb/>lie neither with Oenochroma Guenee (the type genus of the Oenochrominae) and its relatives,<tei:lb/>nor with the Geometridae as a whole. In particular, abdominal tympanal organs, which are</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>NEW CONCEPT OF BUTTERFLIES 253</tei:p>
         <tei:p>typical of geometrids, are absent from hedylids. Also, prolegs are present on abdominal<tei:lb/>segments 3 to 6 and 10 of the larva, unlike most geometrids where their number is reduced. The<tei:lb/>first tergum of the abdomen is strongly 'pouched' (a condition described for papilionoids by<tei:lb/>Ehrlich, 1958&amp;), and pre- and postspiracular bars are present. The abdomen is curved and<tei:lb/>flattened laterally, particularly in the male. The remarkable pupa is attached to a leaf by a silken<tei:lb/>girdle: there is no cocoon. The apical tibial spurs of the hindleg are absent in all species except<tei:lb/>the male of one. The precoxal (or paracoxal) sulcus of the mesothorax joins the 'marginopleural'<tei:lb/>sulcus. In the metathorax the furcal apophysis is weakly sagittate in dorsal view. The pretarsus is<tei:lb/>lost from the forelegs of the male although minute claws are present, and the tarsomeres are<tei:lb/>reduced to two by fusion. The head of the larva is extended into a pair of extremely long horns,<tei:lb/>and there is an anal comb on abdominal segment 10. These characters are all represented<tei:lb/>in various butterflies. In contrast, the moth-like features include the absence of clubs on<tei:lb/>the antennae, and a well-developed frenulum and retinaculum in the males of most<tei:lb/>species, although they are reduced and functionless in a few. The wing venation is peculiar:<tei:lb/>Rsi and Rs 4 share a common stem, but Rs 2 is separate from the cell and is not stalked with Rs 3 .<tei:lb/>Rsi and Rs^ are distinctly sinuate. Special modifications of the wings, including a complex of<tei:lb/>small chambers at the base of the forewing and a prominent flap extending from Sc, are<tei:lb/>described below.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The body of this work aims to provide the evidence that suggests that hedylids are butterflies.<tei:lb/>Are the apparent butterfly attributes genuinely shared-derived characters of hedylids and<tei:lb/>butterflies or are they convergent or parallel developments? In short, are the Hedylidae more<tei:lb/>closely related to the butterflies than to any other lepidopterans?</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A further question is: are the Hedylidae more closely related to the true butterflies<tei:lb/>(Papilionoidea) than to the skippers (Hesperioidea), or does the family represent the sister<tei:lb/>group of the Rhopalocera as a whole?</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A general description of the characters found in this family is provided, together with a<tei:lb/>summary of its biology and distribution. This is followed by observations on selected structures<tei:lb/>with comments on their systematic importance. Finally, the evidence for the affinity of the<tei:lb/>Hedylidae with the Hesperioidea and the Papilionoidea is assessed.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Material</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The observations were based on specimens housed in the British Museum (Natural History).<tei:lb/>Juvenile stages of one species were lent by Mr R. O. Kendall, San Antonio, Texas.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Examination of the structure of the thorax was necessarily limited to avoid breaking up<tei:lb/>numerous specimens. From the study of more easily observed characters the family Hedylidae<tei:lb/>appears to be a homogeneous group, and thoracic structures probably do not differ significantly<tei:lb/>between species. Thoracic structure was examined in species that showed most structural<tei:lb/>variation in the genitalia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HEDYLIDAE Guenee</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hedylidae Guenee, 1857: 521. Type genus: Hedyle Guenee, 1857: 521.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Guenee (1857) described the family for three genera, Hedyle Guenee, Venodes Guenee, and<tei:lb/>Phellinodes Guenee. With the exception of Prout (1910; 1931), most authors have been content<tei:lb/>to describe new species or genera without discussing the taxonomic relationships of the group as<tei:lb/>a whole. Prout, in both these works, dealt with all the genera and species. He treated the taxon<tei:lb/>as a tribe - the 'Hedylicae' - of the subfamily Oenochrominae (Geometridae). Authors who<tei:lb/>preceded Prout assigned the genera to various infrafamilial categories of the Geometridae,<tei:lb/>some of which are not currently in use, with no justification for their action. Kendall (1976), in<tei:lb/>his notes on the life-history of one species, used the name Hedylidae, therefore effectively<tei:lb/>reviving Guenee's original status.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The use of the name Hedylidae is fully justified by Guenee's priority, Kendall's subsequent<tei:lb/>usage, and the absence of any competing name.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>254 M. J. SCOBLE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Generic synonymy</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The species of the family show no fundamental structural difference from each other, and form a<tei:lb/>highly compact group, particularly in the male genitalia, wing venation, wing shape, legs and<tei:lb/>antennae. Below, I synonymize the five genera that are currently accepted. Three of these are<tei:lb/>monotypic.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Macrosoma tipulata Hiibner and Lasiopates hyacinthina Warren are species that exhibit the<tei:lb/>greatest differences from the majority of the family. The valvae of the male genitalia of<tei:lb/>hyacinthina (Fig. 79) are of a more complex shape, the two components of the gnathos are not<tei:lb/>fused medially, and the juxta is characteristic.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>One reason for the proliferation of genera in the Lepidoptera is that since the study of the<tei:lb/>male genitalia became universal, there has been a strong tendency to treat as genera those<tei:lb/>groups where there is a morphological 'gap' in these structures. The consequence has been that<tei:lb/>although a family may contain a few large genera there are usually several anomalous species. If<tei:lb/>these are then excluded from one of the main genera each has to be assigned to a new genus. In a<tei:lb/>family with several large genera it may be impossible to decide to which genus such 'outlier'<tei:lb/>species should be assigned. The description of a new genus therefore becomes inevitable. In a<tei:lb/>family with one large genus there is often a good case to be made for including all species within<tei:lb/>that genus and using lower categorical rank, e.g. subgenus, or simply species-group, to<tei:lb/>distinguish outliers. In the present case, despite the synonymy, I have not so divided Macrosoma<tei:lb/>in this way. This is best left until such time as a revision of all the species is undertaken. The<tei:lb/>synonymized names can then be used as subgenera, if required.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MACROSOMA Hiibner</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Epirrita Hiibner, 1808. [Name unavailable, see Fletcher, 1979.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Macrosoma Hiibner, 1818: 10. Type species: Macrosoma tipulata Hiibner, 1818: 10 (by monotypy).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hedyle Guenee, 1857: 521. Type species: Hedyle heliconiaria Guenee, 1857 (by monotypy). [Four<tei:lb/>described species.] Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Venodes Guenee, 1857: 522. Type species: Venodes napiaria Guenee, 1857: 522 (by monotypy). [Mono-<tei:lb/>typic.] Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Phellinodes Guenee, 1857: 523. Type species: Phellinodes satellitiata Guenee, 1857: 523 (by monotypy).<tei:lb/>[Thirty-three described species.] Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Macrophila Walker, 1862: 1463, 1465. Type species: Macrosoma tipulata Hiibner, 1818 (by monotypy).<tei:lb/>[Junior objective synonym of Macrosoma, see Fletcher, 1979.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hyphedyle Warren, 1894: 375. Type species: Hedyle rubedinaria Walker, 1862: 1464 (by original<tei:lb/>designation). [Synonymized with Hedyle Guenee by Prout, 1910.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lasiopates Warren, 1905: 310. Type species: Lasiopates hyacinthina Warren, 1905: 311 (by original<tei:lb/>designation). [Monotypic.] Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hedylidae remains the valid name of the taxon since family names are not rejected when, after 1960,<tei:lb/>their type genera are found to be junior synonyms.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>General appearance</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hedylids are fairly delicate insects with curved abdomens, particularly in the male (Fig. 63). Figs<tei:lb/>1-18 show the main variation in wing patterns: many of the species bear semi-transparent<tei:lb/>patches on the wings. The fore wings are weakly or strongly emarginate at the apex. The larva<tei:lb/>(Figs 19, 100, 101) bears a pair of very long 'horns' on the head capsule, prolegs on abdominal<tei:lb/>segments 3 to 6 and 10, a pair of furcae on the anal segment, and an anal comb. The pupa (Figs<tei:lb/>20, 21) lacks a cocoon, and is attached to its substrate by a silken girdle.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Description</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Adult</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head (Figs 22-29). Frons narrow and protuberant (Figs 22, 23). Compound eyes large. Ocelli absent.<tei:lb/>Chaetosemata present, one chaetosema behind each eye (Fig. 22). Antenna (Figs 25-28): bases close</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>NEW CONCEPT OF BUTTERFLIES</tei:p>

Maxillae: palpi<tei:lb/>minute, one-segmented; galeae form a well-developed proboscis, not scaled at base. Labial palpi<tei:lb/>ascending (Fig. 24), three-segmented with a deep sensory invagination on distal segment (Fig. 29).<tei:lb/>Tentorium: medial swelling on each tentorial arm (Fig. 23), but dorsal arms not developed.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thorax (Figs 30, 31). Prothorax with membranous patagia and parapatagia; patagia protuberant.<tei:lb/>Mesothorax: anepisternum well developed, not reduced (Fig. 30); precoxal sulcus (paracoxal sulcus of<tei:lb/>Scott, 1985) joins 'marginopleural' suture (Fig. 31).
