         <tei:p>ventral plane, is a distension of base of Sc, the other, predominantly in the dorsal plane, a distension of Cu.<tei:lb/>Prominent ventral fold expands from Sc on underside (Figs 39, 40). Scale-enclosed pocket present at very<tei:lb/>base of underside of wing (Figs 40, 41). Hindwing rounded: in males often with folded area (of glassy<tei:lb/>appearance) present (Figs 10, 16, 44, 47); basally usually with associated sclerotized protuberances (Figs<tei:lb/>44-47, 50) and specialized scales (Figs 48, 49); base of costa weakly or, when frenulum is reduced, strongly<tei:lb/>expanded into a 'shoulder' (Fig. 35), composed of extended frenulum-plate and costal region.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Base of fore wing (Figs 37, 51). Second median plate with substantial part hidden under base of anal<tei:lb/>veins.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Legs (Figs 52-62). Microtrichia present on ventral surface at base of tarsi of mid leg and hind leg of male<tei:lb/>and all legs of female.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fore leg. Epiphysis present (Figs 52-54); tibial spurs absent. Male: tarsus (Figs 52, 55, 57, 58)<tei:lb/>two-segmented, number reduced by fusion but tarsus not shortened; pretarsus reduced to pair of minute<tei:lb/>claws (Fig. 58), empodium and pulvilli absent; tarsi not spined, but hairy; occasionally with a scent brush.<tei:lb/>Female: tarsomeres not fused, tarsi five-segmented (Fig. 54); pretarsus not reduced, bears a pair of<tei:lb/>strongly curved claws (Fig. 59) that are weakly and asymmetrically forked; pulvilli present; tarsus spined<tei:lb/>ventrally, not hairy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mid leg: with one pair of tibial spurs; tarsus five-segmented, tarsomeres not fused; pretarsus not<tei:lb/>reduced, tarsal claws weakly forked; tarsus spined on ventral surface.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hind leg: with one pair (Fig. 61) or occasionally two pairs (Fig. 62) of tibial spurs; tibia somewhat<tei:lb/>swollen; otherwise as mid leg.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdomen. Weakly to moderately curved (Fig. 63), flattened laterally not dorso-ventrally, and narrow-<tei:lb/>ing slightly towards base. Tympanal organs absent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pregenital abdomen (Figs 64, 65, 68). Segment I with narrow prespiracular bar'and broad postspiracular<tei:lb/>bar (tergopleural). Tergum I with large membranous pouch and strong tergal braces. Sternum II with pair<tei:lb/>of mediolateral sclerotizations anteriorly; sternal apodemes reduced.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>NEW CONCEPT OF BUTTERFLIES 259</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male postabdomen (Figs 66, 67). Tergum VIII longer than sternum VIII forming a short hood.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female postabdomen . Segment VII in form of a short hood over the genitalia ; tergum VII large ; sternum<tei:lb/>VII shorter, usually bearing a series of prominent setae on fold just anterior to the ostium bursae (Fig. 90).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male genitalia (Figs 69-80). Genital capsule is 'deep' dorso-ventrally owing to length of lateral arms of<tei:lb/>vinculum. Segment IX comprises a completely sclerotized ring, i.e. tergum and sternum fused. Tegumen<tei:lb/>narrow, sometimes prominently bilobed. Uncus large, usually triangular in ventral view since it narrows<tei:lb/>apically; alternatively apex is truncated or otherwise modified (Fig. 83). Vinculum: ventral plate narrow<tei:lb/>and produced into a prominent narrow saccus; rarely, saccus is rounded. Gnathos usually large and heavily<tei:lb/>sclerotized; occasionally lateral arms do not meet medially. Valvae (Figs 77-82) simple, undivided, usually<tei:lb/>approximately triangular. Diaphragm unsclerotized, or occasionally sclerotized as a juxta into a small<tei:lb/>simple plate or, rarely, a prominent U-shaped structure (Fig. 84). Aedeagus (Figs 85-89) a simple tube;<tei:lb/>vesica unmarked, or with weak sclerotizations.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female genitalia (Figs 90-99). Tergum VIII a well-sclerotized band. Anal papillae usually in form of a<tei:lb/>pair of ear-like lobes. Anterior apophyses sometimes reduced (Figs 93, 96). Posterior apophyses<tei:lb/>developed normally. Bursa copulatrix: a narrow ductus leads into a globose or sub-globose corpus; signum<tei:lb/>absent or present; if present then of a characteristic shape (Figs 98, 99).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Egg</tei:p>
         <tei:p>An egg, found while dissecting the female genitalia of a specimen, was oval.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Larva</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Based on M. heliconiaria (comb, n.) (Fig. 19, and see Kendall, 1976), with further information on M.<tei:lb/>nigrimacula (Warren) (comb, n.) derived from larval exuviae housed in the British Museum (Natural<tei:lb/>History). When this study was at an advanced stage, Mr T. Fox (London Butterfly House) provided a<tei:lb/>colour transparency of a larva (subsequently reared through) of M. cascaria (Schaus) (comb, n.), which he<tei:lb/>collected in Monte Verde, Costa Rica.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head. Head-capsule bears a pair of long horn-like processes, flattened and broad in heliconiaria (Fig. 100),<tei:lb/>not broad in nigrimacula (Fig. 101). (Tips of processes out of focus in transparency of cascaria.}<tei:lb/>Hypognathous. Mandibles toothed. Six ocelli present. Secondary setae present.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thorax and abdomen. Not pigmented. Secondary setae on dorsum capitate in heliconiaria, shorter and<tei:lb/>trifurcate in nigrimacula; row of knobbed setae run along midline in heliconiaria, absent from nigrimacula.<tei:lb/>Scoli absent. Primary setae not on pinaculi. True legs well developed, each bearing a single claw. Prolegs<tei:lb/>present on abdominal segments III to VI, and on X (Fig. 19). Plantae of ventral prolegs with crochets<tei:lb/>biordinal and uniserial; arranged in two transverse bands in heliconiaria and in a penellipse in nigrimacula.<tei:lb/>Abdominal segment X: anal plate extended into a pair of furcae; anal comb present.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pupa (Figs 20, 21)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Known for five species (heliconiaria, notes and illustrations by Kendall (1976), and personal examination;<tei:lb/>tipulata, exuvial remains; M. lucivittata (Walker) (comb, n.), nigrimacula, and cascaria (well-preserved<tei:lb/>pupal exuviae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The pupa is rather flattened, although raised protuberances arise from the thorax of heliconiaria,<tei:lb/>lucivittata, and nigrimacula, and from the abdomen of lucivittata, nigrimacula, and cascaria.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The pupa of all five species is attached to the substrate by a fine silk girdle around the thorax, and by a<tei:lb/>well-developed cremaster. There is no cocoon. The temporal cleavage line appears to be absent, although<tei:lb/>there is a very slight indication of a line running transversely across the top of the head. In each case (except<tei:lb/>for heliconiaria where a specimen was stored in alcohol) the pupa was attached to a leaf. However, as far as<tei:lb/>I know, pupation occurred in captivity in all specimens available so whether or not hedylid pupae are<tei:lb/>always attached to leaves in the wild requires confirmation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Host-plant</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Known only for heliconiaria: Buettneria aculiata Jacq., (Sterculiaceae). Recorded by Kendall (1976).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Habits</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The following comments, on heliconiaria, are based on Kendall (1976), who has provided what appears to<tei:lb/>be the only published information. The eggs are laid singly on top of leaves of Buettneria aculiata. The larva<tei:lb/>eats a series of small holes in the leaf. At rest it lies along the midrib. Kendall notes that the adults of<tei:lb/>heliconiaria are diurnal, as opposed to nocturnal, which may be exceptional for hedylids. Similar<tei:lb/>observations were made for the larva of cascaria collected by T. Fox from Costa Rica (pers. comm.). The<tei:lb/>specimen was found lying along the midrib on the upper surface of the leaf. The leaf of the food-plant<tei:lb/>(unidentified) to which the pupal exuviae is attached is largely consumed. From what remains it is clear that<tei:lb/>the larva had eaten several holes in the leaf.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>260</tei:p>
         <tei:p>M. J. SCOBLE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Parasites</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mirax sp. and Apanteles sp. (Braconidae), identified by P. M. Marsh, USDA, Washington D.C., have<tei:lb/>been reared from heliconiaria larvae (R. O. Kendall, pers. comm.).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Distribution</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Found in Central and South America: recorded from Paraguay, Brazil, Bolivia, Peru, Ecuador, Colombia,<tei:lb/>Venezuela, Guyana, Surinam, French Guiana, Panama, Costa Rica, Honduras, Guatemala, British<tei:lb/>Honduras, Mexico, Cuba, and Trinidad.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Specimens have been collected mostly from montane rain forest, occurring in many localities in the<tei:lb/>Andes. Material has been collected at localities up to 7000 ft.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Comments on selected structures</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Adult</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In this section further detail is provided about structures selected for their biological or systematic interest.<tei:lb/>Emphasis has been placed on comparing the Hedylidae with other macrolepidopterans, and in particular<tei:lb/>the Rhopalocera. I include as macrolepidopterans the following taxa: Castnioidea, Hesperioidea, Papi-<tei:lb/>lionoidea, Geometroidea (sensu Common, 1970), Calliduloidea, Bombycoidea (including Sphingidae and<tei:lb/>Saturniidae), and Noctuoidea. (Geometroidea is used as a term of convenience in this work. Minet (1983)<tei:lb/>argued that the superfamily is not monophyletic.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head. The compound eyes are large and constitute a relatively large portion of the total area of the head<tei:lb/>(Figs 22-24). There is some variation in size between species. The inner, dorsal angle of each eye is weakly<tei:lb/>emarginate where it meets the base of the antenna (Fig. 22). Eye-size is of little value in assessing<tei:lb/>phylogenetic relationships of higher taxa since it is related to habits. Large eyes tend to be associated with<tei:lb/>low light intensity. However, the large eyes of most true butterflies, a group that is typically diurnal, 'are<tei:lb/>specialized for high visual acuity at the expense of relatively poor absolute sensitivity'. The reverse is<tei:lb/>apparently true of moths (Bernard, quoted in Ferguson, 1985). Most hedylids are apparently nocturnal; on<tei:lb/>independent occasions, specimens have been collected at light by A. Watson, M. J. Matthews, and V. O.<tei:lb/>Becker (pers. comm.), and by the late C. L. Collenette (label data). However, heliconiaria is said to be<tei:lb/>diurnal by Kendall (1976).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>22 23</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Figs 22, 23 Head of Macrosoma tipulata Hiibner. 22, anterior aspect; 23, lateral aspect.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The narrow frons bulges moderately (Fig. 23), but not to the degree found for example in the<tei:lb/>Heliothinae (Noctuidae). The narrowness of the frons means that the bases of the antennae are close<tei:lb/>together (Fig. 22). The antennae are usually filiform (Figs 26, 27), but in some species they are bipectinate<tei:lb/>(Fig. 25). In those with filiform antennae, the flagellar segments are rectangular, sometimes almost square,<tei:lb/>and each bears various sensilla. Usually the sensilla are long and arranged approximately in the shape of a<tei:lb/>'U' on each side of the segments. They are shorter in females. In tipulata the segments are uniformly<tei:lb/>covered with shorter sensilla (Fig. 27). The more distal flagellar segments bear two or three longer setae,<tei:lb/>and also a sensillum basiconicum.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>NEW CONCEPT OF BUTTERFLIES</tei:p>
         <tei:p>261</tei:p>
         <tei:p>25</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Figs 24-29 Head and associated structures of Hedylidae. 24, head, lateral aspect, of Macrosoma<tei:lb/>hyadnthlna (Warren), x 7-4; 25, antenna of M. semlermis (Prout), d"; 26-28, antennal segments of (26)<tei:lb/>M. hyacinthina( Warren); (27) M. tipulataH\ibner;(28)M. venodes(Guene), $, arrow indicates reduced<tei:lb/>pectination; (29) labial palpus of M. tipulata Hiibner.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bipectinate antennae are found in both sexes of Macrosoma (= Hedyle) heliconiaria, and its close<tei:lb/>relatives M. semiermis (Prout) (comb, n.), M. inermis (Prout) (comb, n.), and M. albipannosa (Prout)<tei:lb/>(comb, n.), and in males of Macrosoma (= Venodes) napiaria (comb. n.). In the females of napiaria each<tei:lb/>pectination is reduced to a small knob on each side of every flagellar segment (Fig. 28). In those species<tei:lb/>with bipectinate antennae each pectination bears sensilla. The sensilla in males are slightly longer than in<tei:lb/>females.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>262 M. J. SCOBLE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The antennae extend about one-half to just under two-thirds of the length of the fore wing. Whether<tei:lb/>filiform or bipectinate they bear lamellar scales dorsally.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Chaetosemata are present, one chaetosema behind each eye (Fig. 22). They are fairly small, but can be<tei:lb/>seen on dried specimens. Ocelli are absent. The presence of chaetosemata and the absence of ocelli are<tei:lb/>conditions found in Hesperioidea, Papilionoidea, and in many Geometroidea amongst macrolepidopter-<tei:lb/>ans. Chaetosemata are absent from the front of the head. According to Jordan (1923), most Hesperiidae<tei:lb/>have a pair of chaetosemata additional to those on the vertex, sited between the crest of scales on the frons<tei:lb/>and the antennae. This additional pair is absent from papilionoids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mouthparts. The maxillary palpi are minute (Figs 22, 23), a condition found generally in larger<tei:lb/>lepidopterans. The proboscis is well developed. Its base is not scaled, which contrasts with the typically<tei:lb/>scaled condition found in Pyralidae. The labial palpus (Fig. 29) is three-segmented. The palpi are generally<tei:lb/>moderately ascending (Fig. 24) as a result of curvature of the basal segment, but are not appressed to the<tei:lb/>head as they are in papilionids and pierids. The invaginated sensory pit of the terminal segment is a<tei:lb/>character of the lepidopteran ground plan (Kristensen, 1984ft). In those hedylids examined for this<tei:lb/>character, the pit is deep, or moderately deep, and narrow.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vestiture. Long narrow scales form the main covering of the frons and vertex (Fig. 24). These scales are<tei:lb/>neither closely appressed to the head, nor do they form a strongly erect tuft. The labial palpi are covered<tei:lb/>with scales; on the lower surfaces, particularly of the two proximal segments, they are long and narrow,<tei:lb/>forming a fringe (Fig. 24).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thorax. To judge from the distribution of the sclerotized and membranous conditions of the patagia in true<tei:lb/>butterflies (Ehrlich, 1958ft), the membranous condition must have arisen independently on several<tei:lb/>occasions. The sclerotized state is regarded as primitive. The development of membranous patagia has<tei:lb/>probably occurred independently in other macrolepidopterans, although the general condition (including<tei:lb/>that of hesperiids) is of sclerotized patagia. The loss of sclerotized patagia is given as a butterfly 'trend' by<tei:lb/>Ehrlich (1958ft).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The size of the anepisternum of the mesothorax (Fig. 30) is not reduced, i.e., there is no pronounced<tei:lb/>dorsal movement of the anapleural cleft. A reduction is a prominent and specialized feature of Papi-<tei:lb/>lionoidea (Brock, 1971; figures of Ehrlich, 1958ft). In Hesperiidae the reduction is not so pronounced.<tei:lb/>Scott (1985) states that it is very large in moths and skippers; however, it is not large in all skippers.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In the mesothorax, the precoxal sulcus of hedylids appears to be fused with the sulcus (Fig. 31) called<tei:lb/>'marginopleural' by Shepard (1930) and Brock (1971). Usually these sulci are separate in the Lepidoptera.<tei:lb/>The precoxal sulcus does not curve towards the midline as it does in moths and skippers, and the<tei:lb/>basisternum is 'open' - not 'closed' by the sulcus. Brock (1971) drew attention to the divergent fused<tei:lb/>condition in papilionoids and noted that the primitive arrangement was retained in some Hesperiidae, but<tei:lb/>almost reached the specialized condition in advanced members of the group. Scott (1985) observed that in<tei:lb/>hesperiids, although the precoxal sulcus (his paracoxal sulcus) might meet the 'marginopleural', it does not<tei:lb/>fuse with it as in papilionoids. These structures are difficult to interpret and need a broader survey to test<tei:lb/>their soundness.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>There are two characters of particular importance in the metathoracic furca. In his study of the<tei:lb/>integumental anatomy of the Monarch butterfly, Danaus plexippus (L.), Ehrlich (1958a) noted that viewed<tei:lb/>dorsally the apophyses of the furca were shaped like an arrowhead. That this sagittate shape might be the<tei:lb/>general condition of both Hesperioidea and Papilionoidea was suggested by Brock (1971). (Brock treated<tei:lb/>the Hesperiidae as a family of the Papilionoidea.) In the Hedylidae the arrowhead is blunt, but<tei:lb/>nevertheless it is similar to that of other butterflies. The sagittate shape was not seen in the various<tei:lb/>macrolepidopterans examined by Brock. The shape is quite different in Oenochroma vinaria Guenee and<tei:lb/>O. polyspila Lower (Geometridae), andJosiafornax Druce (Dioptidae), which were examined during the<tei:lb/>course of this work.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The character of the metathoracic furca considered by Brock (1971) to be the most prominent and<tei:lb/>divergent for the butterflies was that which he referred to as 'the peculiar mesal fusion of the dorsal laminae<tei:lb/>of the secondary arms from the point of their association with the apophyses to a point level with the<tei:lb/>thoraco-abdominal conjunctival insertion'. This character was also included as one of the shared derived<tei:lb/>(apomorphic) features of the Hesperioidea and Papilionoidea by Kristensen (1976). If I understand<tei:lb/>Brock's description correctly, this mesal fusion is present in the Hedylidae. It can best be seen in dorsal<tei:lb/>view. Despite the weight given to this character by Brock (1971), the structure seems to be present in<tei:lb/>Oenochroma vinaria (Geometridae: Oenochrominae) and also in Archiearis Hiibner, a member of the<tei:lb/>primitive geometrid subfamily Archiearinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Wing venation (Fig. 32a). The venation does not seem to vary between species either in the number of<tei:lb/>veins present, or their branching pattern and disposition. In the fore wing the arrangement of the veins of<tei:lb/>the radial sector (Rs) is characteristic of the family. The sinuous course run by Rs l and Rs 2 is such that they</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>NEW CONCEPT OF BUTTERFLIES</tei:p>
         <tei:p>263</tei:p>
         <tei:p>a</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Figs 30-32 Hedylidae. 30, 31, mesothorax of Macrosoma rubedinaria (Walker): (30) ventrolateral<tei:lb/>aspect, (31) lateral aspect; 32, M. nigrimacula (Warren) (a) fore wing, (b) hind wing; anepisternum<tei:lb/>(am), katepisternum (km), basisternum (bm), precoxal sulcus (pcs), 'marginopleural' sulcus (mps).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>nearly meet at one point. The only stalking that occurs is that formed by the common stem of Rs 3 and Rs 4 .<tei:lb/>Veins R l , Rsi, and Rs 2 are all separate (at least from the cell). These veins fail to coalesce at any point so,<tei:lb/>unlike many macrolepidopterans, no secondary cells are formed. This pattern is generalized, and<tei:lb/>approximates to that exhibited by the more primitive of the macrolepidopteran elements. Unlike several<tei:lb/>lineages of higher Lepidoptera, there is no inward migration ('splitting back') of veins. The arrangement of</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>264</tei:p>
         <tei:p>M. J. SCOBLE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>33</tei:p>
         <tei:p/>
         <tei:p>Figs 33-36 Wing-coupling apparatus in Hedylidae. 33, frenulum of Macrosoma hyacinthina (Warren);<tei:lb/>34, retinaculum of M. bahiata (Felder), view from ventral surface; 35, 36, frenular bristles of (35) M.<tei:lb/>napiaria (Guenee), cf, (36) M. satellitiata satellitiata (Guenee), $.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Rs therefore provides few clues to relationships, although it further supports the exclusion of the group<tei:lb/>from advanced geometroids, calliduloids, bombycoids, and noctuoids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vein MI is remote from Rs 4 , a condition widely encountered, unlike the arrangement found in<tei:lb/>Epiplemidae and Uraniidae where these branches are associated. The usual geometroid condition, and<tei:lb/>indeed that of most higher Ditrysia, is that /?s 3 and Rs 2 share a common stem, and Rs 4 arises from this joint<tei:lb/>stem nearer to the cell (i.e. proximally). A notable exception is the Papilionoidea where Rsj and Rs 4 are<tei:lb/>often associated as in hedylids. In the Hesperioidea there is no 'stalking' of the veins whatsoever; all run<tei:lb/>independently from the cell to the apex of the termen. Vein M is very weakly, but definitely, visible in the<tei:lb/>cell.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CuP is often present, but weak.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hind wing venation (Fig. 32b). Vein Sc+/?j is remote from Rs from the base of the cell; the condition<tei:lb/>contrasts with that found in geometrids and drepanids, but is not dissimilar from Epiplemidae and<tei:lb/>Uraniidae. The presence of two anal veins in the hind wing is more frequently encountered in the<tei:lb/>butterflies (including Hesperiidae), bombycoids and noctuoids amongst the higher Ditrysia, than in<tei:lb/>geometroids (s.l.). The rather generalized occurrence of both these attributes therefore is of little value in<tei:lb/>assessing the relationships of Macrosoma. Nevertheless both features indicate yet further the remoteness<tei:lb/>of the genus from the Geometridae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>M 2 does not arise nearer MI than M 3 .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Wing coupling (Figs 33-37). In males, a single-spined frenulum is usually well developed on the hind</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>NEW CONCEPT OF BUTTERFLIES</tei:p>
         <tei:p>265</tei:p>
         <tei:p>37</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 37 Macrosoma hyacinthina (Warren), base of fore wing, ventral aspect; anterior chamber (ac),<tei:lb/>posterior chamber (pc), subcostal fold (fd).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>wing (Fig. 33). It engages a long retinaculum on the fore wing (Figs 34, 37, 39). The length of the<tei:lb/>retinaculum is related to the need for it to extend over the prominent subcostal fold so as to engage the<tei:lb/>frenulum (Figs 37, 39). The frenulo-retinacular system is reduced and probably non-functional in the males<tei:lb/>of three species: M. subornata (Warren) (comb, n.), M. leucoplethes (Prout) (comb, n.), and napiaria. In<tei:lb/>the first two species the frenulum remains as a single spine, but it is much weaker and shorter. In napiaria it<tei:lb/>is reduced to a few short bristles (Fig. 35). The retinaculum of napiaria is lost, while in subornata and<tei:lb/>leucoplethes it is reduced to a very short, and presumably functionless structure. Although the frenulum<tei:lb/>and retinaculum are reduced in subornata and leucoplethes, the system is well developed in the closely<tei:lb/>related M. desueta (Prout) (comb. n.).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In females there are sometimes a few weak costal bristles on the hindwing (Fig. 36). There is no sign of a<tei:lb/>retinaculum, and functionally the frenulo-retinacular system is lost in this sex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In Hesperioidea and Papilionoidea the frenulum and retinaculum are lost but remarkably, these<tei:lb/>structures are present in males of the hesperiid Euschemon. Scott (1985) notes that Euschemon is<tei:lb/>otherwise a typical pyrgine hesperiid and suggests an independent development of the frenulum and<tei:lb/>retinaculum through perhaps a reverse mutation. The loss of the frenulum and retinaculum or even of the<tei:lb/>retinaculum alone has occurred many times within the Lepidoptera besides the butterflies, e.g. in<tei:lb/>bombycoids, uraniids and some drepanids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Wing surface. There is no holding area (Haftfeld) on the underside of the base of the fore wing and the<tei:lb/>metascutum of the thorax. These patches of velcro-like microtrichia (aculei) are absent from Hesper-<tei:lb/>ioidea, Papilionoidea, Geometroidea, and most Bombycoidea, a feature considered to be related to the<tei:lb/>resting position of the wings (Common, 1969; Kuijten, 1974). In general, those Lepidoptera with wings<tei:lb/>folded over the body have holding areas on the fore wings and thorax, whereas those with wings held<tei:lb/>vertically at rest or at right angles to the body do not.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vestiture. Two kinds of scales predominate on the wing-surface (Fig. 38): (a) broad, 'typical',<tei:lb/>overlapping scales, and (b) hair-like scales. The wings appear to be hairy in parts. The broad scales do not<tei:lb/>provide a dense cover to the wings; hedylids are relatively weakly scaled. In several species there are small<tei:lb/>hyaline patches devoid of scales, or larger areas with semi-transparent scales. The small hyaline patches<tei:lb/>may be seen with the naked eye on some specimens (Figs 10, 16). The hair-like scales are more dense on the<tei:lb/>basal section of the upperside, and somewhat more dense on the underside.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Figs 1-18 illustrates the main kinds of wing patterns in the Hedylidae. Of particular note is that the<tei:lb/>markings on both dorsal and ventral surfaces are, with very minor exceptions, the same, compare Fig. 12<tei:lb/>with Fig. 18. At least one hedylid may hold its wings vertically at rest so exposing the underside (R. O.<tei:lb/>Kendall, pers. comm.) although this requires confirmation. Such a resting position may be related to the<tei:lb/>strong patterning on the underside . In M. subornata the posterior half of the underside is pale and contrasts</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>266 M. J. SCOBLE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>sharply with both the rest of the underside and with that of the upper surface. The habit of holding the<tei:lb/>wings vertically is common among butterflies, and is also to be seen in several geometrids. (I am grateful to<tei:lb/>Dr K. Sattler for suggesting the resting position of hedylids.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>There are several relatively distinct wing-patterns in hedylids, as well as other patterns that are less<tei:lb/>distinct. Frequently, elements of one subgroup are found in another. For example, large areas covered by<tei:lb/>semi-transparent scales are present in many species as are small, but distinctive, white triangular marks on<tei:lb/>the costa of the fore wing near the apex. In some species the apex of the fore wing bears a large patch of<tei:lb/>either chestnut or dark brown. The illustrations show the distinctive emargination of the apex of the<tei:lb/>forewing, a condition found in many species, and the weakly falcate shape of them all. The comments that<tei:lb/>follow are an adjunct to the black and white photographs to provide a guide to colour.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>M. heliconiaria (Guenee) (Fig. 1). Ground colour darkish grey-brown with translucent patches on fore<tei:lb/>and hind wings. The small triangular mark on the costa of the fore wing is white.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>M. hyacinthina (Warren) (comb, n.) (Fig. 2). Ground colour dark grey-brown with a purple iridescence.<tei:lb/>More brown than grey at apex of fore wing. The pale patches on both wings are covered with<tei:lb/>semi-transparent scales except for the subtriangular mark on the costa of the fore wing, which is white.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>M. tipulata Hiibner (Fig. 3). A pale species. The wings bear large areas of semi-transparent scales. The<tei:lb/>darker areas are pale brown, and the small irregular patches on the fore wing are white, edged with darker<tei:lb/>brown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>M. rubedinaria (Walker) (comb, n.) (Fig. 4). Ground colour brown. The small dark streaks are dark<tei:lb/>brown, edged with white.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>M. ustrinaria (Herrich-Schaffer) (comb, n.) (Fig. 5). A pale species. The darker scales scattered<tei:lb/>unevenly over the wing surfaces are pale brown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>M. leucophasiata (Thierry-Mieg) (comb, n.) (Fig. 6). The pale areas are white and the dark parts dark to<tei:lb/>very dark grey-brown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>M. subornata (Warren) (Fig. 7). Ground colour brown, dark brown near apices of wings. The patch on<tei:lb/>the costa is cream, and the patch below it and the tiny spot to one side are white. On the underside the<tei:lb/>posterior half of the fore wing is pale, contrasting markedly with the equivalent section of the upper<tei:lb/>surface.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>M. paularia (Schaus) (comb, n.) (Fig. 8). Ground colour of fore wing pale grey-brown flecked and<tei:lb/>streaked with dark brown. The large spot at the apex of the fore wing is a warm pale brown. The large pale<tei:lb/>area on the hind wing is composed of semi-transparent scales.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>M. coscoja (Dognin) (comb, n.) (Fig. 9). Ground colour pale brown. Apex of fore wing dark brown. The<tei:lb/>small patch at the base of the strong apical patch is composed of semi-transparent scales.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>M. satellitiata (Guenee) (comb, n.) (Fig. 10). Ground colour a darker brown than that of coscoja.<tei:lb/>Otherwise similar to that species. The small 'white' spot at the base of the hind wing represents the glassy<tei:lb/>modification in males discussed below.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>M. albifascia albifascia (Warren) (comb, n.) (Fig. 11). Ground colour grey-brown. The pale area on the<tei:lb/>fore wing is semi-transparent. The apex of the fore wing is a warm pale brown thickly edged with dark<tei:lb/>brown. The very dark streak and patches on the fore wing are also dark brown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>M. hedylaria (Warren) (comb, n.) (Figs 12, 18). The colour pattern is extremely similar to heliconiaria,<tei:lb/>although the apex of the fore wing is more brown than grey-brown. The name hedylaria is obviously a<tei:lb/>composite of Hedyle (the genus in which heliconiaria was described but which is treated as a junior<tei:lb/>synonym of Macrosoma in the present work) and heliconiaria.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>M. lucivittata (Walker) c? (Fig. 13). Ground colour brown. The pale areas are covered with semi-<tei:lb/>transparent scales and many brown piliform scales. 9 (Fig. 14). Similar to the male but with a distinct<tei:lb/>semi-transparent spot near the apex of the fore wing.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>M. nigrimacula (Warren) (Fig. 15). Ground colour brown, flecked and spotted with dark brown. The<tei:lb/>semi-transparent areas are poorly defined on the upper surface in this species. On the underside of the fore<tei:lb/>wing the posterior half bears a large pale grey area that contrasts with the rest of the wing.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>M. leptosiata (Felder) (comb, n.) (Fig. 16). Ground colour brown. Both fore and hind wing edged with<tei:lb/>darker brown distally, particularly on the fore wing.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>M. napiaria (Guenee) (Fig. 17). Ground colour off-white, formed by a covering of semi-transparent<tei:lb/>scales. The veins of the fore wing are a more strongly pigmented shade of cream.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Modification of the fore wings (Figs 37, 39-43). The base of the fore wing bears some apparently unique<tei:lb/>modifications. These take the form of a ventral expansion of vein Sc into a fold, and the presence of two<tei:lb/>small, rounded chambers developed within the bases of certain veins. A pocket is also present and is<tei:lb/>enclosed by a dense fringe of scales. These modifications occur within both males and females. In addition,<tei:lb/>a distinct lobe is formed near the anal edge of the fore wing in males of some species.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>NEW CONCEPT OF BUTTERFLIES</tei:p>
         <tei:p>267</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Figs 38-43 Fore wing structure (ventral aspects) of Hedylidae. 38, vestiture of fore wing of Macrosoma<tei:lb/>tipulata Hiibner; 39, base of fore wing of M. hyacinthina (Warren) to show subcostal fold (fd); 40, 41,<tei:lb/>scanning electron micrographs of base of fore wing of M. tipulata Hiibner; (40) x 16, large arrow<tei:lb/>indicates pocket, small arrow shows base of retinaculum, (41) detail of pocket x 40,? tympanum (tm);<tei:lb/>42, base of fore wing of M. hyacinthina (Warren), arrow indicates position of membrane (see text); 43,<tei:lb/>lobe at base of fore wing of M. hyacinthina (Warren).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>268 M. J. SCOBLE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The expansion of Sc on the underside of the fore wing is prominent (Figs 37, 39, 40). There is some<tei:lb/>variation in its extent between species, but the form is basically similar. This fold is a hollow outgrowth of<tei:lb/>the vein (although both membranes are close together and not 'ballooned'). The fold extends a short way<tei:lb/>along the wing. At the extreme base of the fore wing, Sc is expanded into a hollow chamber (Figs 37, 42) the<tei:lb/>main part of which lies ventral to the plane of the wing. This chamber is divided from the fold by a<tei:lb/>membrane that runs at right angles to the plane of the wing. The position of this membrane is arrowed in<tei:lb/>Fig. 42; it is visible as a dark line in this view. The chamber is invaginated caudally effectively providing<tei:lb/>another pocket, which is enclosed by a thick fringe of hair-scales (Figs 40, 41). The posterior wall of the<tei:lb/>chamber is invaginated. From the ventral exterior lip of this invagination arises a thick fringe of hair-scales<tei:lb/>(Fig. 40 and particularly Fig. 41). Below this fringe, and presumably protected by it, is an extremely<tei:lb/>delicate, transparent membrane. This is supported by a cuticular frame at the base of Cu, also lying in the<tei:lb/>ventral plane of the wing. Stretched over the other (posterior) side of this frame is a whitish membrane,<tei:lb/>which closely resembles the tympanum found in the auditory organs of certain Lepidoptera (Fig. 41).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lying mainly within the dorsal plane of the fore wing is another small , closed chamber (Figs 37 , 42) . This<tei:lb/>chamber is an expansion of the base of the cubitus, 'Cu^ in the terminology of Sharplin (1963).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>47</tei:p>
         <tei:p>.-&gt;ja ??</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Figs 44-47 Scanning electron micrographs of specialized structures on hind wing (ventral aspects) of<tei:lb/>Hedylidae. 44-46, Macrosoma tipulata Hiibner: (44) general view of area x 16, (45) detail of squat<tei:lb/>protuberance, x 140, (46) detail of finger-like protuberance, x 160; 47, M. zikani conifera (Warren)<tei:lb/>(comb, n.), base of hind wing x 16.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>NEW CONCEPT OF BUTTERFLIES</tei:p>
         <tei:p>269</tei:p>
         <tei:p>50</tei:p>
         <tei:p>51</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Figs 48-51 Wing structures of Hedylidae. 48, 49, scale from specialized area of hind wing (ventral<tei:lb/>surface) ofMacrosoma tipulata Hiibner, (48) whole scale, x 2600, (49) detail to show serrations x 6500;<tei:lb/>50, specialized structure near base of hind wing (ventral surface) of M. nigrimacula (Warren); 51, base of<tei:lb/>fore wing of M. hyacinthina (Warren) to show position of second median plate partly hidden under \A<tei:lb/>(arrowed).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Although the function of these chambers is unknown, there are several similarities with the tympanal<tei:lb/>organs found at the base of the fore wing in many nymphalid butterflies. The structure of these alar<tei:lb/>tympanal organs is summarized by Bourgogne (1951). In both hedylids and those nymphalids with these<tei:lb/>organs, the tympanum is situated at the base of vein Cu. Unlike thoracic or abdominal hearing organs,<tei:lb/>there is no tympanic cavity; instead, the tympanum is superficial. In nymphalids, the membrane is<tei:lb/>protected by scales, but in hedylids it is more exposed. In most of those nymphalids with alar hearing<tei:lb/>organs, veins Sc and Cu are swollen basally, and the tracheal air sacs within the swellings communicate with<tei:lb/>the tympanic sac (Bourgogne, 1951). It is uncertain whether there is a functional relationship between the<tei:lb/>sacs, but it should be noted that not all nymphalids with hearing organs have swollen veins. In the<tei:lb/>Hedylidae the veins are not swollen.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>It is well known that some butterflies respond to sound. Swihart (1967) demonstrated the sensitivity to</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>270</tei:p>
         <tei:p>M. J. SCOBLE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>sound of a small chamber at the base of each hind wing of Heliconius erato (L.). He also found a similar, but<tei:lb/>smaller, chamber at the base of each fore wing.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>No information is available on the question of whether hedylids respond to sound, but on circumstantial<tei:lb/>evidence it seems likely that the modifications at the base of the fore wing function as an auditory organ.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The possibility that the chamber enclosed by the fringe of hairs is a scent pouch cannot be discounted , but<tei:lb/>the pocket is present in both males and females. The presence of 'scent pockets' tends to be sexually<tei:lb/>dimorphic in lepidopterans, but is not always so.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A small lobe extends from the anal edge of the fore wing near its base in the males of some species. It is<tei:lb/>prominent in hyacinthina (Fig. 43). A very weakly developed expansion of this area is found in many<tei:lb/>species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Modifications of the hind wing (males). These are present in many species. Viewed with the naked eye<tei:lb/>they appear as small, oval, glassy areas at the base of the wing on both the upper and the under sides (Figs<tei:lb/>10, 16). The modifications take the form of a folding of the wing membrane, making the surface appear<tei:lb/>rather crinkled or distorted when viewed under a dissecting microscope. Their appearance under the<tei:lb/>scanning electron microscope is shown in Figs 44 and 47. From this area one or more protuberances arise on<tei:lb/>the under side of the wing (Figs 44-47, 50). The area is covered with specialized scales.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In hyacinthina the modified area may be roughly divided into an inner, approximately oval section,<tei:lb/>which bears short piliform scales on both surfaces, and an outer section with both piliform scales and<tei:lb/>semi-transparent laminar scales. A prominent knob-like structure is present on the underside.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The modifications of the hind wing are well developed in many other species, and less pronounced in<tei:lb/>several more. Modifications present in one species may be absent from closely related ones. In M. bahiata<tei:lb/>(Felder) (comb, n.) for example they are present, while in coscoja, a close relative, they are not. In the<tei:lb/>same group of species the structures are less strongly pronounced in M. albistria (Prout) (comb, n.) and M.<tei:lb/>uniformis (Warren). In tipulata two protuberances are present (Fig. 44) of which one is relatively squat<tei:lb/>(Fig. 45), and the other is a long digitate structure, which is slightly swollen apically (Fig. 46). The function<tei:lb/>of these protuberances is uncertain, but since they are confined to the males they are probably scent organs<tei:lb/>of some kind. Figs 48 and 49 illustrate the specialized scales found on the surface of the structure in tipulata.<tei:lb/>The longitudinal ridges are strongly serrated (Fig. 49).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>54</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Figs 52-54 Fore legs of male Hedylidae. 52, Macrosoma semiermis (Prout), tibia and tarsus; 53, 54,<tei:lb/>epiphysis of (53) M. tipulata Hiibner, (54) M. napiaria (Guenee).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>NEW CONCEPT OF BUTTERFLIES 271</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Wing base. According to Dr R. de Jong (pers. comm. and in prep.), to whom I am indebted for sketches<tei:lb/>and information, the second median plate of the fore wing is always partly hidden under the base of vein 1A<tei:lb/>in both Hesperioidea and Papilionoidea. The general ditrysian condition seems to be that the plate is not<tei:lb/>obscured by 1A. In the Hedylidae the second median plate is small and partly obscured by 1A (Fig. 51).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Legs. An epiphysis is present on the fore leg of both males and females (Figs 52-56). The presence of this<tei:lb/>structure is widespread among macrolepidopterans including the Hesperiidae (with a few exceptions) and<tei:lb/>Papilionidae, but it is lost in many Pieridae, Nymphalidae, Libytheidae, and Lycaenidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In males the fore tarsi are modified (Figs 55, 58). Although they are not reduced in length (in fact they are<tei:lb/>long or very long) the segments are mostly fused so that only a long proximal segment and a short distal<tei:lb/>segment are present. In tipulata the proximal segment is extremely long (Fig. 55).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The pretarsus of the fore leg is reduced to a pair of small claws in males (Figs 52, 58). In some species<tei:lb/>these claws are minute, and in all species they are only very weakly curved. There is no arolium, or<tei:lb/>empodium, nor are there pulvilli on the fore tarsi of males. The fore tarsi bear a prominent fringe of<tei:lb/>piliform scales giving them a feathery appearance. There are no spines.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In females the fore tarsi are not modified (e.g. tipulata, Fig. 56). There are five tarsomeres and the<tei:lb/>pretarsus bears claws that are strongly curved and asymmetrically forked, pulvilli, and a large arolium. The<tei:lb/>tarsomeres are covered with laminar, not piliform, scales, and a series of small spines is present.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The mid and hind tarsi in both males and females are five-segmented, spined, and with a normally<tei:lb/>developed pretarsus with claws, pulvilli and an arolium. The mid leg is generally longer than the hind leg,<tei:lb/>but shorter than the fore leg.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Microtrichia or aculei ('tiny spines' of Scott, 1985) are not present on the dorsal aspect of the tarsi, unlike<tei:lb/>the Papilionidae, Pieridae, some Nymphalidae and some Lycaenidae. According to Scott they are absent<tei:lb/>from hesperiids and from other macrolepidopterans. Microtrichia are, however, present on the ventral<tei:lb/>aspect of the tarsi of Hedylidae although their distribution is patchy, being best developed on the pulvilli.<tei:lb/>They are absent from the fore tarsi of males. Ventral microtrichia are probably widespread in Lepidoptera.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A single pair of tibial spurs is present on the midleg of both sexes (Fig. 61). The hind leg of the male of<tei:lb/>tipulata bears two pairs of tibial spurs (Fig. 62), but usually hedylids (including the female of tipulata) have<tei:lb/>one pair distally on the hind tibia. The proximal pair of spurs is found in many Lepidoptera, e.g. some<tei:lb/>Thyrididae, some Hesperiidae, some Drepanidae, many Bombycoidea (including Sphingidae), and many<tei:lb/>Noctuoidea (including Notodontidae). This loss is a classic example of a character that is prone to<tei:lb/>independent reduction in many groups. Therefore the loss of spurs in most hedylids and in papilionoids<tei:lb/>does not provide strong evidence for their monophyly. In one female specimen of hyacinthina there is<tei:lb/>apparently no pretarsus at all on the hind leg: the tarsus ends in a flask-shaped tarsomere (Fig. 60). There is<tei:lb/>no sign of claws arising from this last tarsomere. Of the two other females in the collection of the British<tei:lb/>Museum (Natural History), one has lost both hind legs while in the other the tarsi, including the pretarsus,<tei:lb/>are normal. In many species the hind tibia is slightly swollen.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A scent pencil occurs on the fore tibia of males of five species (hyacinthina, lucivittata, M. klagesi (Prout)<tei:lb/>(comb, n.), and nigrimacula, and probably (only one specimen available) on M. latiplex (Dognin) (comb.<tei:lb/>n.)). The pencil comprises a bunch of long hairs arising from the inner surface of the tibia. It is particularly<tei:lb/>well developed in hedylaria.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The modifications of the legs of the Hedylidae are all found within other butterflies. Information for<tei:lb/>Hesperioidea and Papilionoidea is summarized in a useful table by Scott (1985: table 1). Pulvilli and the<tei:lb/>arolium are lost from the legs of Papilionidae, some Pieridae, and some Nymphalidae. In the Papilionidae<tei:lb/>and the Pieridae the tarsomeres are not fused. In Nymphalidae the male fore legs are small although the<tei:lb/>tarsomeres are not lost or fused. In Lycaenidae the male fore legs are reduced to a single tarsomere<tei:lb/>together with reduction or loss of claws. The proximal pair of tibial spurs on the hind leg is absent from all<tei:lb/>true butterflies (Ehrlich, 1958ft; Scott, 1985) and hedylids (with the exception of the male of tipulata), but<tei:lb/>these spurs are present in skippers. Scent brushes, when present, tend to be found on the hind legs of<tei:lb/>butterflies; they occur on the fore legs of Hedylidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdomen. The abdomen is distinctly curved, particularly in males (Fig. 63), and is laterally flattened. Not<tei:lb/>only are these features butterfly-like, but from my initial observations they resemble true butterflies<tei:lb/>(Papilionoidea) rather than skippers (Hesperioidea). This interpretation, however, remains tentative.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tergum I is 'pouched' (Figs 64, 68), that is, there is a pocket-like outgrowth of tergum I posteriorly that<tei:lb/>overlaps tergum II. Ehrlich (19586) used the word 'pouched' to describe the typical papilionoid condition.<tei:lb/>The pouching in hesperioids is not strong, and in some papilionids the pouch is reduced (Ehrlich, 1958ft).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>On segment I there are pre- and postspiracular bars. The prespiracular bar (Figs 64, 68) is a narrow<tei:lb/>sternopleural structure, which extends anteriorly from the antero-lateral margin of sternum II, and curves<tei:lb/>around the spiracle. The presence of a prespiracular bar is the general condition in macrolepidopterans,<tei:lb/>including hesperioids and papilionoids, although it is lost in pierids (Ehrlich, 1958ft). The presence of this</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>272</tei:p>
         <tei:p>M. J. SCOBLE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>N</tei:p>
         <tei:p>*.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>55</tei:p>
         <tei:p>56</tei:p>
         <tei:p/>
         <tei:p>57</tei:p>
         <tei:p>58</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Figs 55-58 Fore legs of Hedylidae. 55, 56, Macrosoma tipulata Hiibner: (55) cf , (56) $ ; 57, M. hedylaria<tei:lb/>(Warren), O"; 58, M. semiermis (Prout), tarsal claws of O", arrowed.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>NEW CONCEPT OF BUTTERFLIES</tei:p>
         <tei:p>273</tei:p>
         <tei:p>59</tei:p>
         <tei:p>60</tei:p>
         <tei:p>61</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Figs 59-62 Legs of Hedylidae. 59, pretarsus of Macrosoma tipulata Hiibner, 9, showing weak fork of<tei:lb/>claw; 60, last (5th) tarsal segment of hind leg of M. hyadnthina (Warren), $ ; 61, 62, hind tibia of (61) M.<tei:lb/>hedylaria (Warren), c? , (62) M. tipulata Hiibner, cf .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>structure in the Hedylidae is therefore of no particular phylogenetic significance. Brock (1971) considers<tei:lb/>that both pre- and postspiracular bars are secondarily developed within the Papilionoidea and Hesper-<tei:lb/>ioidea (his Papilionoidea) and analogous to similar structures in certain Pyraloidea, Geometroidea and<tei:lb/>Noctuoidea. It is not entirely clear why Brock does not consider them homologous.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The postspiracular bar is well-developed in the Hedylidae. It is a tergopleural structure (Figs 64, 68),<tei:lb/>which just fails to meet the sternum. According to Brock (1971) the postspiracular bar is derived from terga<tei:lb/>I and II. Ehrlich (19586) considered the presence of a postspiracular bar to be specialized within the<tei:lb/>Papilionoidea, where he presumably considers it to have evolved independently within the group. Scott<tei:lb/>(1985) records the bar as absent in Papilionidae (Ehrlich said it was reduced or absent), present or absent in<tei:lb/>Nymphalidae, present and large in Libytheidae, and absent in Lycaenidae. He notes its presence in or<tei:lb/>absence from Hesperioidea and its absence from other macrolepidopterans. Both Ehrlich and Scott<tei:lb/>consider the structure as derived. The occurrence of a similar structure in some other macrolepidopterans</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>274</tei:p>
         <tei:p>M. J. SCOBLE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>63</tei:p>
         <tei:p>64</tei:p>
         <tei:p/>
         <tei:p>66</tei:p>
         <tei:p>tg Vlll</tei:p>
         <tei:p>67</tei:p>
         <tei:p>65</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Figs 63-67 Abdomen of Hedylidae. 63, 64, Macrosoma bahiata (Felder), lateral aspect: (63) whole<tei:lb/>abdomen, (64) base of abdomen, small arrow - pre spiracular sclerotization, large arrow - post<tei:lb/>spiracular sclerotization; 65, sternum II (st II) of M. paularia (Schaus); 66, segment VIII of M. semiermis<tei:lb/>(Prout), d", lateral aspect; 67, tergum VIII (tg VIII) of M. tipulata Hubner, cf .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(e.g. Thyrididae) noted by Brock is probably too isolated to suggest that the structure in the butterflies is<tei:lb/>not derived.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The tergal groove is well developed and leads into a strong tergal brace - the internal ridge of the groove<tei:lb/>(Fig. 64).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>There are no abdominal tympanal organs in the Hedylidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male genitalia (Figs 69-89). The lateral arms of the vinculum are long, so the genital capsule appears<tei:lb/>'deep', that is, expanded dorso-ventrally. The natural way to mount these structures for microscopic slide<tei:lb/>preparation is laterally, since if they are mounted ventrally they tend to topple over on the slide. Most</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>NEW CONCEPT OF BUTTERFLIES</tei:p>
         <tei:p>275</tei:p>
         <tei:p>68</tei:p>
         <tei:p>69</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Figs 68-71 Abdomen and male genitalia of Hedylidae. 68, segments I and II of Macrosoma bahiata<tei:lb/>(Felder), lateral aspect, abbreviations as for Fig. 64; 69-71, male genitalia, lateral view, of (69) M.<tei:lb/>semiermis (Prout), (70) M. hyacmthina (Warren), (71) M. paularia (Schaus).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>butterfly systematists mount male genitalia laterally for the same reason. The genitalia of the Hedylidae are<tei:lb/>similar to those of many butterflies in the shape of the genital capsule. They might be regarded as fairly<tei:lb/>generalized butterfly genitalia, but this does not provide strong evidence for the monophyly of hedylids and<tei:lb/>other butterflies since the arrangement might be primitive. Certainly the Castniidae also have genitalia that<tei:lb/>are 'deep'. The lateral arms are fused with the tegumen so that segment IX of the abdomen forms a closed<tei:lb/>ring (e.g. Figs 73, 74), a feature noted as a tentative ground plan character of the Amphiesmenoptera<tei:lb/>(Kristensen &amp; Nielsen, 1979: 126; Kristensen, 1984&amp;: 150). The condition frequently encountered in the<tei:lb/>Lepidoptera is that of a distinct separation of the tergum and sternum of segment IX.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The valva is approximately triangular, and unmodified. This condition is found in many species of<tei:lb/>macrolepidopterans including many butterflies.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>There are no particularly striking modifications of the main components of the genitalia. The greatest</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>276</tei:p>
         <tei:p>M. J. SCOBLE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Figs 72-76 Male genital capsules of Hedylidae. 72-74, lateral aspects of (72) Macrosoma tipulata<tei:lb/>Hiibner, (73) M. lamellifera (Prout), (74) M. napiaria (Guenee); 75, 76, ventral aspects of (75) M.<tei:lb/>napiaria (Guenee); 76; M. nigrimacula (Warren) (a) valvae and juxta removed, (b) valvae and juxta.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>modifications are the shapes of the uncus in heliconiaria (Fig. 83), the valva (Fig. 79) and juxta (Fig. 84) of<tei:lb/>hyacinthina, and the simplification of the genitalia of tipulata (Fig. 72).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female postabdomen and genitalia (Figs 90-99). Tergum VII is longer than tergum VI and forms a weak<tei:lb/>hood over the genitalia, when they are not extended. Tergum VIII is well-sclerotized and narrow (Fig. 90),<tei:lb/>and gives rise to a pair of thin, anterior apophyses. In most species examined these are sclerotized, but in<tei:lb/>some they are membranous (staining in Chlorazol black E), and short (Figs 93, 96). Presumably, in those<tei:lb/>species with reduced apophyses the muscles are functionless during oviposition. In hyacinthina and</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>NEW CONCEPT OF BUTTERFLIES</tei:p>
         <tei:p>277</tei:p>
         <tei:p>78</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Figs 77-84 Male genitalia of Hedylidae. 77-82, valvae of (77) Macrosoma heliconiaria (Guenee), (78)<tei:lb/>M. semiermis (Prout), (79) M. hyacinthina (Warren), (80) M. lamellifera (Prout) (comb, n.), (81) M.<tei:lb/>nigrimacula (Warren), (82) M. napiaria (Guenee); 83, uncus of M. heliconiaria (Guenee), ventral view;<tei:lb/>84, juxta of M. hyacinthina (Warren), valvae at different plane of focus.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>278</tei:p>
         <tei:p>M. J. SCOBLE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Figs 85-89 Male genitalia, aedeagus, of Hedylidae. 85, Macrosoma heliconiaria (Guenee); 86, M.<tei:lb/>hyacinthina (Warren); 89, M. napiaria (Guenee).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>hedylaria the reduced anterior apophyses are usually bent inwards (medially) at their ends at about right<tei:lb/>angles. Reduced anterior apophyses are found in many butterflies.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Terga IX and X form a sclerotized band more narrow than tergum VIII. The posterior apophyses, which<tei:lb/>are derived from this, are sclerotized rods.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ventrally, sternum VII is folded before the ostium bursae thus forming a lip to this aperture. The lip is<tei:lb/>nearly always fringed with strong setae (Fig. 90). The sclerotizations around the ostium bursae include<tei:lb/>anterior, posterior, and lateral components. The antevaginal and postvaginal sclerites are small, while the<tei:lb/>lateral sclerites (derived from sternum VIII) are large and extend laterally to unite with the anterior<tei:lb/>apophyses in those species where they are sclerotized. The extent of these ostial sclerotizations varies<tei:lb/>between species. In heliconiaria the lamella postvaginalis is absent as are the setae on the fold of sternum<tei:lb/>VII. In tipulata the sclerotizations are virtually absent (Fig. 97).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>NEW CONCEPT OF BUTTERFLIES</tei:p>
         <tei:p>279</tei:p>
         <tei:p>91</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Figs 90-91 Female postabdomen and genitalia of Hedylidae. 90, Macrosoma hedylaria (Warren),<tei:lb/>abdominal sternum VII, ventral aspect, antrum (an); 91, M. lucivittata (Walker), lateral aspect.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Figs 92-95 Female genitalia of Hedylidae. 92-94, ventral aspect of (92) Macrosoma rubedinaria<tei:lb/>(Walker), (93) M. hyacinthina (Warren), anterior apophysis arrowed, (94) M. rubedinaria (Walker) to<tei:lb/>show well-sclerotized anterior apophyses; 95, M. lucivittata (Walker), lateral aspect.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>280</tei:p>
         <tei:p>M. J. SCOBLE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>98</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Figs 96-99 Female genitalia of Hedylidae. 96, 97, lateral aspect of (96) Macrosoma hedylaria (Warren),<tei:lb/>anterior apophysis arrowed, (97) M. tipulata Hiibner; 98, 99, signum of (98) M. lucivittata (Walker), (99)<tei:lb/>M. rubedinaria (Walker).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The ostium bursae leads into the ductus bursae, the first part of which is funnel-shaped with sclerotized<tei:lb/>walls, the antrum (Fig. 94). Beyond this the ductus bursae is narrow, membranous, and usually long. It<tei:lb/>expands suddenly into a globose or slightly elongate-globose membranous corpus bursae (Fig. 91). The<tei:lb/>corpus bursae may bear a single signum of a characteristic shape (Figs 98, 99) , or the signum may be absent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The weakly telescoped ovipositor ends in a pair of large, soft, setose, ear-like lobes (Figs 92, 93).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Juvenile stages</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The shape of the egg varies within the Lepidoptera, but it is essentially flat or upright (Chapman, 1896).<tei:lb/>Many butterflies have upright eggs. In the Hesperiidae, however, they are flat. The oval egg dissected from<tei:lb/>the macerated abdomen of a female hedylid appears to be of the flat variety, but its shape did not resemble<tei:lb/>that of the hesperiid egg. Since both flat and upright eggs are found within single families, or even single<tei:lb/>genera, (Hinton, 1981), the gross shape of the egg is of limited phylogenetic significance.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The larva (Fig. 19) exhibits features of various butterfly families rather than any one of them. Its<tei:lb/>horn-like processes (Figs 19, 100, 101) strongly resemble those of many Nymphalidae. The secondary setae<tei:lb/>on the body are like those of some pierids. The crochets on the ventral prolegs of the final instar , which are<tei:lb/>arranged in a penellipse or as transverse bands, are neither like those of hesperiids (in which they form a<tei:lb/>circle) nor like papilionoids (where, in post first instars, they are usually arranged in a mesoseries) . An anal<tei:lb/>comb (found in Hedylidae) is usually present in Hesperiidae and at least some Pieridae among the<tei:lb/>macrolepidopterans.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The pupa (Figs 20, 21) resembles that found in Papilionidae (see Igarashi, 1984) or Pieridae, amongst the<tei:lb/>butterflies, in that it is attached to the substrate by both a girdle and a cremaster, and that there is no<tei:lb/>cocoon. A girdle is present in some sterrhine geometrids, e.g. Anisodes Guenee (see Common, 1986) and<tei:lb/>Cyclophora Hiibner. However, these genera lack the other butterfly characters discussed in the present</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>NEW CONCEPT OF BUTTERFLIES</tei:p>
         <tei:p>281</tei:p>
         <tei:p>100</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Figs 100, 101 Half of head capsule of larval exuviae of Hedylidae. 100, Macrosoma heliconiaria<tei:lb/>(Guenee); 101, M. nigrimacula (Warren).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>work. Furthermore, whereas the girdles of butterflies (including hedylids) are thoracic, those of sterrhine<tei:lb/>geometrids are spun around the abdomen (Holloway, pers. comm. - information derived from unpub-<tei:lb/>lished manuscripts housed in the British Museum (Natural History); and see Fig. 3 of Common, 1986 for an<tei:lb/>Anisodes girdle). The presence of a thoracic girdle is probably a ground plan character of the Rhopalocera,<tei:lb/>although weak cocoons are usually present in hesperiids. Loss of the cocoon is a typically papilionoid<tei:lb/>character, although it is present in Parnassius Latreille (Papilionidae) and weak and web-like in some<tei:lb/>satyrines. The girdle is present in Pieridae and Papilionidae, but is lost in Nymphalidae and many<tei:lb/>Lycaenidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A termporal cleavage line is said by Scott (1985) to be present in Hesperiidae, but absent from<tei:lb/>Papilionoidea. Mosher (1916) referred to the line as the epicranial suture. The apparent absence of the line<tei:lb/>in the Hedylidae is therefore like that of true butterflies rather than that of skippers. A temporal cleavage<tei:lb/>line is found in many moths. Mosher notes its presence in Lycaenidae, although Scott (1985: table 1)<tei:lb/>records it as absent from that family.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Discussion</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Hedylidae exhibit a high degree of structural uniformity. Several characters seem to be<tei:lb/>unique to the family, which provides evidence for its suspected monophyly. The most striking<tei:lb/>are the small chambers at the base of the fore wing, the protuberances on the underside of the<tei:lb/>hind wing, the sinuous course of veins Rsi and Rs 2 of the radial sector in the fore wing, and the<tei:lb/>long fore tarsi of the male composed of only two tarsomeres.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Two important questions about the phylogeny of the Hedylidae need to be discussed. First,<tei:lb/>are hedylids members of a taxon composed of Hesperioidea plus Papilionoidea plus themselves,<tei:lb/>i.e., are they butterflies in the broadest sense? Second, if so, what are the relationships of<tei:lb/>hedylids, hesperiids, and papilionoids to each other: do hedylids represent the sister group of the<tei:lb/>taxon Hesperioidea plus Papilionoidea (i.e. the Rhopalocera), or are they more closely related<tei:lb/>to the Hesperioidea or to the Papilionoidea than are either of these two related to each other? I<tei:lb/>shall argue that the Hedylidae are indeed 'butterflies' in the broadest sense. That they may<tei:lb/>represent the sister group of the Papilionoidea remains an intriguing possibility. This possibility<tei:lb/>is not a conclusion of this work: it would be premature and requires further comparison of the<tei:lb/>three taxa involved.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>282 M. J. SCOBLE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A separate, but related, problem is how to treat the nomenclature. Papilionoidea and<tei:lb/>Hesperioidea are widely used names, although Hesperioidea, consisting as it does of a single<tei:lb/>family, is redundant (Farris, 1976; Wiley, 1979), assuming that the Megathyminae are not<tei:lb/>viewed as an independent family. How should the Hedylidae be treated?</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Although the butterflies are one of the best studied groups of organisms, the published<tei:lb/>evidence for their monophyly is certainly not overwhelming. Ehrlich (19586) regarded hesper-<tei:lb/>iids as papilionoids that retain a great many primitive characters. Both Ehrlich and Kristensen<tei:lb/>(1976) retained the two superfamilies and did not synonymize them, Ehrlich because he<tei:lb/>considered the phenetic distance between them sufficiently great, and Kristensen because he<tei:lb/>considered the sister-group relationship a reasonable working hypothesis but one that required<tei:lb/>confirmation. Although the consensus is that hesperioids and papilionoids do form a<tei:lb/>monophyletic group, the characters on which this argument is based are not entirely convincing.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Kristensen (1976) records six possible specialized characters (apomorphies) shared by the two<tei:lb/>taxa, two of which he considers doubtful. However, none of them have been examined in a great<tei:lb/>number of species of butterflies and moths. Until they are examined they must remain somewhat<tei:lb/>in doubt. A particular problem with these characters is that they are not observable on dried<tei:lb/>specimens. Some of the characters can only be seen on alcohol-preserved, or fixed material (e.g.<tei:lb/>the twist in the oblique lateral dorsal muscle of the mesothorax, and the structure of the aorta in<tei:lb/>the mesothorax). Those that can be observed on dried specimens require maceration of the head<tei:lb/>or thorax, and have been examined, inevitably, in a limited number of Lepidoptera. A detailed<tei:lb/>study of the relationships of the Hesperioidea and the Papilionoidea is being undertaken by Dr<tei:lb/>R. de Jong, who has found several specialized characters considered to support the sister-group<tei:lb/>relationship of the two taxa. If hedylids are the sister group of papilionoids then several of de<tei:lb/>Jong's characters will have to be treated as homoplasious. It would be premature to treat the<tei:lb/>Hedylidae as the sister group of the Papilionoidea while de Jong's detailed work is in progress.<tei:lb/>For this reason it has not been possible to make unequivocal statements about precisely which<tei:lb/>taxa some of the characters 'define'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Recently Scott (1985) has discussed the phylogeny of the butterflies. From his table 1, the<tei:lb/>characters that appear to support the monophyly of the papilionoids and hesperioids are: the<tei:lb/>presence of a postspiracular bar, found in skippers but not in Papilionidae, some Nymphalidae,<tei:lb/>and Lycaenidae, and the presence of a secondary sternopleural sulcus, variable in size, but<tei:lb/>present in all butterflies.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>No other specialized features are tabulated by Scott as unique to the adults of all butterflies,<tei:lb/>with the possible exception of the absence of spurs on the tibia of the mid leg. However,<tei:lb/>although the spurs are absent from skippers, they are lost only in Papilionidae within the true<tei:lb/>butterflies so the condition is likely to be a parallel development.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Of the attributes of the Hedylidae described and discussed above, 13 are of particular<tei:lb/>significance in the discussion of the question of the relationship of the Hedylidae to the skippers<tei:lb/>and true butterflies. Of these several resemble the condition in true butterflies rather than<tei:lb/>skippers.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(1). Apophyses of metathoracic furca sagittate. The sagittate condition appears to be a<tei:lb/>specialized character of the three taxa. It certainly deserves examination in many more species<tei:lb/>to establish that it is definitely absent from moths and therefore diagnostic of butterflies.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(2). Pupa girdled. Ehrlich (19586) and Scott (1985) regard a girdled pupa in butterflies as<tei:lb/>primitive and its absence as specialized. Scott considers this condition to have been present in<tei:lb/>the ancestor of hesperioids and papilionoids. There is no general survey of the occurrence of<tei:lb/>girdled pupae in the Lepidoptera, so to suggest that the condition is diagnostic of hedylids,<tei:lb/>hesperioids, and papilionoids needs to be treated with caution. This attribute derives its<tei:lb/>taxonomic strength in conjunction with others.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(3). Second median plate of fore wing lies partly under the base of vein L4. Although this<tei:lb/>character requires examination in a wide range of Lepidoptera, it appears to support the view of<tei:lb/>the monophyly of the Hesperioidea plus the Papilionoidea (de Jong, pers. comm.) plus the<tei:lb/>Hedylidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(4). Presence of an anal comb in the larva. This structure, which is present in Hesperioidea</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>NEW CONCEPT OF BUTTERFLIES 283</tei:p>
         <tei:p>and Hedylidae, seems to be confined to the Pieridae in the Papilionoidea. It may reasonably be<tei:lb/>assumed to be a ground plan character of the Papilionoidea. The presence of an anal comb in the<tei:lb/>Tortricidae is probably an independent development. However, if the Macrolepidoptera are not<tei:lb/>monophyletic then the closest relatives of the Rhopalocera may be found among the microlepi-<tei:lb/>dopterans. The tortricoid/cossoid assemblage might be a serious contender.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(5). Presence of a postspiracular bar on the first abdominal segment. Postspiracular scler-<tei:lb/>otizations are present on the first abdominal segment of non-ditrysian moths (see for example<tei:lb/>Kyrki, 1983; Kristensen, 1984a - 'lateral lobe of tergum F lo in his figure 2). That the presence of<tei:lb/>a secondary sclerotization (postspiracular bar) is a character of the ground plan of hedylids,<tei:lb/>hesperioids, and papilionoids is a reasonable supposition. The presence of a postspiracular bar<tei:lb/>in certain Pyraloidea (those without tympanal organs), certain Geometroidea (Drepanidae,<tei:lb/>Thyatiridae, and most Uraniidae), and Noctuoidea (many families) (Brock, 1971) must cast<tei:lb/>some doubt on the value of the structure as an indicator of the monophyly of hedylids,<tei:lb/>hesperioids, and papilionoids. The postspiracular bar is recorded as absent from macrolepidop-<tei:lb/>terans by Scott (1985: table 1), although he made no comment on the postspiracular sclerotiza-<tei:lb/>tions in the macrolepidopteran families discussed by Brock (1971).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(6). Reduction of anterior apophyses in female genitalia. The weak, reduced anterior<tei:lb/>apophyses in some Hedylidae is a condition found also in many butterflies (de Jong, pers.<tei:lb/>comm.). Whether this is a ground plan character of hedylids, hesperioids, and papilionoids, or<tei:lb/>whether it is one that is subject to extensive parallelism is unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(7). Abdomen curved, particularly in males. As noted above, the shape of the abdomen<tei:lb/>resembles that of the true butterflies rather than that found in skippers. This character is only<tei:lb/>doubtfully a unique derivation of Hedylidae + Papilionoidea. A detailed study, preferably<tei:lb/>measuring the degree of curvature, is needed to ascertain whether the condition in Hedylidae<tei:lb/>and Papilionoidea is greater than that found in Hesperiidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(8). Abdominal tergum I strongly 'pouched'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(9). Precoxal (paracoxal) sulcus joins 'marginopleural' sulcus. This character appears to<tei:lb/>be a specialization of the Hedylidae and the Papilionoidea. The main objections to this view<tei:lb/>are that the sulci are difficult to observe, and that they have been examined in relatively few<tei:lb/>species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(10). Pupal cocoon lost. Unlike the condition in hesperioids, the cocoon of hedylids and most<tei:lb/>papilionoids is lost. Loss of a cocoon occurs elsewhere in the Lepidoptera, so this character is of<tei:lb/>doubtful value and derives its strength in consideration with others.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(11). Loss of temporal cleavage line in pupa. The loss of this cleavage line in both hedylids<tei:lb/>and papilionoids is further, although rather weak, evidence for their close relationship.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(12). Crochets of ventral prolegs of larva not forming a complete circle. This character is<tei:lb/>based on an examination of only two species. The penellipse ofnigrimacula, and the transverse<tei:lb/>bands of heliconiaria are neither the typical circle of hesperiids nor the usual mesoseries of<tei:lb/>papilionoids. It is possible, considering other characters of the family, that the hedylid condition<tei:lb/>is part of a transformation series circle &gt; penellipse &gt; mesoseries, but this remains a tentative<tei:lb/>suggestion.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(13). Loss of pretarsus in the fore leg of males. Reduction or loss of the pretarsus is<tei:lb/>widespread in butterflies. A reduction of the pulvilli and arolium is the condition found in all legs<tei:lb/>of the most primitive papilionoids. The initial reduction, confined as it is to the fore legs of the<tei:lb/>male, appears to be the first stage of a reduction fully established in the papilionoids. Therefore<tei:lb/>either the character is a shared specialization of the Hedylidae plus Papilionoidea or it has<tei:lb/>developed in parallel in the two groups. The possibility remains that the pretarsus is redeveloped<tei:lb/>(a reversal) in hesperiids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Nomenclature</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Papilionoidea are generally regarded as a separate superfamily from the Hesperioidea, although<tei:lb/>Brock (1971) combined the two in Papilionoidea. In the present study I follow convention and retain both<tei:lb/>taxa as superfamilies since the relationships between the Hesperioidea and the Papilionoidea is being<tei:lb/>studied in detail by R. de Jong. Also, Kristensen (1976) noted some uncertainties about the sister group</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>284 M. J. SCOBLE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>relationship of the two groups, and recently Stallingseffl/. (1985, quoting C. L. Remington) made a similar<tei:lb/>point.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>It would be premature to formally asign the Hedylidae to the Papilionoidea at this stage, so to retain<tei:lb/>equivalence of rank they are treated as a superfamily (Hedyloidea stat. n.). Consequently, the<tei:lb/>Rhopalocera now include three superfamilies Hesperioidea, Hedyloidea, and Papilionoidea, all of<tei:lb/>interchangeable position (sedis mutabilis, Wiley, 1979).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Epilogue: a suggested phytogeny</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Although this work concluded with the conservative suggestion that hedylids are rhopalocerans<tei:lb/>of which the precise relationships remain uncertain, the following dendrogram (Fig. 102) is a<tei:lb/>fully resolved three taxon statement presented to stimulate critical assessment.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>7-13</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1-6</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 102 Dendrogram to suggest possible phylogenetic relationships of Hesperioidea, Hedyloidea and<tei:lb/>Papilionoidea. Numbers represent the characters in the Discussion. Relative strengths and weaknesses<tei:lb/>of the characters are not indicated, but are considered in the text.</tei:p>

I thank both, and further express my gratitude to R. de Jong who<tei:lb/>made available unpublished sketches and other information from his work on the phylogenetic rela-<tei:lb/>tionships within the butterflies.          <tei:p>286 M. J. SCOBLE</tei:p>

         <tei:p>systems. Systematic Zoology 28: 308-337.<tei:lb/>Wootton, R. J. 1979. Function, homology and terminology in insect wings. Systematic Entomology 4:</tei:p>

      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>British Museum (Natural History)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Milkweed butterflies: their cladistics and biology</tei:p>
         <tei:p>P. R. Ackery &amp; R. I. Vane- Wright</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Danainae, a subfamily of the Nymphalidae, contains only some 150 species, yet aspects of<tei:lb/>their biology have stimulated far more attention than can be justified by species numbers<tei:lb/>alone. In recent years, an expansive literature has grown, considering aspects of their<tei:lb/>courtship and pre-courtship behaviour, migration, larval hostplan associations, mimicry and<tei:lb/>genetics. The popularity of danaines among biologists can certainly be attributed to this<tei:lb/>combination, within one small group, of so many of the factors that make butterflies such an<tei:lb/>interesting group to study. The obvious need to place this wealth of biological data within an<tei:lb/>acceptable systematic framework provided the impetus for this volume.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Started eight years ago within the conventions of evolution by natural selection and<tei:lb/>Hennig's phylogenetic systematics, the book is now largely about natural history (what the<tei:lb/>animals have and do, where they live and how they develop) and natural groups - as revealed<tei:lb/>by a form of analysis approaching that practised by the new school of 'transformed cladistics' .<tei:lb/>The authors have prepared a handbook that will appeal to a wide range of biologists, from<tei:lb/>museum taxonomists to field ecologists.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>425 pp, 12 pp colour, 73 b/vv plates, line and graphic illustrations, maps, extensive bibliography.<tei:lb/>ISBN 565 00893 5. 1984. Price 50.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
